The fire was started in two places along a little-traveled road, with evidence found at the scene.
A $250,000 reward is offered for information leading to an arrest.

Here are the highlights:

Winds that fueled Southern California wildfires ease, allowing firefighters to gain ground.
Dry Santa Ana winds changed direction, increasing humidity and easing fire burden.
Firefighting aircraft resume flights, dropping fire retardant on blazes.
Fire damage increases to 434,543 acres, with 1,664 structures destroyed.

Here are the highlights:

Sudanese court finds British teacher Gillian Gibbons guilty of insulting religion.
She is sentenced to 15 days in prison for naming a teddy bear "Mohammed".
Gibbons faces deportation from Sudan after her prison term, her lawyer says.
She plans to appeal the verdict.

Here are the highlights:

Seven college students died in a weekend fire at a North Carolina beach house.
The owner's 18-year-old daughter survived but is hospitalized with smoke inhalation.
Authorities are investigating the cause of the fire, which engulfed the house in flames.
Six University of South Carolina students and one Clemson University student died in the fire.

Here are the highlights:

Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez cuts ties with Colombia until Alvaro Uribe is no longer president.
Uribe withdrew support for Chavez's mediation efforts with FARC, citing protocol breach.
Chavez accuses Uribe of lying and bowing to US pressure to get rid of him.
Chavez says his arms are open to the Colombian people despite the rift.

Here are the highlights:

Diagnosed with type I diabetes at age 7 by Dr. Robert Deputy.
Learnt to test urine for sugar, give insulin injections, and follow a diabetic diet.
Advancements in technology improved management, including home blood glucose testing kits and insulin pumps.
Continuous glucose monitors provide constant readings, paving the way for a "closed loop" system.

Ray Gravell, former Wales and British Lions center, dies at 56 from suspected heart attack.
He won 23 caps for Wales and played on the 1980 Lions tour of South Africa.
Gravell was a respected rugby broadcaster and actor after his playing career.
He was praised for his passion, flair, and dignity, and was a great ambassador for Wales.

Here are the highlights:

Barack Obama's gospel concerts in South Carolina featured Donnie McClurkin, a singer who opposes homosexuality.
Gay bloggers criticized Obama for associating with McClurkin, calling it "sucking up to anti-gay bigots".
Obama's campaign said he strongly disagrees with McClurkin's views and will fight for gay rights as president.
Obama held a conference call with gay leaders, but some remain disappointed with his decision to keep McClurkin on the bill.

Atletico Madrid crush Real Zaragoza 4-0 in Primera Liga, moving up to sixth place.
Luis Garcia scores his first goal for Atletico, with Maxi Rodriguez and Diego Forlan also scoring.
Getafe win their first game of the season with a 2-0 victory over Murcia.
Valladolid struggles continue with a 2-1 loss to Athletic Bilbao.

The Venetian Resort Hotel Casino opened in Las Vegas in May 1999 with 3,036 suites.
The property received recognition for revolutionizing the Las Vegas hotel industry and won several awards.
The Venetian added the 1,013-suite Venezia tower in 2003, expanding its suite count to 4,027.
Las Vegas Sands Corp. went public in 2004, with shares rising 61% on its opening day.

Here are the highlights:

US Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice urges State Department officials to serve in Iraq, even in war-torn areas.
Rice says people need to serve where they are needed, amid objections from foreign service officers.
The new directive would be the first since the Vietnam War era, with 200 officials notified to serve in Baghdad.
Those who decline could face dismissal unless they have a valid medical reason.

Here are the highlights:

Four bodies found in a canyon, bringing death toll to seven, as firefighters battle 23 fires across seven counties.
Improving weather conditions allow more people to return home, but new evacuations ordered in some areas.
President Bush visits affected areas, promising federal help and declaring a disaster zone.
Fires have destroyed over 472,000 acres, with estimated damage to homes and businesses topping $1 billion.

Cmdr. Michael B. Portland relieved of command due to loss of confidence in his ability to command.
Crew falsified inspection records for nuclear reactor's cooling system to cover up misconduct.
Six personnel punished for forging records, one officer and five enlisted personnel.
Cmdr. William J. Houston to replace Portland as USS Hampton's new commander.

A bus crashed into a pickup truck and an 18-wheeler on Interstate-40 in Arkansas, killing 3 people.
The crash injured 40 others and shut down a 13-mile stretch of the highway.
The bus was traveling from Chicago to Dallas with 44 passengers on board.
Two passengers and the pickup truck driver were killed in the crash.

Here are the highlights:

Kelly Pless weighed 220 pounds at her heaviest, but lost 95 pounds through diet and exercise.
She struggled with weight her whole adult life, gaining as a teenager and losing 50 pounds after high school.
Pless started walking and eventually running, adopting an "eat to live" philosophy and portion control.
She's kept the weight off for 1.5 years and is now training for two marathons.

Here are the highlights:

Singapore Airlines' A380 completes maiden passenger journey between Singapore and Sydney.
The double bed on board is the first of its kind on a commercial jet.
The luxury cabin features private suites, Givenchy tableware, and a 23-inch widescreen LCD.
The flight sets a new standard for air travel with its quiet, fuel-efficient design.

Here are the highlights:

The Justice Department plans to combat illegal export of US military tech to Iran and China.
Iran is the only country still flying the F-14 Tomcat, a highly sought-after jet.
US to tighten monitoring of export licenses and increase restrictions on dual-use technologies.
Recent cases involve illegal exports of stealth missile tech, military aircraft components, and night vision equipment.

King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia's visit to London sparked dissent among UK political elite and protesters.
UK foreign secretary pulled out of meeting with Saudi counterpart to attend to his new adopted son.
Saudi Arabia is the UK's largest trading partner in the Middle East, with $2.8 billion in exports expected in 2007.
UK and Saudi Arabia signed a $10 billion deal for 72 Eurofighter Typhoon Jets.

Tens of thousands of Congolese refugees fled camps in the Democratic Republic of Congo amid rebel attacks.
Refugees were forced to flee due to fighting between government forces and rebel troops.
UNHCR reports that 28,000 refugees abandoned three camps, while 2,000 left a fourth camp.
Refugees are in dire need of shelter, water, and medical aid due to the harsh conditions.

Genarlow Wilson, freed from prison, says he's glad he rejected plea deal to avoid sex offender label.
He served 2 years of 10-year sentence for aggravated child molestation.
Wilson says he wants to major in sociology and focus on his college studies.
He vows to be more conservative, alert, and appreciative of his blessings.

Here are the highlights:

Two key Democratic senators, Feinstein and Schumer, will vote in favor of Michael Mukasey's attorney general nomination.
Mukasey's views on "waterboarding" and presidential power to order electronic surveillance raised concerns among Democrats.
Feinstein praises Mukasey's integrity and independence, citing his fresh leadership for the Justice Department.
Schumer says Mukasey is "far better than anyone could expect from this administration".

Here are the highlights:

9 people killed, 19 injured in tour bus crash in southeastern Utah on Sunday night.
Bus carrying 50 people from Telluride, Colorado to Phoenix, Arizona left highway and rolled over.
Road was wet but not icy, police said; bus lost control on curve and rolled 41 feet down embankment.
Four men and five women died in the crash, with most passengers returning from a ski trip.

Banksy is Britain's most wanted artist, known for his subversive and satirical public art.
His work sells for hundreds of thousands of dollars, despite his secret identity.
Ten of his original pieces sold at auction for over $1 million last week.
Banksy's art is now sold by major galleries, including Lazarides Gallery in London.

Naples, Italy faces a garbage crisis due to mismanagement, mafia profiteering, and lack of accountability.
The city's dumps are overflowing, and a state of emergency has been declared multiple times.
€1.8 billion in emergency funds have been allocated, but it's unclear how the money has been spent.
Citizens are protesting the planned re-opening of a dump, which will ruin a promised golf course development.

Here are the highlights:

Russia's President Vladimir Putin orders regular bomber patrols beyond borders due to security threats.
14 strategic bombers took off simultaneously from airfields across Russia on long-range missions.
Putin hopes partners will understand this move, which is seen as a show of military strength.
The move is likely to add to Western concerns about Russia's growing assertiveness.

Here are the highlights:

• Louis' Lunch in New Haven, Connecticut claims to have invented the hamburger in 1900.
• The Fried Twinkie was invented by Christopher Sell at The ChipShop in Brooklyn, New York.
• Frank J. Wisner created the Root Beer Float in Cripple Creek, Colorado in 1893.
• Ed Waldmire, Jr. debuted the Corn Dog on a stick at Cozy Dog Drive In in Springfield, Illinois in 1946.

Here are the highlights:

Azerbaijan authorities uncovered a radical Islamic terror plot against the US Embassy in Baku.
The plot was foiled after a weekend raid that netted several suspected members of the radical group.
The US Embassy in Baku closed to the public as a precaution, with Britain also shutting its embassy.
The threat may or may not be linked to a Saturday raid that killed one suspect and arrested several others.

Here are the highlights:

North Korean freighter crew regains control from pirates off Somalia after deadly fight.
Two pirates killed, five captured, and three crew members wounded in the battle.
US Navy destroyer USS James E. Williams assisted in the operation, ordering pirates to surrender.
Pirates had seized the ship's bridge, but crew kept control of steering gear and engines.

Debra Lafave, ex-teacher, violated probation by hugging a 17-year-old co-worker at a Florida restaurant.
She was convicted of having sex with a 14-year-old student in 2005.
Lafave claimed the hug was innocent and part of a casual work atmosphere.
She was given a verbal reprimand and ordered to quit her job.

Here are the highlights:

Ralph Lauren's designs have had a significant impact on American fashion and the concept of the "Good Life".
He founded his company, Polo, because "it was the sport of kings, glamorous, sexy and international".
Lauren's focus is on creating consistent and accessible clothing that stands for something and evolves over time.
He plans to expand his brand globally, with more stores in China, Japan, and other countries.

Here are the highlights:

Suspect John Lewis captured at Miami homeless shelter after being spotted on a Miami-bound bus.
He was unarmed and without incident, according to Miami Police Chief John Timoney.
Lewis is suspected of fatally shooting Philadelphia Police Officer Chuck Cassidy on October 31.
He was arrested twice on drug charges, with the second case still pending.

Here are the highlights:

Hyundai Tiburon: A sporty coupe with a shark-like design, available for around $20,000.
Mazda MazdaSpeed3: A pocket rocket with a 263-hp engine and seven-speaker Bose stereo.
Pontiac G5 GT Coupe: A stylish and performance-oriented car with a 173-hp engine and good gas mileage.
Ford Mustang V6: A revamped chassis and 210-hp engine make it an outstanding value at a lower price.

Here are the highlights:

President Bush criticizes Congress for having "the worst record in 20 years" and not getting work done.
He accuses Congress of wasting time on investigations and failed votes on Iraq.
Bush threatens to veto a "three-bill pileup" and urges Congress to pass bills one at a time.
He also criticizes Congress for not sending a single appropriations bill to him.

Sniper Lee Boyd Malvo struggles with shame, guilt, and remorse in prison.
He draws self-portraits with tears, reflecting his emotional state.
Malvo is serving a life sentence in Virginia's maximum-security Red Onion prison.
He was brainwashed by John Allen Muhammad into aiding the deadly shooting spree.

Here are the highlights:

Italy coach Roberto Donadoni keeps Cristiano Lucarelli in the squad for the Euro 2008 qualifier against Scotland.
Lucarelli scores twice against South Africa and is rewarded for his fine form.
Veteran forwards Filippo Inzaghi and Alessandro Del Piero are left out of the squad.
Fabio Cannavaro returns from suspension and Raffaele Palladino gets his first senior call-up.

Here are the highlights:

Erik Prince, CEO of Blackwater USA, testifies before the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform.
Blackwater provides training to military and law enforcement communities, and protective services in hostile areas.
The company's personnel are accountable under US statutes, treaties, and regulations, and cooperate with government investigations.
Blackwater welcomes the FBI review of the September 16 incident and will cooperate fully.

Benfica midfielder Augustin Binya banned for six matches for horror tackle on Celtic's Scott Brown.
Tackle was described as one of the worst ever seen by referee Martin Hansson.
Brown avoided injury but claimed Binya tried to break his leg.
Benfica can appeal, but Binya will miss remaining Group D matches and potentially more.

Here are the highlights:

Sen. Hillary Clinton remains the top Democratic presidential candidate, with 44% support.
She leads GOP front-runner Rudy Giuliani 51% to 45% in a head-to-head matchup.
Clinton's support has slipped since last month, but she still leads Obama and other rivals.
Giuliani's enthusiasm among Republicans is low, with only 27% saying they'd feel enthusiastic if he won the nomination.

Here are the highlights:

Russian President Vladimir Putin visits Iran, urging peaceful nuclear activities in the region.
Putin and Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad agree on peaceful nuclear objectives.
Russia is building Iran's first nuclear power plant, resisting US-led sanctions.
Putin meets with leaders of Caspian nations to discuss sea sharing and regulation.

Three French journalists charged in alleged child kidnapping plot arrive in Paris.
14 others remain in custody in Chad, facing serious charges.
French President Nicolas Sarkozy holds emergency talks in Chad.
Children's backgrounds difficult to determine, may never return to families.

Here are the highlights:

A sixth US service member died from injuries sustained in a Black Hawk helicopter crash in Italy.
The helicopter crashed Thursday afternoon, killing four and injuring seven, with two later dying.
The craft was an Army H-60 Black Hawk attached to the 1st Battalion, 214th Aviation Regiment.
The military is not releasing the names of those killed, pending notification of their families.

Three men arrested and charged with murder in shooting death of University of Memphis football player Taylor Bradford.
Police found Bradford fatally wounded near campus residence hall area after a car crash.
Investigation led to the arrest of DeeShawn Tate, Victor Trezevant, and Courtney Washington.
Prosecutors considering seeking death penalty in the case.

Here are the highlights:

Britney Spears ordered to give up custody of her children to ex-husband Kevin Federline.
Judge Scott Gordon awards Federline full custody until further order.
Spears must submit to random drug tests and work with a parenting coach.
Federline and Spears must attend joint co-parenting counseling and avoid derogatory remarks.

O.J. Simpson posts $250,000 bail, walks out of jail after judge doubles bail to ensure his appearance at trial.
Simpson violated terms of previous bail by attempting to contact a co-defendant.
Judge scolds Simpson, saying he wasn't taking the matter seriously, with "no 'get-out-of-jail-free card'".
Simpson faces trial on 12 criminal counts, including conspiracy, kidnapping, and robbery, on April 7.

Here are the highlights:

Air Force grounds F-15s after crash of older model in Missouri, now returning F-15E Strike Eagles to service in Iraq and Afghanistan.
F-15Es must pass inspection of critical parts on airframe before returning to flying missions.
Inspection includes checking hydraulic system lines, longerons, and environmental control system bay.
F-15Es are used for ground support in Iraq and Afghanistan, as well as homeland security mission over the US.

Former ICE detainees accuse agency of forcibly injecting them with psychotropic drugs during deportation.
Raymond Soeoth and Amadou Diouf claim they were injected against their will.
Dr. Paul Appelbaum says government's use of potent medications is "subject to a malpractice claim".
ICE chief Julie Myers says 1,073 detainees received medical escorts, 56 received psychotropic medications.

Here are the highlights:

A 7-year-old girl was sexually assaulted while in the care of a babysitter hired by her mother.
The mother was unaware of the abuse until a family friend recognized her daughter on a videotape.
The suspect, Chester Arthur Stiles, is a 37-year-old former animal trainer.
The FBI is seeking Stiles in a separate case involving sexual assault and lewdness with a minor.

Here are the highlights:

Sen. Barack Obama criticizes Sen. Hillary Clinton's vote on Iran, calling it a "blank check" for President Bush.
Obama says Clinton's judgment was "flawed" on the vote and the Iraq war authorization.
He accuses Clinton of not learning from past mistakes and repeating them.
Obama vows to clarify his differences with Clinton in the next phase of his campaign.

Charges against Bryant Purvis reduced to second-degree aggravated battery in "Jena 6" case.
Purvis enters not guilty plea and focuses on studies and basketball.
Charges reduced for at least five of the six students accused.
Mychal Bell, 17, remains in jail for probation violation.

Up to 1,000 human rights campaigners protested outside No. 10 Downing Street, demanding democracy in Pakistan.
Protesters called for the resignation of Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf and the release of political prisoners.
Jemima Khan, ex-wife of Imran Khan, delivered a petition to Downing Street, urging Britain to support democracy in Pakistan.
The petition demands the restoration of democracy, judiciary, and the release of all political prisoners.

T.I. arrested on gun charges in Atlanta, will remain in custody until bond hearing Friday.
Rapper's bodyguard-turned-informant delivered three machine guns and two silencers to T.I.
T.I. convicted felon, not allowed to own firearms, and has been arrested on gun charges before.
Harris won two awards at the BET Hip Hop Awards, which went on without him.

Three Chinese nationals arrested for importing thousands of counterfeit luxury handbags in the US.
Operation involved about 300,000 bags and wallets with brands like Burberry, Gucci, and Coach.
Customers paid $16 million for items worth over $100 million in legitimate retail sales.
Authorities seized 29 bank accounts and three New York properties.

Here are the highlights:

National Hurricane Center director Bill Proenza resigns after staff petition calls for his ouster.
Proenza's comments about hurricane satellite QuikSCAT sparked staff dissatisfaction.
Deputy Director Ed Rappaport takes over temporarily, Proenza on leave.
Proenza's leadership style and comments led to staff unhappiness and petition.

Here are the highlights:

Over 1,700 people have died in Bangladesh after a devastating tropical cyclone hit the western coast.
Floodwaters recede, revealing more bodies, with thousands injured and many still missing.
Aid workers face debris-blocked roads, no electricity, and limited communications in remote areas.
Cyclone Sidr has left 280,000 families homeless, with widespread damage to crops and livestock.

Here are the highlights:

A man has been indicted for allegedly displaying hangman's nooses from a pickup truck during a civil rights march.
Jeremiah Munsen, 18, repeatedly drove past marchers in Alexandria, Louisiana, with nooses hanging from his truck.
A juvenile passenger was apprehended, claiming to be a Ku Klux Klan member with a "KKK" tattoo.
Munsen is accused of a federal civil rights conspiracy violation and a federal hate crime.

R.E.M. debuts new song "Until the Day Is Done" on CNN's "Anderson Cooper 360°".
Song will also appear in four-hour documentary "Planet in Peril" on environmental crises.
Band's Michael Stipe praises documentary's powerful images and message.
Song fits perfectly with documentary's theme of eco-devastation.

Here are the highlights:

Eloisa Tamez refuses to give up her land for a US-Mexico border fence, citing family history and heritage.
The US government is building a 700-mile fence along the Mexican border, including 370 miles by year's end.
Border Patrol agents face increasing violence and the fence aims to curb illegal immigration and drug trafficking.
Landowners, like Tamez, are fighting the construction, citing property rights and the fence's effectiveness.

Here are the highlights:

Some Christian congregations are turning to Scientology for help, despite controversy and criticism.
Two pastors, Rev. Charles Kennedy and Rev. James McLaughlin, use Scientology's teachings in their sermons.
They borrow from Scientology's programs to address community issues, such as addiction and crime.
They believe Scientology's teachings complement their Christian values, not replace them.

Car bomb attack in Algeria kills 3, wounds 23 near judicial police office in Thenia.
Blast destroys about 20 houses, commission appointed to aid victims.
Islamic extremists have struck several times in recent years, including a deadly 2014 attack.
Al Qaeda affiliate claimed responsibility for previous attacks in Algeria.

Michael Vick must adhere to tightened restrictions after testing positive for marijuana use.
He will undergo random drug testing, substance abuse therapy, and electronic monitoring.
Vick must stay home between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m. and be electronically monitored.
He faces a possible 12- to 18-month prison term at sentencing on December 10.

Here are the highlights:

Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr appeared on CNN's "Larry King Live" to talk about the Beatles' impact.
They joked about their early days as a band and their rise to fame.
The pair praised the enduring popularity of their music, saying it's "uplifting and joyful".
They also discussed the re-mixing of their music for Cirque du Soleil's "Love" show.

Three Palestinians, including two sick children, have died while waiting for resettlement from Iraq.
A 3-year-old boy died of rickets and pneumonia, and a 14-year-old died of Hodgkin's disease.
UNHCR has appealed for the resettlement of "vulnerable and sick" children in Al Waleed refugee camp.
About 2,000 Palestinian refugees are stranded in camps along the Syrian border.

Japanese balloonist Michio Kanda missing off Alaska coast while flying from Japan to US west coast.
Last heard from via satellite phone Thursday at 9 a.m. Alaska time.
Coast Guard searches underway, using planes and cutters to locate Kanda.
Kanda holds world record for longest-duration balloon flight, 50 hours and 38 minutes.

Here are the highlights:

Senators Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama will debate for the first time without John Edwards on Thursday night.
The debate will be held at the Kodak Theatre in Los Angeles, California, and starts at 8 p.m. ET.
Obama's campaign raised $32 million in January from 170,000 new donors, allowing for expanded TV ad buys.
Clinton has the edge in superdelegates, but Obama leads in pledged delegates.

Here are the highlights:

A car bomb struck a US Embassy vehicle in Beirut, killing 3 Lebanese civilians and injuring 21 others.
The driver and passenger, both Lebanese nationals, suffered minor injuries.
The blast was caused by a 15-kilogram bomb placed in a car before the explosion.
US Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice condemned the terrorist attack.

Here are the highlights:

Bobby Murcer promised to hit a home run for a terminally ill fan, Scott Crull, and kept his promise.
The Cubs' Bobby Murcer hit two home runs for Crull, but Crull was not told he was dying.
The Red Wings' tradition of throwing an octopus on the ice for good luck started in 1952.
PETA has objected to this practice, which continues to this day.

Here are the highlights:

A mother seeks to have her 15-year-old daughter's womb removed to prevent menstrual pain.
Doctors are considering the hysterectomy for Katie Thorpe, who has cerebral palsy.
The move is opposed by a disability charity, citing human rights concerns.
The surgery could set a "disturbing precedent" for disabled girls across Britain.

The Chinese government expects a surge in weddings on August 8 due to cultural significance of the number "eight" for wealth and fortune.
The number "eight" sounds like the word for "wealth" and "fortune" in Chinese, making it auspicious.
Last year, nearly 3,400 couples got married on August 8, with some waiting all night outside the registration office.
The Beijing Municipal Civil Affairs Bureau is accepting online reservations for marriage registrations this year.

Turkey advances to Euro 2008 finals with 1-0 win over Bosnia-Herzegovina.
Nihat Kahveci scores lone goal in first half, securing Turkey's qualification.
Norway's 4-1 win over Malta is not enough to qualify, ending their hopes.
Turkey's victory ends in a tense finish, with team holding on for the win.

Here are the highlights:

Coalition troops killed Haitham Sabah al-Badri, al Qaeda emir of greater Samarra, in an airstrike.
Al-Badri was responsible for the 2006 attack on Samarra's al-Askariya mosque.
Four armed men were killed, including one foreigner, in the raid outside Samarra.
Mortar attacks in Baghdad killed 11 people and wounded 15 others.

Richard Roberts resigns as Oral Roberts University president amid allegations of misconduct and misuse of school funds.
Lawsuit claims Roberts and wife lavishly spent school money on personal expenses and gave access to a convicted sex offender.
Roberts and wife deny allegations, with Roberts saying he wants to see "God's best" for the university.
Board of Regents to meet to discuss search for new president.

Thousands attended the funeral of Lebanese MP Antoine Ghanem, killed in a bomb blast.
Ghanem's coffin was carried through Beirut's Christian district, accompanied by thousands of mourners.
The assassination is the latest in a series of attacks targeting anti-Syrian figures in Lebanon.
The incident threatens to cast the country into political uncertainty ahead of a presidential vote.

Here are the highlights:

Police arrest 20 suspects in Europe, including 11 in Italy, suspected of recruiting suicide bombers.
Arrests made in Italy, Britain, France, Portugal, and other European countries.
Police found al Qaeda manuals for explosives, detonation devices, and poisons during the arrests.
Suspects accused of forming Salafi Jihad terrorist cells and producing false documents.

Pet Fashion Week in New York features dogs in haute couture, strutting down the runway with human models.
Canines wear one-of-a-kind design creations, not boring raincoats, for owners who want to pamper their pets.
The show highlights couture clothing, jewelry, and accessories for well-dressed dogs in the $40 billion pet industry.
Pet owners willing to pay for their pup's stylist can find unique items at the annual event.

Mira Nair's "The Namesake" is an adaptation of Jhumpa Lahiri's novel about loss and family.
The film explores universal themes of movement, cultural identity, and intergenerational conflict.
Kal Penn plays Gogol, a 15-year-old Indian-American boy struggling to balance his identities.
The film was well-received by audiences in both India and the US, despite its cultural differences.

Here are the highlights:

A grand jury indicted four suspects on charges of first-degree murder and armed burglary in Sean Taylor's death.
Eric Rivera Jr. is identified as the shooter who fired the fatal shot.
The four suspects, including three adults and a 17-year-old, are being held without bail.
Taylor, 24, was shot during an apparent burglary at his home in Miami, Florida.

Here are the highlights:

Man serving life sentence for robbery confesses to fatally shooting deputy in Florida.
Deputy Paul Rein was transporting Michael Mazza to court when he was shot.
Mazza overpowered Rein, took his gun, and drove away before being arrested hours later.
He faces charges of first-degree murder and escape.

Human error likely caused ship crash and oil spill in San Francisco Bay, killing nearly 400 birds.
Captain and crew barred from leaving ship, which is docked for repairs in Oakland.
Coast Guard launches federal criminal probe to determine if captain and crew violated federal laws.
Oil spill sickened birds, formed globules on beaches, and oozed into San Francisco city waterfront.

Here are the highlights:

British hotel chain Travelodge offers free accommodation to couples named Mary and Joseph for a night.
Couples must be in a long-term relationship and provide proof of identity.
The offer is valid at any of the chain's 322 hotels in the UK from December 24 to January 5.
Free parking space for a donkey is also available if needed.

Here are the highlights:

Journalist Eric Weiner spent 10 years searching for the happiest places on earth.
He found happiness in Bhutan, Iceland, Thailand, India, and Switzerland.
Weiner discovered that money doesn't necessarily lead to happiness, and taxes are important.
He now describes himself as a "recovering grump" after his year-long quest.

Saudi lawyer Abdulrahman al-Lahim's license revoked for speaking about gang-rape case.
Woman sentenced to 200 lashes and six months in prison for speaking out.
Human rights groups demand Saudi King Abdullah drop charges against the rape victim.
Lawyer faces disciplinary hearing, possible suspension and disbarment for defending the victim.

Here are the highlights:

• Investigators seize computers and analyze online information to find clues in the Omaha mall shooting.
• The 19-year-old gunman, Robert Hawkins, sent a text to his ex-girlfriend and left a voice mail for his mother before the shooting.
• Hawkins chose his victims randomly and took his own life after killing eight people at a department store.
• The motive behind the shooting remains unclear, but Hawkins had a history of mental health issues and suicidal thoughts.

Angelina Jolie visits Iraq to focus attention on internally displaced people, calling efforts "lagging".
She criticizes lack of coherent plan to help 2 million "very vulnerable" internally displaced people.
Jolie wants to find ways to help UNHCR be more active in Iraq, focusing on security and resettlement.
She emphasizes the crisis' impact on regional stability and the need for a government plan.

Udinese lost 3-1 to Napoli, with Ezequiel Lavezzi scoring twice and setting up another goal.
Lavezzi's goals ended a two-and-a-half-month goal drought, moving Napoli to ninth in the table.
Udinese's Pepe was ejected for a second yellow card, leaving the team with 10 men.
Palermo won 1-0 over Livorno, with Fabrizio Miccoli scoring a shot from outside the area.

Here are the highlights:

A six-month trial at Heathrow airport uses RFID technology to track and monitor luggage.
The trial aims to reduce errors and improve accuracy, currently at 60%.
RFID tags offer over 99% accuracy, compared to 60% for barcode tags.
The technology could lead to faster check-in, secure collection, and added value services.

Here are the highlights:

King Hussein asked President Nixon to attack Syria in 1970 to counter Syrian invasion of Jordan.
Nixon Presidential Library released declassified documents revealing secret messages and diplomatic cables.
US officials sought to persuade Saudi Arabia to distance itself from Palestine Liberation Organization.
US government knew Israel had a nuclear weapon by 1969, but didn't encourage its acquisition.

Rev. James Orange, civil rights activist, dies at 65 in Atlanta.
He was jailed in 1965, sparking a fatal protest and the Selma-to-Montgomery march.
Jimmie Lee Jackson, 26, was shot and killed during the protest, leading to Bloody Sunday.
Orange's death led to the Voting Rights Act, signed into law in 1965.

Lebanese voters elect pro-government candidate Mohammed al-Amin Itani to replace Walid Eido.
Anti-government candidate Camille Khouri wins seat in Metn, defeating former President Amin Gemayel.
Khouri is a member of the anti-government Free Patriotic Movement.
Results closely watched ahead of presidential election, with Michel Aoun expected to run.

Here are the highlights:

CIA asked Justice Department to investigate former operative John Kiriakou for allegedly disclosing classified information.
Kiriakou spoke about waterboarding, saying it's torture and should be stopped, after CIA destroyed interrogation tapes.
Kiriakou underwent waterboarding during training, lasting 5 seconds before stopping, and says it's inhumane.
Investigation could take months to complete, with penalties ranging from loss of clearance to criminal prosecution.

Here are the highlights:

Felicia Sullivan's Valentine's Day was ruined when her boyfriend asked for time to think about their relationship.
She discovered he had contact with other women, leading her to break up with him.
Brian Wise's Valentine's Day went awry when he was accused of paying for sex with a woman who got food poisoning.
Judy McGuire advises lowering expectations and focusing on self-care on Valentine's Day.

Here are the highlights:

Attorneys for Majid Khan, a "high-value" detainee, request a judge to bar CIA from destroying evidence of alleged torture.
Khan claims he was subjected to aggressive CIA detention and interrogation program, causing severe physical and psychological trauma.
Khan's attorneys claim he was "forcibly disappeared" before being taken to Guantanamo, where he remains imprisoned without charge or trial.
The CIA denies allegations of torture, calling its interrogation program "lawful and highly productive".

Here are the highlights:

Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad asked to visit World Trade Center site, but NYC officials denied request.
Police Commissioner Raymond Kelly cited ongoing construction and security concerns as reasons for denial.
Iranian officials called the rejection "unfortunate", while US officials condemned the visit as unacceptable.
Several presidential candidates, including Hillary Clinton and Rudy Giuliani, also opposed the visit.

Here are the highlights:

A Florida judge ruled evidence against a former astronaut was inadmissible due to unlawful police tactics.
The evidence included statements made to police and items found in her car.
The judge said the police failed to obtain written consent to search her car.
The astronaut, Lisa Nowak, is accused of assaulting a romantic rival at an airport.

Here are the highlights:

Sharon Long, a forensic artist, helps identify murder victims by creating faces from human skulls.
She works with police to build a face from a skull, often using research and guesswork.
Long's work has solved historical mysteries and identified victims in cold cases.
Her latest case involves eight sets of human remains found in Florida woods.

German zookeepers are bottle-feeding a 4-week-old polar bear cub due to concerns its mother might eat it.
The cub is thriving in human care, but its mother is showing signs of distress.
The zoo took the cub away after noticing the mother's unusual behavior.
The zoo is considering introducing another adult bear to help the mother overcome her loss.

Here are the highlights:

Pastor Brady Boyd facilitated a meeting between the parents of the shooter and the families of the victims.
The meeting was emotional, with hugs and tears, and led to a sense of forgiveness and healing.
The Murrays, the parents of the shooter, visited the church and met with the families of the victims.
The visit was seen as a step towards healing and reconciliation for all involved.

Here are the highlights:

More than a dozen wildfires rage across Southern California, forcing thousands to flee their homes.
Over 265,000 people have been evacuated, with 4,900 firefighters battling the fast-moving blazes.
At least 50 homes and businesses have been destroyed or damaged, with 98,000 acres burned.
Strong winds are expected to continue through Tuesday, making the situation "very dangerous and unpredictable".

Celtic vs. Rangers match postponed as mark of respect after Motherwell captain Phil O'Donnell's death.
O'Donnell, 35, died after collapsing on the field, leaving the football community in shock.
Celtic captain Stephen McManus and Rangers manager Walter Smith agree postponement is necessary.
Motherwell's home game against Celtic next Sunday was already postponed as a tribute to O'Donnell.

Here are the highlights:

India's court system has a massive backlog of 300 million unresolved cases.
Mobile courts are being used to bring justice to rural areas.
Judge Sandeep Singh's mobile courtroom hears cases in a dusty schoolyard.
The mobile court has cleared 1,100 cases in six months, compared to 500 in traditional courts.

Here are the highlights:

Fran Townsend, President Bush's homeland security adviser, resigns after 4½ years.
She will seek new opportunities in the private sector, focusing on global risk management.
Townsend praised by Bush for her work in protecting the American people from terrorism.
She will stay on as part of the search committee to find her replacement.

Here are the highlights:

Chiquita Brands International faces $7.86 billion lawsuit over alleged ties to Colombian paramilitary group AUC.
Families of 393 victims seek $10 million in compensatory and punitive damages each.
Company admits to making "protection payments" to AUC, but denies allegations of facilitating arms shipments.
Chiquita will fight the allegations, calling the payments necessary to protect its employees and their families.

Here are the highlights:

2-year-old Riley Ann Sawyers was beaten, held under water, and thrown across the room before her death.
Her mother, Kimberly Trenor, described the abuse and disposal of her daughter's body to police.
Trenor and her husband, Royce Zeigler, were arrested on charges of injuring a child and tampering with evidence.
The toddler's body was found in a plastic storage container in a Galveston waterway on October 29.

Here are the highlights:

June 29, 2007: Police defuse bomb in London's Haymarket, central London, with 200 liters of fuel and gas cylinders.
July 21, 2005: Four men attempt to carry out attacks on London's transport network, but bombs fail to explode.
July 7, 2005: Four suicide bombers detonate themselves on three underground trains and a bus, killing 52.
August 2004: Anti-terrorist police disrupt plot to blow up targets in southeast England using explosives-packed limousines and vehicles.

Topps Meat Co. recalls 21.7 million pounds of ground beef due to E. coli contamination risk.
Recalled products may cause severe diarrhea, cramps, and other complications.
25 illnesses are under investigation in 8 states, with 300,000 pounds recalled initially.
Consumers should check "sell by" dates and return products for a full refund.

A boy playing with matches started a Southern California wildfire, burning 38,000 acres and destroying 21 homes.
The 38,526-acre Buckweed Fire was sparked on October 21 in the Agua Dulce community.
The 14-year-old suspect admitted to starting the fire and is being held at home with his parents.
The fire forced the evacuation of 15,000 people and injured three civilians and two firefighters.

Here are the highlights:

The Democratic presidential nomination race in Texas is a statistical dead heat between Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama.
The CNN/Opinion Research Corp. poll shows Clinton with 50% support and Obama with 48%.
The race is a virtual tie, with a sampling error of plus or minus 4.5 percentage points.
John McCain is the clear favorite for the Republican nomination, with 55% support among likely Texas GOP primary voters.

Here are the highlights:

At least 200 people evacuated after tanker truck carrying 9,000 gallons of gasoline erupts in northern Boston suburb.
No serious injuries reported, but witnesses recount close calls with explosions and fires.
Flames engulf at least 40 cars and three buildings, including two houses, fire officials say.
Firefighters still battling blaze in one home seven hours after the incident.

Here are the highlights:

Kaka wins 2007 World Footballer of the Year award, beating Ronaldo and Messi.
He led AC Milan to Champions League victory over Liverpool with a sublime 90-minute performance.
Kaka's skills were honed at Sao Paulo and Brazil, earning him a winners' medal in the 2002 World Cup.
He averages a goal every three games for club and country, showcasing his versatility.

Interpol makes global appeal to identify man in digitally reconstructed photos of child sexual abuse.
Man's face was disguised, but images can be restored to help identify him.
Photos show him sexually abusing boys aged 6 to early teens in Vietnam and Cambodia.
Interpol seeks public help to bring him to justice and protect vulnerable children.

Here are the highlights:

Up to 80,000 items at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library are unaccounted for due to poor record-keeping.
Audit finds "significant breakdown in internal controls" at the library.
Library officials acknowledge problems with inventory control, citing 100,000 items with only 20,000 accounted for.
Library is implementing audit recommendations, upgrading software and hiring additional staff.

Here are the highlights:

Dozens of Defense Department personnel fight wildfires in Southern California, with thousands more on standby.
12 Defense Department firefighting teams, with 12 engines, are already working the blazes.
550 Marines from Camp Pendleton prepare to deploy to the fire area.
1,500 National Guard troops, including 200 from border duty, have been called up to help with supplies and security.

Here are the highlights:

Tom Cruise talks about his beliefs in Scientology in a 2004 video.
He says it's a privilege to be a Scientologist and is dedicated to helping others.
Cruise emphasizes the humanitarian work of the Church of Scientology and its founder L. Ron Hubbard.
He finds peace and says Scientologists can create new realities and improve conditions.

Here are the highlights:

Australian Prime Minister Kevin Rudd assures Afghan President Hamid Karzai of a long-term commitment to Afghanistan.
Rudd and French President Nicolas Sarkozy visit Afghanistan to meet with Karzai and troops.
Australia is the largest non-NATO contributor to the war in Afghanistan with nearly 1,000 troops stationed in Oruzgan.
Rudd promises continued aid to Afghanistan, despite plans to withdraw troops from Iraq by mid-2008.

Here are the highlights:

Michael Vick turned himself in to authorities to serve his sentence for dogfighting.
He faces 12 to 18 months in prison for a federal conspiracy charge.
Vick pleaded guilty in August and apologized for his actions.
He is being held at Northern Neck Regional Jail until his sentencing hearing.

Pope Benedict XVI says football can teach young people moral lessons, including honesty, solidarity, and fraternity.
He believes the sport can be a vehicle for education and promoting positive values.
Ancona football club was endorsed by the Vatican for its commitment to fair play and family atmosphere.
Pope Benedict XVI is a Bayern Munich supporter and has spoken about football's potential for moral teaching.

Here are the highlights:

Two tractor-trailers crashed and burst into flames on a US-Mexico border bridge, killing four people.
The accident triggered a chain-reaction crash with three other vehicles, including a pickup truck and minivan.
Six people were injured, with three killed in the pickup truck and one in a vehicle that struck one of the tractor-trailers.
The bridge was closed for the evening and reopened after inspection by Texas Department of Transportation engineers.

Pojamarn Shinawatra, wife of ousted PM Thaksin, arrives in Thailand to face corruption charges.
She was greeted by 50 well-wishers and escorted to the Supreme Court.
Charges stem from a Bangkok land deal and stock concealment plan, carrying up to 8-year sentence.
Released on 5 million baht bail and ordered not to leave the country.

Riots erupt in Paris suburbs after two teens die in motorcycle crash with police car.
Violence spreads to nearby towns, with 60 police officers injured and many buildings set on fire.
Residents accuse police of fleeing the crash scene, while police say they tried to revive the teens.
Investigation launched into the deaths, with police citing speed and lack of helmets as contributing factors.

Rinko Kikuchi stunned global cinema audiences with her Oscar-nominated performance in "Babel".
She's one of Japan's hottest young actresses and models, working with Karl Lagerfeld.
Despite success, she remains unconventional, defying traditional Japanese beauty standards.
Talk Asia follows her on a modelling assignment and discusses her life after "Babel".

Here are the highlights:

Kenya's disputed election has led to hundreds of deaths and tens of thousands fleeing their homes.
Businesses have been destroyed and supply routes disrupted, affecting the country's economy.
The Nairobi Stock Exchange lost 40 billion Kenyan Shillings in value on its first day of trading.
Kenya's tourist industry is expected to take a heavy hit due to the unrest.

Here are the highlights:

• Ducati's motorbikes are the ultimate name in luxury, competing fiercely to defend its title against Japanese rivals.
• Monita Rajpal visits the Bologna factory floor and meets Moto GP champion Casey Stoner.
• Bruce Dickinson, lead singer of Iron Maiden, trades his leather and long hair for a commercial airline pilot's uniform.
• Paul Van Dyk takes Art of Life on a tour of his hometown, former East Berlin, and shares his musical inspirations.

Here are the highlights:

Michigan's Republican primary will be the main event on Tuesday, with John McCain seeking independent support.
McCain won New Hampshire with independent voters and is campaigning hard to repeat the success in Michigan.
Michigan is a swing state, but voting trends favor the Democrats, who have carried the state in the last four elections.
The state's economy is struggling, with a 7.4% unemployment rate, higher than the national average.

Here are the highlights:

Lance Cpl. Maria Lauterbach, 20, missing from Camp Lejeune, North Carolina, since December 14.
She was 8 months pregnant and her car was found at Jacksonville's bus station.
Her cell phone was last used on December 14 and a withdrawal was made from her bank account.
Investigations are ongoing and a Facebook page has been set up to help find her.

Here are the highlights:

• An 18-year-old mother offered herself for sex in exchange for treatment for her leukemia-stricken baby in Iraq.
• The head of the Iraqi Red Crescent says the plight of Iraq's children is nearing epidemic proportions.
• Over 1.6 million children under 12 are homeless in Iraq, with 95,000 volunteers and 5,000 employees trying to help.
• The organization faces a monumental task of treating and feeding the children, with funds low and a desperate situation.

Here are the highlights:

Coalition forces found 26 bodies in mass graves and a "torture complex" with chains and electrical systems.
The complex was discovered in an area thought to be an al Qaeda in Iraq haven and operating base.
The bodies were found in mass graves next to execution sites and were believed to be dead for 6-8 months.
The complex also contained weapons caches, including anti-aircraft weapons, machine guns, and homemade explosives.

Pakistan rejects UN nuclear watchdog chief's concerns about nuclear weapons falling into extremist hands.
ElBaradei's comments are "irresponsible" and "unwarranted", says Pakistan's foreign ministry.
Pakistan's nuclear weapons are secure under multilayered safeguards and controls, the ministry claims.
Pakistan is a responsible nuclear state and has fully complied with IAEA obligations.

Here are the highlights:

Presidential candidates discuss foreign policy credentials after Benazir Bhutto's assassination in Pakistan.
Hillary Clinton stresses her experience and knowledge in dealing with crises.
John McCain and Barack Obama criticize Clinton's Iraq War vote and judgment.
Candidates shift focus to Pakistan's stability and potential impact on global security.

Here are the highlights:

Lebanon's civil war raged on when I was 14, with shells raining down on our neighborhood in Beirut.
I watched the last throes of the war firsthand, feeling sad, frustrated, and fearful.
The war's return brings back memories of frightened children, darkness, and chaos.
Lebanon's presidential election is the setting for a struggle between religion and clan, threatening to set the country back 20 years.

Seven Manchester United fans taken to hospital after violence breaks out before Champions League match in Rome.
Five fans receive stab wounds, two others treated for intoxication, none with serious injuries.
Violence occurred on Pont Duca d'Aosta bridge, a known hotspot for Roma's Ultras.
Roma coach Luciano Spalletti condemns the violence, calling those involved "sick".

Here are the highlights:

Chester Stiles, 37, sought in connection with videotaped rape of 3-year-old girl four years ago.
Former girlfriend Tina Allen believes she introduced Stiles to the victim.
Stiles' former girlfriend is "disgusted" and "mortified" at her role in bringing them together.
Authorities urge Stiles to turn himself in, warning he will not be forgotten.

American al Qaeda member Adam Gadahn renounces US citizenship in a 50-minute video.
Gadahn protests imprisonment of Sheikh Omar Abdul Rahman and John Walker Lindh.
He urges al Qaeda members to attack US President Bush during his Middle East trip.
Gadahn is on the FBI's Most Wanted List with a $1 million reward.

Here are the highlights:

Theodore Sorensen helped John F. Kennedy draft a 1960 speech addressing his Catholicism and church-state separation.
Kennedy's speech reassured Americans about his faith, but didn't eliminate anti-Catholic sentiment entirely.
Sorensen says Romney's 2012 speech on faith in politics differs from Kennedy's, emphasizing religion's role in public life.
Sorensen believes Romney's speech was well-written, but Kennedy's was more effective in addressing the anti-Catholic issue.

The Boeing 777 is a long-haul aircraft with a safe service history, never involved in a fatal accident.
It was first introduced in 1995 and has since made over 2 million flights.
The 777-200LR set a world record for distance traveled non-stop, flying 21,601 km from Hong Kong to London.
The aircraft has won numerous awards and set multiple records for speed and distance.

Here are the highlights:

Donors pledge $7.4 billion to help build a Palestinian state at a conference in Paris.
The funds will support short-term priorities, including economic development and government reform.
Palestinian Prime Minister Salam Fayyad calls the pledge a "vote of confidence" in the Palestinians.
Former British Prime Minister Tony Blair urges the Palestinians to show progress in the coming months.

Here are the highlights:

Rep. Tom Lantos, House Committee on Foreign Affairs chairman, dies at 80 due to cancer complications.
He represented California's Northern District for 14 terms, serving since 1981.
Lantos was a Holocaust survivor and outspoken human rights advocate, serving as a true American hero.
He will be remembered for his integrity, moral conviction, and dedication to a better world.

Here are the highlights:

Car bombs in Amara, Iraq, kill at least 27 people and wound 151 in a market district.
Three bombs detonated in close succession in the city's central commercial area.
The blasts occurred in a city that has seen fighting between rival Shiite factions.
Iraq's Interior Ministry fired the city's police chief in the aftermath of the attack.

Kenya's reputation as a stable nation hides widespread poverty, violent crime, and corruption.
Tribal bonds are stronger than national identity, with 40 tribes and 36 million people.
Incumbent President Mwai Kibaki won the election with 51.3% of the vote, but results disputed.
International election observers question the legitimacy of the election, throwing Kenya's future into doubt.

Benazir Bhutto's assassination does not mean Pakistan is inherently hopeless.
Bhutto's adherence to feudal politics and conformity disappointed moderate Pakistanis.
Pakistan's women mourn her loss, but also criticize her failure to challenge backward mindset.
Pakistan can still have hope by transcending trauma and tribalism.

Here are the highlights:

Saudi King Abdullah pardons 19-year-old rape victim sentenced to 200 lashes and six months in prison.
The pardon was announced on the same day as the start of the Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia.
The victim's husband thanked the king for the pardon, saying it would ease their emotional and psychological stress.
The king's decision was welcomed by the White House, but not seen as a change in Saudi Arabia's strict Islamic law.

Diana's former butler, Paul Burrell, gave conflicting testimony about a "secret" in a letter from the princess.
The coroner dismissed the claim, saying the information was already public and in Burrell's own book.
Burrell's testimony was delayed after he couldn't find the letter, which he claimed contained the secret.
The inquest heard that Diana was planning to buy a home in the US or South Africa.

Here are the highlights:

Princess Diana's mother called her "a whore" over her relationships with Muslim men.
Diana was still "holding a candle" for former boyfriend Hasnat Khan when she met Dodi Fayed.
Burrell cast doubt on whether Diana was ready to marry Fayed, citing her lingering feelings for Khan.
Diana's butler, Paul Burrell, testified that she feared for her life in a letter to him.

Here are the highlights:

U.S., Turkey, and Iraq hold talks on Kurdish rebels using northern Iraq as a launchpad for attacks.
Turkish warplanes pounded Kurdish separatist targets in northern Iraq over the weekend.
Iraqi President Jalal Talabani and Vice President Tariq al-Hashimi met with Kurdish Regional Government President Massoud Barzani.
The three Iraqi officials condemned the Turkish bombing campaign and vowed to work towards national unity.

Andy Roddick defeated Kei Nishikori 6-2 6-4 in the ATP tournament in San Jose.
Roddick dominated the match, taking a 3-0 lead and breaking Nishikori's serve.
Nishikori held his cool despite Roddick's verbal warning, but made crucial errors in the second set.
Roddick won in 63 minutes, his second title in San Jose.

Marines involved in 2004 Falluja offensive investigated for allegedly killing civilians.
Allegations based on "credible information" from a former Marine during a polygraph test.
Investigation by Naval Criminal Investigative Service, no one charged yet.
Probe sparked by claims of eight captured Iraqis gunned down in 2004.

At least 10 people have died and thousands are homeless due to torrential rains in Ecuador.
Heavy rainfall, worst in 25 years, has affected over 10,000 families across nine provinces.
Five people died when an ambulance fell into a hole in a flooded street in Los Ríos province.
President Rafael Correa has declared a state of emergency and deployed 2,000 military and police personnel.

Italian tennis players Potito Starace and Daniele Bracciali banned by ATP for betting on matches.
Starace suspended for six weeks, fined $30,000 for making five bets totaling 90 euros.
Bracciali banned for three months, fined $20,000 for making 50 five-euro bets.
Players claim they were scapegoats for larger match-fixing scandal, not aware of ATP rules.

Here are the highlights:

Trevor Rees, Princess Diana's bodyguard, testifies in court, denying conspiracy theories surrounding her death.
He claims to have no memory of the crash, but doesn't support conspiracy claims.
Rees suffered serious injuries and received threatening phone calls and letters after the accident.
He testifies that he didn't take the calls or letters seriously and didn't support Dodi Fayed's father's claims.

Here are the highlights:

A father and his three children were stranded in snowy California woods for three days.
They fashioned a "Help" sign out of twigs on a nearby unpaved road.
The family slept in a culvert, removed their socks to stay warm, and ripped apart shirts for warmth.
They were rescued by a helicopter and reported to be in good condition.

Here are the highlights:

"No Country for Old Men" wins Best Picture at the 80th Academy Awards.
Daniel Day-Lewis, Tilda Swinton, Marion Cotillard, and Javier Bardem win acting awards.
The Coen brothers win Best Director and Best Adapted Screenplay for "No Country".
Marion Cotillard wins Best Actress for her role in "La Vie en Rose".

Here are the highlights:

An American Airlines passenger died on a flight after complaining of trouble breathing.
MedAire advises airlines on handling in-flight medical events, receiving 50-60 calls daily.
The top in-flight illnesses are fainting, gastrointestinal problems, and respiratory issues.
Passengers with medical conditions should pack critical medications in a carry-on bag.

President Bush signs energy bill to raise auto fuel economy standards to 35 miles per gallon by 2020.
Bill also boosts support for alternative fuel research and energy conservation efforts.
Current fuel-economy standards set in 1975 will be replaced with a single average standard for manufacturers.
Bill faces opposition from some Republicans who call it a "no-energy" bill and a recipe for recession.

Here are the highlights:

President Bush stresses faith-based groups' role in fighting AIDS, calling it a struggle of conscience and morals.
He asks Congress for $15 billion to expand the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief.
The program has treated over 1.3 million people with AIDS, with increased funding aiming for 2.5 million.
Bush plans to visit sub-Saharan Africa next year to see the program in action.

Here are the highlights:

Oregon Supreme Court rules 12-year-old boy should have a say in whether he gets circumcised.
Father wants to circumcise son as part of Jewish conversion, but mother objects.
Court sends case back to trial court to resolve whether boy agrees to circumcision.
Boy's opinion on procedure is crucial to determining custody dispute.

Man rescues co-worker from crocodile's jaws in Australia, but accidentally shoots him in the process.
Crocodile grabbed Jason Grant by the arm while they collected eggs in the Adelaide River.
Zac Fitzgerald shot the crocodile, but a second shot struck Grant in the upper right arm.
Grant's injuries are not life-threatening and he was flown to a hospital for treatment.

Here are the highlights:

Four US soldiers, including three Army Rangers, arrested for planning to rob drug traffickers.
Charged with conspiracy to possess and distribute cocaine and carrying firearms.
Arrests made in Georgia after a sting operation and search of a storage facility and Army camp.
Soldiers face minimum 10-year prison sentences for drug conspiracy and weapons charges.

Armenian President Robert Kocharian declares state of emergency after clashes between police and protesters.
Protesters claim last month's presidential election was rigged, demanding the results be voided.
Police used force to clear Freedom Square of thousands of demonstrators, with some injured and cars burned.
Government hopes state of emergency will bring order to Yerevan, with opposition vowing to pursue claims through legal means.

Here are the highlights:

Nearly 3 million gallons of sewage spilled into San Francisco Bay due to pump failure.
Spill occurred at South Marin Sanitation District's waste treatment facility in Mill Valley.
Waste was released into Richardson Bay, and boaters warned to avoid the area.
Tests underway to determine extent of contamination and impact on wildlife.

Here are the highlights:

62 members of the Gambino, Genovese, and Bonanno families face 80 charges, including money laundering and murder.
The Gambino family profited from extortion in the New York construction industry and labor unions.
Four members of the Gambino family are charged with eight crimes, including murder, including a 1990 armored truck robbery.
A member of the Attorney General's Organized Crime Task Force infiltrated the Gambino family and recorded hundreds of hours of conversations.

Saddam Hussein claimed he faked having WMD to intimidate Iran and prevent invasion.
He thought the US would retaliate with a limited aerial attack, not invasion.
Hussein asked his generals to hold off allied forces for two weeks before insurgency.
He professed to wanting to restart WMD program and take credit for insurgency.

The twins receive a check-up on February 26, 2008.
Nancy Grace introduces the twins on set on February 14, 2008.
The twins go for a stroll on February 11, 2008.
First video of Nancy Grace's twins released in January 2008.

Here are the highlights:

Hispanics are the largest minority group in the US, but the term is limiting and doesn't capture their complexity.
Many Latinos don't identify with the terms "Hispanic" or "Latino", preferring to identify by country of origin.
The US government uses "Hispanic" to refer to Spanish-speaking countries, while "Latino" refers to Latin America.
Latinos are a diverse group with different languages, cultures, and experiences, making it difficult to speak of them as one thing.

Here are the highlights:

The US Navy has moved the USS Cole and other ships to the eastern Mediterranean Sea off Lebanon.
The deployment is not linked to the Lebanese presidential standoff, according to the Pentagon.
The ships will operate in the vicinity for a while, signaling US engagement in the region.
The move is seen as a message to Syria to resolve the situation in Lebanon.

Here are the highlights:

Sen. Hillary Clinton wins Texas, Ohio, and Rhode Island primaries, boosting her campaign.
Sen. Barack Obama wins Vermont, but loses three key contests, including Texas and Ohio.
Sen. John McCain wins all four Republican contests, securing the GOP nomination.
McCain claims victory, saying he will be the Republican nominee for president.

Here are the highlights:

Top Democratic presidential candidates debate in South Carolina on Martin Luther King Jr. Day.
Sen. Barack Obama addresses Ebenezer Baptist Church, where King once preached.
Obama leads among African-American voters, with 60% support in a CNN poll.
Clinton holds a special relationship with many in the black community, thanks to her husband's popularity.

Here are the highlights:

Pakistan's President Pervez Musharraf says Benazir Bhutto's assassination was her own fault.
Musharraf claims Bhutto was responsible for her own death, citing her decision to stand outside her car.
Bhutto was killed in Rawalpindi on December 27 while campaigning for parliamentary elections.
The cause of her death remains unclear, with some suggesting she may have been shot before the bomb blast.

Texas couple charged with capital murder in death of "Baby Grace" Riley Ann Sawyers.
Riley was beaten to death, body found wrapped in plastic bags in Galveston Bay.
Grand jury upgraded charges after gathering additional evidence, including DNA confirmation.
Death penalty decision will be made after investigation concludes.

Saudi lawyer Abdul Rahman al-Lahem's license reinstated after representing kidnapped and raped teenager.
He was suspended for speaking to media about the case, which drew international attention.
Seven men were sentenced to prison for the rape, while the victim received 200 lashes and six months in prison.
Minister of Justice Abdallah bin Mohammed al-Sheikh denies license revocation, citing a "carefully examined procedure".

Here are the highlights:

Russia is like a mountain river: fast, dangerous and beautiful, says business analyst Anna Glubokina.
Many tourists visit Russia for its churches, palaces, Kremlin, Red Square, and great scenery.
Justin Goney, originally from Ohio, taught English in Moscow and thinks there are more tourists now.
Volker Kleensang visits Kaliningrad, a former German territory, and notes its unique European-oriented culture.

Here are the highlights:

Al Qaeda claims responsibility for assassination of Pakistani Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto.
Al-Zawahiri allegedly began planning the killing in October, according to an Italian news agency.
The claim has not been verified on radical Islamist Web sites.
US intelligence community monitoring the situation, but no conclusion on responsibility yet.

Here are the highlights:

The US Senate was briefly convened for 11 seconds to block recess appointments.
Democrats will hold "pro forma" sessions to prevent President Bush from making appointments.
Sen. Jim Webb opened and closed the session, spending 57 seconds in the chamber.
Senators will share the duty of presiding over the shortened sessions.

Here are the highlights:

President Bush proposes temporary, broad-based tax relief package to stimulate the economy.
Package would be worth around $140 billion, or 1% of GDP, and provide "shot in the arm" to economy.
Bush wants tax incentives for businesses and rapid income tax relief for consumers.
Democrats express support, but want package to include relief for low- and middle-income earners.

Here are the highlights:

Over 150 people abandoned a sinking cruise liner after it collided with an iceberg in Antarctic waters.
The ship, Explorer, sent out a distress call after hitting the iceberg around 10 p.m. ET Thursday.
Passengers and crew were evacuated onto lifeboats, with no reported injuries.
Five ships are en route to assist the sinking vessel in the minus 5C temperature.

Here are the highlights:

Todd Barber gave up a six-figure salary to restore ocean reef ecosystems after witnessing coral reef devastation.
He developed the "Reef Ball" to mimic nature and provide a habitat for natural reefs to grow.
Reef Balls are made of concrete, portable, and environmentally friendly, and can be used worldwide.
The Reef Ball Foundation has placed Reef Balls in over 59 countries, rehabilitating marine ecosystems.

Valerie Gooding, CEO of BUPA, ranked as one of Europe's most powerful businesswomen.
She attributes lack of women in top roles to lack of confidence and role models.
Good leaders deliver results and exceed expectations, says Gooding, citing a Chinese saying.
Business is a constant challenge, with new opportunities and pressures to keep leaders engaged.

Here are the highlights:

A fire charred the top of two wings of the Monte Carlo Resort and Casino in Las Vegas.
The fire was fully contained within an hour, with no major injuries reported.
The cause of the fire is unknown, but welders were working on the roof at the time.
Most damage was to the top floor, with some debris igniting four floors below.

Here are the highlights:

Huckabee admits he has no foreign policy credentials after comments on Bhutto's assassination spark questions.
He suggests cracking down on illegal Pakistani immigrants to address terrorism concerns.
Huckabee's comments spark criticism for being uninformed and populist.
His campaign says he was trying to shift focus away from foreign policy scrutiny.

President Bush draws parallels between Vietnam War and potential costs of pulling out of Iraq.
He warns of the "price of America's withdrawal" being paid by innocent citizens.
Bush seeks to shore up support for Iraqi Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki and his government.
He emphasizes the importance of staying the course in Iraq to prevent a repeat of Vietnam.

Here are the highlights:

US Marshals' task force in Atlanta captures over 3,000 suspects annually, with only one exchange of gunfire.
They use computer-simulated attacks to train, with scenarios changing every few minutes.
The task force tracks 10-15 suspected killers, with a focus on violent offenders.
Their motto: "We'll pull all our collective knowledge and resources to hunt them down and take them into custody."

Here are the highlights:

The Farm at Cape Kidnappers in New Zealand offers an adrenaline rush with surfing and hiking.
Ojai Valley Inn & Spa in California is a Spanish Colonial hideaway with mountain views and activities.
Haymarket Hotel in London, UK, captures the city's cool vibe with bold colors and trendy shops.
Villa Mangiacane in Tuscany, Italy, feels like a Bernardo Bertolucci set with its sculpture garden and olive grove.

A Vietnamese woman was sentenced to 2.5 years in jail for cooking tiger carcasses.
She sold bone marrow to traditional medicine men for $400 per gram.
Tigers are critically endangered, with only about 100 remaining in Vietnam.
Three accomplices received suspended sentences ranging from 24 to 30 months.

Here are the highlights:

Heath Ledger was remembered by fans for his kindness, humility, and talent.
He helped a driver change a flat tire in Brooklyn, showing his good nature.
He was described as a "sweet person" and "unbelievably talented actor" by Donal Logue.
He was seen teaching his daughter Matilda right from left in Brooklyn, showing his devotion.

Here are the highlights:

Blackwater CEO Erik Prince denies guards opened fire on Iraqi civilians, saying they faced insurgent fire.
Prince claims guards were under attack and only fired in self-defense.
Iraqi government demands Blackwater be expelled from Iraq within six months.
US officials are discussing ways to fill the security gap if Blackwater leaves.

Here are the highlights:

Four people, including three MSF workers and a journalist, killed in a mine explosion in southern Somalia.
The victims included a Kenyan doctor, a French logistician, and a Somali driver.
Journalist Hassan Kafi Hared, 36, was killed while walking to a news conference in Kismayo.
The medical humanitarian organization is evacuating remaining international staff from the area.

Celebrities' lenient treatment for drug use undermines faith in criminal justice system and encourages youth to use drugs.
Model Kate Moss and singer Amy Winehouse have faced allegations of drug use with no serious consequences.
Professor Hamid Ghodse says treating celebrities differently than non-celebrities sends wrong message to young people.
Britain, Spain, and Italy have high rates of cocaine abuse, according to the International Narcotics Control Board.

Here are the highlights:

• Colorado prosecutor asks judge to dismiss first-degree murder charge against Tim Masters.
• New DNA evidence suggests someone else might have committed the crime.
• Judge throws out Masters' 1999 murder conviction and frees him "in the interest of justice".
• Prosecutor asks for special prosecutor to continue investigating Hettrick's murder.

Here are the highlights:

Jamie Lynn Spears, 16, announces pregnancy to her 18-year-old boyfriend Casey Aldridge.
Consensual sex between the two may be legal, depending on the state and circumstances.
Critics argue that laws are too strict and unfairly prosecute teens in consensual relationships.
Spears plans to raise her child in Louisiana, despite potential legal implications.

Here are the highlights:

British teenager Scarlett Keeling's murder in Goa was allegedly covered up by police to protect the tourist industry.
Police initially said she drowned, but a second autopsy revealed rape and murder.
A suspect was arrested, but Keeling's mother doesn't believe he's the killer.
Police are investigating allegations of a cover-up and officer misconduct.

Here are the highlights:

Four people, including three MSF workers and a journalist, killed in a mine explosion in southern Somalia.
Three MSF workers, including a Kenyan doctor, were killed along with a Somali journalist, Hassan Kafi Hared.
The incident occurred in Kismayo, a city in southern Somalia, where ongoing violence has devastated the capital Mogadishu.
The medical humanitarian organization is evacuating remaining international staff from Kismayo.

Here are the highlights:

23 Marines injured, 4 critically, after bus overturns at Alabama military base.
Bus was carrying members of Marine Corps Reserve unit during training exercise.
Injuries reported among members of First and Headquarters Platoons from Bessemer, Alabama.
11 injured released from hospital by mid-afternoon.

Here are the highlights:

Kaka wins 2007 World Footballer of the Year award, beating rivals Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi.
He fulfills his dream of winning the Champions League with AC Milan in Athens.
Kaka's skills were honed at Sao Paulo and AC Milan, where he averages a goal every three games.
He's a midfielder with goalscoring ability, elegance, and skill, playing for both Milan and Brazil.

Here are the highlights:

Christina Laurean claims she was at a Christmas party on the night her husband allegedly killed Maria Lauterbach.
Cesar Laurean, a Marine, is wanted for first-degree murder and may have fled to Mexico.
Christina Laurean knew about the death a day before reporting it to authorities.
Lauterbach, 20, was eight months pregnant and had accused Cesar Laurean of rape.

Here are the highlights:

Sen. Hillary Clinton accuses Sen. Barack Obama of borrowing campaign speeches.
Obama responds, saying his words have been used by Clinton and Deval Patrick.
Clinton says Obama's speeches are empty rhetoric, while Obama says words matter.
Obama campaign cites instances where Clinton has used his signature phrases.

Here are the highlights:

Six people, including two children, found dead in a Memphis home, police say.
No signs of forced entry or forced struggle, investigation ongoing.
Police ask community for help in solving the slayings, no suspect identified.
At least one neighbor heard gunshots, but did not report it to authorities.

Four men arrested in connection with the shooting death of NFL player Sean Taylor.
Suspects confessed and will be charged with murder, authorities announced.
Taylor, 24, was shot during an apparent burglary at his Miami home on Tuesday.
Additional arrests are possible, according to police.

Here are the highlights:

Rizana Nafeek, a 17-year-old Sri Lankan housemaid, is on death row in Saudi Arabia for accidentally killing a baby.
She was convicted of murdering the 4-month-old boy in her care, but her father says it was an accident.
The Sri Lankan government is investigating the agency that sent her to work abroad and seeking clemency.
Rights groups criticize Saudi Arabia's legal system and the treatment of foreign workers, including children.

Here are the highlights:

• Atlanta Falcons quarterback Michael Vick expected to plead guilty to dogfighting charges.
• Vick's plea deal may include prison time, but NFL has not decided on football sanctions.
• Many CNN.com readers think Vick should be banned from playing professional football again.
• Some readers believe Vick should be allowed to play again, but with conditions and community service.

Here are the highlights:

Richard Branson left school at 16 and founded a magazine, then entered the record business.
Virgin now has over 300 companies, from cola to trains to phones.
Branson's philosophy is to create businesses where others are not doing it well enough.
He prioritizes the Virgin brand's reputation and employee well-being.

From January 1, smoking will be banned in cafes, clubs, casinos, and hotels in France.
Smoking will also be prohibited in bars, discotheques, and restaurants.
Smokers will still be allowed to smoke on terraces, but face fines starting at €450.
Enforcement will begin after an amnesty over the New Year holiday.

Here are the highlights:

Toddler's body found on Texas island in October, later identified as 2-year-old Riley Ann Sawyers.
Mother, Kimberly Trenor, and boyfriend, Royce Zeigler, arrested on child injury and tampering charges.
DNA analysis still pending to confirm identification, but police believe she is "Baby Grace".
Couple's bonds set at $350,000 each, awaiting further investigation and court proceedings.

Here are the highlights:

Four suspects, including 17-year-old Eric Rivera Jr., indicted on murder and burglary charges in Sean Taylor's death.
Rivera allegedly fired the fatal shot during a burglary at Taylor's home.
Three other suspects, aged 18-20, appeared in court, held without bail, and under suicide watch.
Taylor, 24, died a day after being shot during an apparent burglary at his home.

Manchester United will honor the 50th anniversary of the Munich air disaster on February 6.
Eight players died in the crash, including Geoff Bent, Roger Byrne, and Duncan Edwards.
A memorial service will be held at Old Trafford, and a minute's silence will precede England's match against Switzerland.
Survivor Harry Gregg prefers to remember the happy times with the "Busby Babes" rather than the tragedy.

Sudan and Chad sign non-aggression pact to halt cross-border hostilities and normalize relations.
Talks between presidents Idriss Deby and Omar al-Beshir facilitated by Senegalese President Abdoulaye Wade.
United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-moon witnesses signing of agreement.
Pact aims to halt rebel group movements and normalize relations between the two countries.

Sen. Larry Craig files appeal to overturn guilty plea in bathroom sex sting case.
He claims innocence and wants to clear his name.
The appeals process could take months to complete.
Craig's decision not to resign creates a political headache for Senate leadership.

Here are the highlights:

Queen Elizabeth II officially opened Heathrow's $8.6 billion Terminal 5, part of a rejuvenation plan.
The new terminal is expected to handle 30 million passengers annually, with further expansion planned.
Environmental groups criticize the expansion, citing increased emissions and climate change.
Business groups welcome the expansion, citing its importance for Britain's economic competitiveness.

Here are the highlights:

A 18-year-old man, Khiel Coppin, was shot and killed by New York police in a hail of bullets.
Coppin's mother called 911 reporting a family dispute with a gun, but no gun was found on him.
He was shot 8 times after ignoring police commands to stop and get on the ground.
Police believed they were about to receive fire, but no gun was recovered at the scene.

Here are the highlights:

The Amazon rainforest has lost 20% of its area in 40 years, with 17% degraded.
Deforestation is driven by logging, mining, agriculture, and cattle ranching, with 80% of logging illegal.
The Amazon plays a crucial role in regulating Earth's temperature and is home to millions of species.
Conservation efforts are underway, with Brazil's government taking steps to slow deforestation.

Here are the highlights:

The US imposed sanctions on two Iranian military groups and several banks accused of backing nuclear proliferation and terrorism.
The sanctions freeze assets and prohibit US citizens from engaging in financial transactions with the designated entities.
