The US accuses Iran of pursuing nuclear technologies, supporting militants, and denying the existence of a UN member.
Iran's banks are accused of funneling hundreds of millions to terrorists through deceptive financial practices.

Here are the highlights:

Sheikha Lubna Al Qasimi is the first female minister of economy in the Gulf and first to launch her own perfume line.
She founded Tejari, the first Middle Eastern business-to-business marketplace, in 2000.
She aims to increase foreign ownership in certain sectors, citing the country's 80% expatriate population.
Sheikha Lubna believes foreign direct investment promotes transparency, diligence, and economic growth.

Here are the highlights:

New York Gov. Eliot Spitzer used a high-priced call-girl ring at least eight times in recent months.
Spitzer resigned as governor, effective Monday, citing his "private failings" as the reason.
Federal agents had him under surveillance twice this year, including at the Mayflower Hotel in Washington.
Spitzer's resignation may not affect decisions about whether he will face prosecution.

Iraqi women face hardships and horrors, including torture and death, in the war-torn country.
Nahla's husband was killed in a bomb blast, leaving her with a life of pain and grief.
Iraqi women like Nahla and Dr. Eaman find strength to keep going despite the horrors they've faced.
Yanar, a fighter for women's rights, left her comfortable life to build support for women's rights in Iraq.

Here are the highlights:

Aung San Suu Kyi is "ready to cooperate" with Myanmar's government and seeks dialogue with the ruling junta.
She met with three executive members of her National League for Democracy, the first time in over three years.
Suu Kyi welcomed the appointment of Aung Kyi as minister of relations, a liaison between government and herself.
The UN's special envoy, Ibrahim Gambari, said the situation in Myanmar has improved, with a process for dialogue underway.

Here are the highlights:

Francesca Lewis, 13, sole survivor of plane crash, awake and talking after two days in rugged Panamanian mountains.
She was treated for a fractured arm and cuts, with no major damage reported.
Rescuers found her under a plane wing, disoriented and thinking she was at home.
She was carried to a helicopter in torrential rain and is now in stable condition.

Pakistan election officials disqualified Nawaz Sharif from January parliamentary elections due to previous convictions.
Sharif's candidacy was barred due to a criminal conviction, a spokesman for his party confirmed.
Sharif had filed paperwork for candidacy, but left open the possibility of boycotting the election.
He was convicted of terrorism, hijacking, and tax evasion after Musharraf seized power in 1999.

Kaka named European player of the year, winning France Football's Ballon d'Or award.
Kaka's success comes two years after Ronaldinho won the award, also from Brazil.
Kaka was a key factor in AC Milan's Champions League triumph and top scorer in 2007.
He has now won all major prizes individually and collectively at just 25 years old.

European leaders agree to send 1,800-strong security force to Kosovo ahead of independence declaration.
Force aims to maintain stability and ease handover from UN to local authorities.
EU leaders balance support for Kosovo's independence with incentives for Serbia's EU membership.
Serbia's EU membership dependent on recognizing Kosovo's independence and handing over war criminals.

Thousands of Chileans may have to sleep in the streets after a 7.7 magnitude earthquake kills at least two and injures dozens.
Hundreds of homes are destroyed, with over 1,200 totally flattened and many more damaged.
Tocopilla Mayor Luis Moyano says people will have to sleep in the street due to uninhabitable homes.
A tsunami warning was issued but later canceled, and aid organizations are rushing to the area.

No charges filed against 10-year-old boy who accidentally started 38,000-acre wildfire in California.
Boy admitted to starting fire by playing with matches, investigators said.
Fire destroyed 21 homes and 42 other structures in Agua Dulce community.
District attorney's office referred case to Department of Children and Family Services.

Here are the highlights:

Police found remains of missing Marine Lance Cpl. Maria Lauterbach in suspect's backyard.
Blood spatter evidence found inside suspect's home, indicating violent activity.
Authorities treating death as murder, suspect Cesar Armando Laurean is on the run.
Laurean's wife claims Lauterbach committed suicide, but police say evidence suggests otherwise.

Here are the highlights:

Investigators smuggled bomb-making components through 19 US airports without detection, exploiting TSA weaknesses.
GAO found security officers followed procedures, but vulnerabilities allowed testers to bypass security.
Devices built with smuggled components could cause severe damage to an airplane and threaten passenger safety.
TSA chief defends policies, citing a "multilayered approach" to security, but acknowledges need for improvement.

Kenya's disputed election has led to hundreds of deaths and displaced tens of thousands.
Businesses have been destroyed and looted, disrupting supply routes and affecting the economy.
The equity market lost 40 billion Kenyan Shillings ($591 million) in value on its first day of trading.
The country's tourism industry is also expected to take a hit due to the unrest.

Here are the highlights:

Terry Pratchett, 59, diagnosed with rare form of early onset Alzheimer's disease.
Plans to continue writing, including next book "Nation" and "Unseen Academicals".
Will meet most current and future commitments, but may need to adjust schedule.
Asks fans to keep things cheerful, saying "I think there's time for at least a few more books yet."

Iraqi forces detained suspected leader of terrorist cell network funded by Raghad Hussein, Saddam's eldest daughter.
Raghad Hussein is wanted by Iraqi authorities on terrorism charges and has an arrest warrant.
The network has been linked to attacks on coalition forces using rocket-propelled grenades and roadside bombs.
The raid was carried out by Iraqi forces, advised by US Special Forces, in Tikrit, Hussein's hometown.

Here are the highlights:

Hillary Clinton became emotional at a New Hampshire campaign event, her eyes welling with tears.
She spoke about the challenges of being a candidate and her passion for the country's future.
Clinton said she couldn't do it without believing it was the right thing to do.
She emphasized the importance of reversing the country's decline.

Here are the highlights:

Iraq's humanitarian crisis worsens, with no end in sight, according to Amnesty International and the Red Cross.
Amnesty reports a climate of impunity, economic collapse, and escalating refugee crisis.
Civilians continue to be killed and injured, with millions relying on poor-quality water and inadequate medical care.
Human rights violations, including torture and rape, remain rampant, with little accountability.

Here are the highlights:

Barrett Wissman's arts festivals, including Festival del Sole in Napa Valley, bond with local communities.
The festival attracts world-class artists, including Joshua Bell and Itzhak Perlman, with wine and cuisine.
Napa's wineries and hospitality industry enthusiastically support the festival, hosting events and dinners.
The festival's goal is to engage local communities and attract diverse audiences through music, art, and culture.

Lyon beats Valenciennes 2-0, staying four points ahead in French league.
Juninho and Sidney Govou score goals for Lyon.
Nancy celebrates 40th anniversary with 1-0 win over Bordeaux.
Troubled Paris St Germain wins 2-1 at Racing Strasbourg.

Here are the highlights:

Sen. Hillary Clinton won the New Hampshire primary with 39% of the vote.
She rebounded from a third-place finish in Iowa, thanks to strong support from women and Democrats.
Clinton's campaign emphasized her experience, saying she has delivered change as first lady and senator.
She also gained support from union voters, who made up 10% of the electorate.

Here are the highlights:

UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon sends envoy to Myanmar amid violent clashes between security forces and protesters.
Protests have spread to international cities, including London, outside the Myanmar embassy.
The envoy, Ibrahim Gambari, will lead a briefing on the situation for the UN Security Council.
The UN calls for the military junta to exercise restraint and cooperate with the envoy's mission.

Here are the highlights:

Buses for women only introduced in Mexico City to reduce harassment and discomfort.
Service started in January and is available on four major lines, to expand to 15 more.
Female passengers praise the service, saying it's more comfortable and safer.
Male drivers are being replaced with women, and buses are cleaner and more peaceful.

Kuwait's emir dissolves parliament amid power struggle with government over corruption and abuse of power allegations.
New elections set for May 17, following Cabinet's resignation and parliament's demands for investigations.
Emir cites fragile regional situation and internal security concerns for dissolving parliament.
Parliament, dominated by opposition politicians, has been at odds with government for months.

Here are the highlights:

FBI finds bodies of three children and their father, Eddie Harrington, who abducted them from their home in Columbus, Georgia.
Harrington, 28, had threatened to kill his children before disappearing with them on March 5.
The bodies were discovered in a wooded area of Columbus by a person walking nearby.
The children's mother, Agena Battle, had publicly begged for help to find her kids and pleaded for their safe return.

Here are the highlights:

Keri Christensen, a mother of two, is an Iraqi war veteran and combat veteran.
She was nearly a victim of a roadside bombing in Iraq and now struggles with depression and PTSD.
Women make up about 11% of the military force in Iraq and Afghanistan, with many seeing violence firsthand.
Christensen receives counseling and therapy to cope with her experiences and symptoms.

Here are the highlights:

Nurse practitioner Arlene Samen founded One H.E.A.R.T. to combat high infant and maternal mortality rates in Tibet and worldwide.
She provides childbirth education and equipment to remote areas, where women lack access to care.
One H.E.A.R.T. has distributed over 3,400 safe birthing kits and trained over 1,000 people in life-saving techniques.
The organization targets areas with high infant and maternal mortality rates, including Nayarit, Mexico, and plans to expand to Nepal and Ecuador.

Two graduate students found shot to death in an apartment off the LSU campus.
Bodies of Chandrasekhar Reddy Komma and Kiran Kumar Allam, both Ph.D. candidates from India, discovered.
No suspects identified; police investigating as a double homicide with possible home invasion robbery motive.
LSU campus remains open, with students and faculty warned to use caution.

Danish authorities arrested three people suspected of plotting to assassinate a cartoonist who drew Prophet Mohammed.
The cartoonist, Kurt Westergaard, was the target of the plot, which was foiled by the authorities.
The arrests were made in the Aarhus area of western Denmark and involved a Dane and two Tunisians.
The plot was allegedly planned to take place at Westergaard's home.

Here are the highlights:

Colleen Hiltbrunner traveled to South Africa for cosmetic surgery and a luxury safari.
Medical tourism is on the rise, with patients seeking cheaper options abroad.
Surgeries in many countries cost half or even one-fifth what they would in the US.
Patients must research the quality of doctors and facilities to ensure safe outcomes.

Scientists discover fossilized remains of giant rodent, estimated to be 3 meters long and 1.5 meters tall.
Rodent weighed around 1 ton, making it the largest discovered to date.
It likely fed on soft vegetables and fruit, not meat, due to small teeth.
Found in Uruguay, the rodent roamed the earth about four million years ago.

Rawalpindi's police chief stopped doctors from conducting an autopsy on Benazir Bhutto's body.
The police chief said Bhutto's husband objected to the autopsy, contradicting Pakistani law.
New video shows Bhutto being shot before a bomb exploded, contradicting government's account.
Doctors' clinical notes suggest Bhutto was shot, but police prevented autopsy from confirming.

Here are the highlights:

Atlanta becomes nation's bank robbery capital with 350 heists in 12 months.
FBI reports Atlanta's rapid growth and increased bank branches contribute to rise.
Violent crime is up across the nation, especially in major metro areas like Atlanta.
FBI advises banks to be extra vigilant during holiday season, profiling not recommended.

Here are the highlights:

Michael Vick says he's "forever a changed man" and asks for leniency in a handwritten letter to a judge.
He claims he's been unfairly judged and ridiculed for his actions.
Vick accepted responsibility for financing a dogfighting ring and asked for a second chance.
He pledged to use his earnings to help people and pay restitution.

Here are the highlights:

Steven Spielberg led FBI to stolen $700,000 Norman Rockwell painting in his California collection.
The original owner of the painting was stolen in 1973 from a Missouri gallery.
Only 5% of stolen art is recovered, and the original owner may not get it back.
The thief may sell the art on the black market, disguising its origin to avoid detection.

Here are the highlights:

Pete Sampras upset current world number one Roger Federer in an exhibition match in Macau.
Sampras won 7-6 6-4, avenging two previous defeats to Federer in the Asian series.
Federer was coming off a long season, and Sampras credited his big serve and indoor carpet surface.
Sampras ruled out a comeback from retirement, saying he had his time in the 90s.

Alex Trebek, 67, suffers minor heart attack at home, recovering in hospital.
Trebek has hosted "Jeopardy!" for 23 years, since 1984.
He is expected to resume taping in January, no previous condition known.
Trebek is a native of Sudbury, Ontario, and has hosted other game shows.

Archaeologists discover ruins of Aztec pyramid in Mexico City's Iztapalapa neighborhood.
Construction workers unearthed ancient walls in June, believed to be part of the main pyramid.
Government archeologist Jesus Sanchez hopes to find the city's main pyramid below the central plaza.
Excavation plans will be decided after a year-long investigation.

Here are the highlights:

Hundreds protest outside Sudanese presidential palace, demanding execution of teacher Gillian Gibbons.
Gibbons was convicted of insulting religion for naming a teddy bear "Mohammed" in class.
She was given 15 days in jail, with plans to appeal the sentence.
British lawmakers are en route to Khartoum to secure her early release.

Here are the highlights:

Two men sentenced to 15 years in prison for raping and kidnapping a 15-year-old French boy in Dubai.
The mother, Veronique Robert, is appealing the sentence, calling it too lenient.
The case has raised concerns about Dubai's treatment of rape victims and its laws on homosexuality.
The government says the sentence is in accordance with international standards and not lenient.

Chile recalls ambassador from Peru over disputed maritime territory.
Peru publishes new map, pushing its bid to negotiate a new sea border.
Chile protests, citing difficulties in bilateral relations, and exercises its territorial rights.
Peru seeks to downplay the row, emphasizing the need for open dialogue.

President Bush vetoed a bill to expand the State Children's Health Insurance Program for a second time.
The bill would have added $35 billion over five years, but Bush called it a "wrong direction" for healthcare.
Democrats said the bill addressed Republican concerns, but fell short of the two-thirds majority needed to override.
The program currently covers 6 million children and could be extended with a cigarette tax increase.

Mohammed Alshaya owns high street brands like Topshop, Coast, and NEXT in the Middle East.
He sees a new mindset in the Gulf, driven by a new generation of leaders.
Alshaya's retail division experiences 25-30% annual growth, with plans to expand into Eastern Europe.
He believes a single GCC currency would improve efficiency and conciliation between the six countries.

Two US Air Force F-15s escorted two Russian Bear bombers out of an air exclusion zone off Alaska.
Russian bombers were detected 500 miles off the Alaska coast by US radar.
US fighters from Elmendorf Air Force Base escorted the bombers without incident.
US military officials consider the incident a routine Russian military exercise.

Jeffrey Jamaleldine was shot in the face in Iraq, nearly killing him, but he'd go back to fight again.
He's a 31-year-old US Army scout who wears a Stetson hat and spurs on his boots.
Jamaleldine's father wishes he'd fight for Germany instead of the US, which invaded Iraq.
Jamaleldine's love for America is unwavering, and he'd sacrifice again to defend its ideals.

Here are the highlights:

Oprah Winfrey campaigns with Barack Obama in Iowa, New Hampshire, and South Carolina, drawing large crowds.
She praises Obama's "vision" for America and his ability to bring "statesmanship" to the White House.
Obama thanks Winfrey and his wife Michelle, emphasizing the "fierce urgency of now" in his stump speech.
Winfrey's endorsement is seen as a boost for Obama's campaign, particularly among African-American voters.

Here are the highlights:

A disgruntled former employee alerted Sudanese officials about a British teacher's teddy bear named "Mohammed".
Gillian Gibbons, 54, was convicted of insulting religion and sentenced to 15 days in jail and deportation.
Sudan's President Omar al-Bashir pardoned Gibbons and she was released, then deported to England.
The private school was shut down after the controversy, its future uncertain.

Here are the highlights:

Debra Lafave, former teacher, arrested for "inappropriate but non-sexual contact" with 17-year-old coworker.
Lafave violated probation terms by having contact with someone under 18.
She was released on her own recognizance and has no comment on the allegations.
Lafave's attorney says the contact was just a "workplace friendship".

Delta and American Airlines cancel hundreds of flights for wiring inspections on some of their jets.
Delta cancels 275 flights, affecting flights until early Friday, while American cancels 132 flights.
Passengers are rebooked and accommodated with hotel and food costs covered by the airlines.
Inspections are voluntary and expected to be completed by the end of the week.

Here are the highlights:

Four crew members died and one is missing after a fishing vessel sank off Alaska's Aleutian Islands.
The Alaska Ranger, a 180-foot processing trawler, reported water leaking into its steering gear compartment.
Most of the 47 people on board had survival suits, but four were confirmed dead and one is still unaccounted for.
The cause of death is unknown, but survival time without a suit is less than 30 minutes.

Ty Ziegel, a Marine sergeant, was badly wounded in Iraq and lost part of his skull and arm.
He fought the VA over disability benefits, feeling like a "Social Security number" rather than a person.
The VA system is criticized for being outdated and not prepared to handle the medical advances in the battlefield.
Ty Ziegel's story is one example of the struggles many wounded veterans face in the VA system.

Here are the highlights:

• College professor finds way for students to listen to lectures remotely using audio iPods.
• Tech toys for the holiday season include Nintendo DS Light, SanDisk Sansa Connect, and Nokia 5300 Music Express.
• Students use MP3 players to study and review lectures, with benefits including better grades and convenience.
• Advances in technology are changing the way we live and learn, with implications for education and employment.

Here are the highlights:

Two suspected car bombs struck Algiers, destroying UN headquarters and a government building.
At least 26 people are confirmed dead, with hospital sources reporting 76 fatalities.
Algerian Interior Minister blames a militant Islamic group with ties to al Qaeda for the attacks.
UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon condemns the attacks as "an abjectly cowardly strike".

Four people indicted for setting fire to Michigan State University research building in 1999.
Fire caused over $1 million in damage and loss of research records.
Accused of also setting fire to commercial logging equipment to sabotage lumbering activity.
Indictment comes after nearly a decade-long investigation.

Efraim Diveroli, 22, runs arms dealer company AEY Inc. with over $10 million in US government contracts.
Company supplied old Chinese ammunition to Afghan military, despite contract stating it would come from Hungary.
Diveroli's grandfather says he's being targeted by jealous competitors, while his father wishes he pursued a different career.
Diveroli's MySpace page hints at his desire for success and thrills, with a focus on weapons and military equipment.

A man was arrested at Orlando International Airport for trying to board a flight with bomb-making materials.
He was acting strangely, "rocking left and right and up and down," witnesses said.
The materials in his bags posed no danger, according to TSA officials.
He is scheduled for an initial appearance in federal court on Wednesday.

An A380 superjumbo partially rolled onto grass at Singapore airport after a tow truck malfunctioned.
No one was injured, but passengers were evacuated for inspection and potential damage assessment.
The plane was repositioned and all four tires were replaced, and it's now ready to fly again.
Most passengers continued to Sydney on a Boeing 747-400 or other flights.

Here are the highlights:

The Dalai Lama rejects Chinese allegations, denying he seeks Tibet's separation and Olympic sabotage.
He calls for dialogue with China and an end to violence in Tibet.
The Dalai Lama expresses sadness over loss of life, including Chinese victims, and prays for their families.
He urges China to exercise wisdom and initiate a meaningful dialogue with Tibetans.

Here are the highlights:

Gray wolves removed from Endangered Species Act's "threatened" list after 30 years.
There are now 1,500 gray wolves in Yellowstone National Park.
States can shoot wolves outside park boundaries once hunting season is established.
Conservationists fear hundreds of wolves will be killed by hunters and ranchers.

Congress passes bill to expand government's power to conduct electronic surveillance without court orders.
Measure allows National Security Agency to intercept communications between US and foreign targets.
Civil liberties groups warn of a broad net that could sweep up law-abiding US citizens.
President Bush urges Congress to pass the bill to protect national security.

Cuban President Raul Castro takes over from his brother Fidel, citing need for increased productivity and economic growth.
Salaries in Cuba average $15 per month, with many people relying on black market to make ends meet.
Raul Castro promises to increase incomes and savings, particularly for those in need, and to reduce red tape.
Cubans are calling for reforms, including greater freedom to travel and private ownership of land.

Researchers discover oldest gold jewelry in the Americas, a 4,000-year-old necklace found in Peru's Lake Titicaca region.
The gold and turquoise necklace was discovered near a human burial site by anthropologist Mark Aldenderfer.
The find is 600 years older than any other gold jewelry discovered in the Western Hemisphere.
The necklace may have been a status symbol for an individual in a society without formal leadership.

Bolivian President Evo Morales to sign legislation for May 4 referendum on new constitution.
Bolivian Congress decides to hold referendum on new constitution amid opposition from nonindigenous Bolivians.
Hundreds protest outside congressional building in La Paz to prevent opposition lawmakers from entering.
Referendum will allow Bolivian people to decide on new constitution's approval or rejection.

A B-2 stealth bomber crashed at Andersen Air Force Base in Guam, with two pilots ejecting safely.
The pilots, from the 509th Bomb Wing, were in good condition after the crash.
A board of officers will investigate the cause of the crash.
The incident is the second Air Force crash in three days.

Here are the highlights:

• Paint sealant may not be necessary for most cars, but consider climate and road conditions.
• Fabric or leather protection is a good purchase if you have kids or eat in the car regularly.
• Rustproofing is not necessary in most cases, as modern vehicles are less prone to underbody rusting.
• Extended warranties may not be worth it if you plan to sell the car before the manufacturer's warranty expires.

Here are the highlights:

Jeff Donohoo, 36, lives with autism and works at a hospital in Tennessee.
He's a passionate Braves fan and enjoys cooking and baking.
Donohoo's mother, Nancy, helped him socialize and adapt to daily routines.
He's dependable and valuable at work, despite challenges with social interactions.

Omar bin Laden, son of Osama, says he's against violence and wants his father to find another way.
He last saw his father in 2000 and has no idea where he is.
Omar is launching a movement for peace and is proud to be his father's son.
He doesn't consider his father a terrorist and believes he's fighting to protect Muslims.

A Chinese couple named their baby "@" because it echoes their love for the child in Chinese.
The "@" symbol is familiar to Chinese e-mail users, but they often pronounce it as "love him".
The name is an extreme example of people's adventurous approach to Chinese as commercialization and the Internet take hold.
The government has banned names using Arabic numerals, foreign languages, and symbols not belonging to Chinese minority languages.

Here are the highlights:

Miami ranks as the worst city for most aggressive drivers in the US, followed by New York, Boston, and Los Angeles.
The nation's roads are peppered with traffic black spots, causing frustration and road rage.
The rise in traffic levels and increasing age of drivers contribute to road rage, according to AAA.
Drivers can combat road rage by adjusting their habits, avoiding confrontations, and seeking help if needed.

Here are the highlights:

Courtney Larrell Lockhart, 23, arrested in connection with murder of Auburn University freshman Lauren Burk.
Lockhart's mother apologizes for the family's suffering, saying "I'm just sorry for the loss of that family."
Burk was found shot and killed on campus, with her car on fire nearby.
Police investigating whether a gas can found in downtown Auburn is related to the case.

Here are the highlights:

A cult member claims two women died in a cave, one from cancer and one from fasting, during their apocalyptic seclusion.
The cave-dweller, Vitaly Nedogon, relayed the information to Russian TV journalists.
The cult, led by Kuznetsov, had predicted the end of the world in May and threatened mass suicide.
Officials will investigate the claims once the remaining 11 cult members leave the cave.

Here are the highlights:

Richard Sonnen, 16, planned a Columbine-style attack at his Idaho high school due to bullying.
He spent 16 months in mental institutions after his mother discovered his plan.
Richard's mother, Elaine, saw warning signs in her son and took action to stop him.
He was diagnosed with bipolar disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, and other conditions.

Sunni and Shiite militias in Iraq are pulling displaced people into their movements due to government and international inaction.
2.7 million internally displaced Iraqis face daily struggles, including unemployment and lack of access to food and healthcare.
Militias are providing aid and services, including food, oil, and healthcare, to gain support and build their groups.
The international community is criticized for its lack of response to the humanitarian crisis in Iraq.

Here are the highlights:

Iowa's presidential caucuses may be won by candidates who perform well in specific regions.
The central part of the state is Democratic-leaning, while western Iowa is Republican-strong.
The Mississippi River city of Davenport and Linn County are key battlegrounds.
The Des Moines Register's endorsement is a highly sought-after prize in Iowa presidential politics.

Ajax drew 2-2 with Vitesse Arnhem, falling five points behind league leaders PSV Eindhoven.
Urby Emanuelson and Luis Suarez scored for Ajax in a four-minute span after halftime.
Feyenoord and Groningen drew 1-1, with Feyenoord's Mark-Jan Fledderus scoring an own goal.
Heracles won 5-0 at Venlo, their first away victory of the season.

Here are the highlights:

Queen Elizabeth II officially opens Heathrow's new Terminal 5, a $8.6 billion project 15 years in the making.
The terminal aims to increase passenger capacity and maintain Heathrow's status as a major transport hub.
Environmental groups criticize the expansion, citing increased emissions and climate change concerns.
Business groups welcome the expansion, citing its importance for the UK's economic competitiveness.

Coca-Cola was born in Atlanta, Georgia, on May 8, 1886, as a soda fountain drink.
It was first sold in Canada and Mexico in 1897 and in Panama in 1906.
The company entered China in 1927 and its 100th country, Sierra Leone, in 1957.
Today, Coca-Cola is the world's largest beverage company, operating in over 200 countries.

A 24-year-old gang member, Billy Ray Hines, was arrested for a shooting at a Los Angeles bus stop.
Eight people were wounded, including five children, and two intended victims are still being sought.
Hines faces 10 counts of attempted murder and authorities are seeking the gun used in the incident.
Witnesses identified Hines as the gunman, who was arrested near the scene of the shooting.

Soyuz space ship crew rests after rough ride back to Earth.
Craft carrying South Korea's first astronaut lands 260 miles off mark.
Crew subjected to severe G-forces during re-entry, but condition is satisfactory.
Search helicopters find capsule, confirm crew is unharmed.

Here are the highlights:

James Kruger survived a tornado that destroyed his house in Lafayette, Tennessee.
He credits his survival to a higher power, saying God was "beating his ass" to teach him a lesson.
Pam Whitaker lost her home and everything in it, including her disability check.
Tornadoes killed at least 56 people across four states, including 32 in Tennessee.

Man dies after falling 4 stories at Shea Stadium, police say he was sliding down escalator.
Daughter disputes police report, says father was walking down escalator, not sliding.
Witnesses saw 36-year-old Antonio Nararainsami sitting on banister before falling.
He died at hospital 25 minutes after 10 p.m. incident.

Heather Mills' divorce case with Paul McCartney ends with a £24.3 million settlement.
Judge Hugh Bennett criticizes Mills' "less than candid" testimony and "make-belief" claims.
Mills earned more money during the marriage than before, according to the judge's ruling.
McCartney presented balanced evidence and was a consistent witness, the judge wrote.

Here are the highlights:

A man at the center of a ricin exposure case has been arrested in Las Vegas.
Roger Bergendorff, 57, was hospitalized with ricin exposure in February.
He is charged with possession of a biological toxin and unregistered firearms.
He faces up to 30 years in prison and a $750,000 fine.

Here are the highlights:

Lonely Planet author Thomas Kohnstamm admits to plagiarizing and fabricating parts of travel guidebooks.
He also accepted free travel and didn't visit Colombia to write its guidebook.
Kohnstamm's book is set for release next week, detailing his experiences as a travel writer.
Lonely Planet is reviewing his work and considering changes to prevent similar incidents.

Samsung Group Chairman Lee Kun-hee plans to resign amid indictment for tax evasion and breach of trust.
Lee was charged with tax evasion and breach of trust in connection with company control transfer to his son.
Samsung is South Korea's largest conglomerate with annual sales of nearly $160 billion.
Company apologizes for causing concerns and plans to outline reform measures this week.

Here are the highlights:

Abu Dujana, alleged military commander of al Qaeda-linked Jemaah Islamiyah, sentenced to 15 years in prison.
He's suspected of plotting attacks on Australian Embassy and JW Marriott hotel in Jakarta.
Dujana is accused of involvement in Bali nightclub bombings that killed over 200 people.
He denied involvement in Marriott Hotel attack, saying he only met with plotter Noordin Top.

Here are the highlights:

Neanderthals' voices simulated, sounding like a frog croak or human burp.
Florida anthropologist Robert McCarthy used computer synthesizer to reconstruct Neanderthal vocal tracts.
Neanderthals lacked "quantal vowels" used in modern human language, speaking differently.
McCarthy plans to simulate an entire Neanderthal sentence using 50,000-year-old fossils.

Here are the highlights:

A Georgia military contractor, Pyrotechnic Specialties Inc., sold faulty stun grenades to law enforcement agencies.
The grenades were relabeled and sold after the Navy deemed them defective, causing injuries to FBI agents.
The company bribed a federal official and paid for a strip club visit, according to an indictment.
The indictment charges the company and three officials with conspiracy, money laundering, and fraud.

Here are the highlights:

The US government paid over $1.7 million to companies owned by Warren Jeffs' polygamous sect.
Companies Utah Tool and Die, Western Precision, and NewEra Manufacturing received defense contracts.
Some contracts were made after Jeffs was named to the FBI's "Most-Wanted List".
Money earned from government contracts was allegedly used to fund Jeffs' compounds and church activities.

Pope Benedict XVI addresses sex abuse scandal, calling it "gravely immoral behavior" and "deep shame".
He urges media and entertainment industry to promote moral renewal and protect children.
Pope praises US as "nation of prayer" and says religion plays a vital role in American life.
He will meet with US bishops and celebrate Mass at two baseball stadiums during his six-day visit.

Here are the highlights:

Staff Sgt. Tyrone Luther Hadnott charged with rape and other violations of the Uniform Code of Military Justice.
Alleged sexual assault of 14-year-old girl in Okinawa, Japan.
Japanese authorities released Hadnott after initial allegations dropped, but Marine Corps conducted own investigation.
Hadnott now faces court-martial, with no dates set.

Here are the highlights:

Sen. Barack Obama mocks Hillary Clinton for throwing back a shot of whiskey in front of TV crews.
Obama says Clinton is trying to "toughen him up" for a fall race against John McCain.
Clinton criticizes Obama's "bitter" comments about small-town Pennsylvanians.
Obama blasts Clinton for acting like "Annie Oakley" in her attempts to connect with gun owners.

Here are the highlights:

Kevin Kuranyi's early goal gave Schalke a 1-0 win over Hamburg, moving them to joint second in the Bundesliga.
Schalke and Werder Bremen are now nine points behind Bayern Munich with four games left.
Bayern can seal the title with a win over Stuttgart on Sunday, pending the outcome of other matches.
Werder Bremen drew 3-3 with Karlsruhe, missing a chance to put pressure on Bayern.

Here are the highlights:

Fungal disease: Circular patches of yellow-to-brown grass; treat with fungicide or corn-gluten mix.
Weeds: Fast-growing, unruly greenery; eradicate by hand or with herbicide, and aerate soil.
Insects: Brown turf with loose grass; treat with imidacloprid or beneficial nematodes.
Dog urine can "burn" turf; flush area with water immediately to prevent damage.

Tornadoes strike suburban Washington, mangling trees and stripping siding from several homes.
No injuries reported in the storm, which hit Maryland communities.
First tornado touched down in St. Charles, Maryland, with winds of 80 mph.
Second tornado hit Hyattsville, Maryland, with winds reaching 100 mph.

Here are the highlights:

• Scotland Yard inquiry into Benazir Bhutto's death concludes she died from head injury caused by bomb blast.
• No evidence of gunshot wound, but possibility of upper trunk or neck wound cannot be entirely ruled out.
• One attacker, not two, was involved in the immediate attack, and was likely standing near the rear of Bhutto's vehicle.
• The blast caused a violent collision between Bhutto's head and the escape hatch area of the vehicle.

Here are the highlights:

Storms in northern Georgia killed two people, with possible tornadoes causing damage and power outages.
Heavy damage reported in Prosperity, South Carolina, where residents saw a tornado touch down.
Tornadoes also touched down in Georgia, destroying homes and causing injuries.
Over 56,000 customers remained without power in South Carolina and Georgia.

Here are the highlights:

Iraqi report calls Blackwater USA's shooting "pre-meditated murder", demands $8 million compensation for each of 17 killed.
Report accuses guards of firing indiscriminately, violating Iraqi rights, and recommends payment to families of victims.
Blackwater says guards acted lawfully, citing hostile attack, but Iraqi government says no evidence of attack.
Security contractors have immunity from Iraqi law, but new steps are being taken to review their role in Iraq.

Here are the highlights:

Bill Clinton denies accusing Obama's campaign of "playing the race card" in an interview.
Clinton says his comments were taken out of context and twisted for political purposes.
Obama campaign denies planning to use race as an issue, says Clinton's comments are unclear.
Clinton refuses to answer questions about his comments, calls them a "cheap story" diversion.

Here are the highlights:

Fistfight breaks out between Ugandan and Libyan presidential guards at ceremony in Kampala, Uganda.
Several guards and journalists injured, no leaders hurt.
Libyan guards pushed away Ugandan guards at mosque entrance, sparking violence.
Ugandan guards fought back, drawing guns and causing chaos.

Here are the highlights:

A female suicide bomber killed at least 40 people and wounded 65 in Karbala, Iraq.
The blast occurred near the Imam Hussein shrine, a holy site for Shia Muslims.
Two American soldiers were killed by a roadside bomb north of Baghdad.
US Vice President Dick Cheney visited Iraq, saying the war has been "well worth the effort."

Nadia Comaneci became the first gymnast to score a perfect 10 in 1976 Montreal Olympics.
She won three gold medals and seven perfect scores in the Games.
Comaneci's initial perfect score on uneven parallel bars was greeted with uproar.
She defected to the United States in 1989, settling in Norman, Oklahoma.

Here are the highlights:

Fungal diseases: Circular patches of yellow-to-brown grass; or blades with tiny red threads; treat with fungicide or corn-gluten mix.
Weeds: Fast-growing, unruly greenery; eradicate by pulling or using liquid herbicide; prevent with good lawn care habits.
Insects: Brown turf, loose enough to lift; treat with pesticides or organic solutions like milky spore or nematodes.
Dog urine: High in nitrogen, can "burn" turf; flush area with water immediately to prevent damage.

Here are the highlights:

Michigan's Republican primary will be the main event on Tuesday, with John McCain seeking to replicate his New Hampshire win.
The primary is open to all registered voters, including independents and Democrats.
McCain won Michigan's 2000 primary, with 52% of voters identifying as independents or Democrats.
The Detroit Free Press and The Detroit News have endorsed McCain for the Republican nomination.

Here are the highlights:

Four US soldiers killed in roadside bombing in southern Baghdad, bringing total US deaths to 4,000.
The bombing was part of an improvised explosive device attack on a US military vehicle.
The US military has been fighting in Iraq for five years, with 3,263 killed in attacks and 737 in non-hostile incidents.
The US death toll has reached 4,000, with estimates of Iraqi deaths ranging from 80,000 to hundreds of thousands.

Here are the highlights:

Adam Gilchrist announces retirement from cricket at the end of the Australian summer.
He will retire from Tests after the current match and one-day internationals after the tri-series.
Gilchrist broke the world record for most wicketkeeping dismissals in Tests with 414.
He will spend more time with his family in his next phase of life.

Eduardo Gutierrez, a legal immigrant, struggles to send money to his parents in Mexico due to rising costs and less work.
He earns $18.50 an hour but hours have shrunk, and gas and grocery bills have skyrocketed.
Remittances from US workers to Mexico have decreased by $100 million in January, a consistent trend over the past year.
Eduardo's father in Mexico relies on the remittances to support his ailing father and 12 other family members.

Captain Javier Zanetti scored a late volley to earn Inter Milan a 1-1 draw against Roma.
Roma's Francesco Totti had given the visitors a first-half lead with a goal from a Max Tonetto cross.
Inter's Nicolas Burdisso missed a chance to equalize in first-half stoppage time.
Zanetti's goal maintained Inter's unbeaten Serie A record and nine-point lead at the top.

Rangers thrashed Hearts 4-0, their 10th consecutive Scottish Premier League win.
Jean-Claude Darcheville scored twice in the first half, including a goal from a tight angle.
Nacho Novo added two more goals, including a cheeky back-heel finish from five meters.
Celtic won 2-1 at home to Inverness Caledonian Thistle, with Scott McDonald scoring his 25th goal.

A Colorado woman, Rozita Swinton, is a person of interest in a Texas polygamist sect's abuse allegations.
She was arrested for making a false report to police in February.
Swinton made calls to authorities claiming abuse at the YFZ Ranch in March.
DNA samples are being taken from mothers and children at the ranch.

Colombian police killed a top drug trafficker, Victor Manuel Mejia Munera, in a shootout on a farm.
He was a key figure in a right-wing paramilitary group and had ties to drug trafficking.
The government had offered a reward for his capture, but he was killed in a police operation.
Three people were arrested and several weapons were seized in the operation.

Here are the highlights:

Democrats fear party's nomination process may become undemocratic due to superdelegates' influence.
Neither Hillary Clinton nor Barack Obama is likely to gather enough delegates for nomination.
Superdelegates' votes could tip the balance, potentially leading to a "civil war" in the party.
Party's superdelegate system was established to avoid convention turmoil, but some question its fairness.

Sarah Teres' 2-year-old daughter Molly refused to use the toilet, causing a family nightmare.
Teres enrolled Molly in the Toilet Training School at Children's Hospital Boston.
The school uses books, music, and art to help children overcome their fear of using the toilet.
Molly graduated from the program and is now fully toilet trained.

Here are the highlights:

Grand Theft Auto IV released Tuesday, expected to set sales records and rival Iron Man's box office.
The game's release date and widespread reach may negatively impact Iron Man's opening weekend.
Gamers may choose to play the game instead of watching the movie, analysts say.
The game's popularity could surpass Pirates of the Caribbean's opening weekend sales.

Here are the highlights:

Bobby Cutts Jr. apologizes to girlfriend's family, asking jury to spare his life.
He tearfully admits to murdering Jessie Marie Davis and their unborn child, Chloe.
Cutts' mother testifies, describing him as a former honor student and loving son.
Jury decides Cutts' punishment, which could be death or life in prison without parole.

Here are the highlights:

Rescue teams found the wreckage of a plane that crashed in Venezuela's Andes Mountains, killing all 46 on board.
The impact was direct, with the aircraft "practically pulverized" and no survivors.
The plane, carrying 43 passengers and three crew members, went missing during a flight from Merida to Caracas.
The cause of the crash is unknown, but harsh weather and rough terrain are expected to complicate the rescue effort.

A man dressed as a priest was caught at Amsterdam's Schiphol airport with 3 kilos of cocaine.
He claimed the packages contained "holy sand" and refused to be searched.
Police found the cocaine strapped to his legs beneath his priest's clothes.
The Bolivian national was arrested and charged with drug smuggling.

Two anti-whaling activists seized by Japanese vessel, handed over to Australian officials in Antarctic.
Benjamin Potts and Giles Lane from Sea Shepherd Conservation Society jumped on ship to protest whaling.
Australian Foreign Minister Stephen Smith stresses priority is retrieving the men, not addressing allegations.
Japan's Fisheries Agency calls Sea Shepherd members "terrorists", claims activists threw bottles at ship.

Here are the highlights:

Gen. David Petraeus chosen to become chief of US Central Command, replacing Adm. William Fallon.
Petraeus to leave Iraq in late summer or early fall, with Lt. Gen. Ray Odierno taking over.
Odierno, commander of Multinational Corps-Iraq, to return to Iraq to prepare for Petraeus' departure.
Gates expects Senate to approve nominations quickly, aiming for a smooth transition.

Here are the highlights:

Terrye Cheathem creates greeting cards for prison inmates, addressing complex emotions and tough love.
Cards express good wishes, celebrate holidays, and offer tough love, saying "Just do it."
Over 2.3 million people are in US jails or prisons, with a growing population.
Cards are sold online and in stores, aiming to capture sentiments for a captive audience.

Here are the highlights:

Joshua Hanson waited 8 hours to buy Halo 3, the most anticipated video game in history.
Halo 3 is expected to shatter entertainment sales records within its first 24 hours.
Fans praise the game's graphics, game play, and story, comparing it to Star Wars and Harry Potter.
The game's popularity has created a culture of millions of Xbox fans who "eat, sleep and live Halo."

Six US troops killed in Iraq, making 2007 the deadliest year for American military in the war.
Four soldiers died in a roadside bomb explosion in northern Iraq's Tameem province.
A sailor died in Salaheddin province due to injuries from an explosion.
Total US military deaths in Iraq now stand at 3,856.

Here are the highlights:

Lauren Burk, 18, a freshman at Auburn University, was found shot and killed on campus.
Courtney Larrell Lockhart, 23, is charged with capital murder in her death.
Police found Burk's car on fire and are investigating whether a gas can was used.
A campus-wide memorial service will be held Monday to honor Burk's memory.

Here are the highlights:

Parker's favorite dress is a 1950s-style cocktail dress by Gustavo Cadile.
She treasures a clutch that belonged to her aunt, a beautiful but impractical keepsake.
Her go-to outfit is a thermal top, scarf, and Victoria Beckham DVB jeans.
Her most expensive item is a hot-pink crocodile Hermès Birkin bag.

Here are the highlights:

The Svalbard Global Seed Vault, also known as the "Doomsday Vault", has received its first shipment of seeds.
The vault stores millions of seeds from around the world, including major food staples like maize and wheat.
The vault is designed to store 4.5 million distinct samples of seeds, or 2 billion seeds in total.
It will keep seeds safe for centuries, even in the event of global warming or other disasters.

White students at South African university tricked black workers into eating stew with urine, sparking outrage.
Video shows students urinating in stew, then encouraging workers to eat it, laughing.
Five people arrested during march to protest the incident and demand justice.
University officials condemn the video, suspend students and offer counseling to affected workers.

A tornado swept through Tupelo, Mississippi, damaging trees, power lines, and overturning an 18-wheel truck.
The storm moved north across the city, causing damage to the Mall at Barnes Crossing and Tupelo Regional Airport.
The airport sustained minor damage, including broken windows, and was closed briefly before reopening.
No injuries were reported, and authorities are assessing the damage.

Here are the highlights:

Saudi Arabia's oil wealth fuels economic growth, but also causes high inflation.
Inflation in Saudi Arabia is at a 30-year high of 9.6%.
Rental costs, fuel, and water prices have increased significantly.
The government is studying remedies, but experts say there's no quick solution.

A man in north India pushed a 6-year-old Dalit girl into burning embers, seriously burning her.
The girl was walking with her mother on a path reserved for upper caste villagers.
The man, a teenager, was charged with attempted murder and confessed to the crime.
The attack is one of several recent incidents of violence against Dalits in Uttar Pradesh.

Here are the highlights:

Obama wants to focus on Iraq, al Qaeda, and global influence as president.
He believes the US has lost its sense of identity and values worldwide.
Obama criticizes the war in Iraq for distracting from key issues like energy policy and global warming.
He thinks he and Clinton will split remaining contests, with her winning West Virginia by a "big margin".

Here are the highlights:

Lufthansa Airlines flight scrapes wing on ground during landing attempt in Hamburg, Germany.
Plane recovers and lands safely after pilot pulls up to avoid damage.
Gust of wind causes wing to scrape ground, pilot says.
Damage is minimal and not structural, plane is back in service.

Here are the highlights:

An explosion destroyed a home in suburban Pittsburgh, killing an elderly man and injuring his grandchild.
The blast occurred on Mardi Gras Drive in Plum Borough, 15 miles northeast of Pittsburgh.
The elderly man, 64, was babysitting his grandchild when the explosion happened.
Several neighboring homes were damaged, and several families were displaced.

Dutch tourist claims to have spotted Madeleine McCann at a French restaurant near Montpellier.
Tourist recognized Madeleine from media reports and may have seen her distinctive eye defect.
Surveillance tape shows a girl matching Madeleine's description at the L'Arche restaurant.
Police investigated, but determined it was not the missing child.

Nicaragua breaks diplomatic relations with Colombia in solidarity with Ecuador.
Colombia's attack on a rebel camp in Ecuador sparks regional tensions.
OAS passes resolution to ease tensions, orders commission to investigate and propose solutions.
US Defense Secretary Robert Gates sees little chance of war between Colombia, Ecuador, and Venezuela.

Here are the highlights:

Five young men died when their car drove off a private airstrip in Florida and crashed into an oak tree.
The 2008 BMW was split in two in the violent wreck, with all victims declared dead at the scene.
The car became airborne for 200 feet before striking the tree, ejecting three occupants.
Authorities are investigating the cause of the crash, including the possibility of alcohol or drugs.

Here are the highlights:

A year after a tornado destroyed 90% of Greensburg, Kansas, the town is rebuilding with green building in mind.
The mayor, governor's office, and nonprofit expert formed Greensburg GreenTown to create a model for sustainability.
Residents and businesses are working together to build energy-efficient homes and businesses, including a John Deere dealership.
The town aims to be 100% renewable energy and attract new green businesses, including a biodiesel facility.

Police dogs in Duesseldorf, Germany wear protective shoes to shield their paws from broken glass.
Beer drinkers often discard bottles on pebbled walkways, leaving behind sharp glass shards.
The shoes are also used by dogs walking on ice in Alaska, costing 60 euros each.
Dogs need a month of training to get accustomed to wearing the protective footwear.

Native Hawaiians occupy Iolani Palace grounds, vowing to stay and govern the kingdom.
Group claims the 1893 overthrow of the monarchy was illegal and seeks its return.
Protesters chained gates, stationed guards, and kept the palace closed to visitors.
Palace staff and visitors expressed mixed reactions to the occupation.

UN's anti-drugs chief criticizes Amy Winehouse and Kate Moss for alleged drug use, saying it devastates West Africa.
Cocaine used in Europe passes through impoverished African countries, corrupting governments and creating addicts.
UN official says Winehouse's fame sends a damaging message to vulnerable youth.
Kate Moss also targeted for alleged drug use, undermining anti-poverty efforts in Africa.

Fistfight erupts between Ugandan and Libyan presidential guards at ceremony in Kampala.
Several guards and journalists injured, no leaders hurt, but several knocked over.
Libyan guards push away other guards, sparking fury and a brief fight.
Leaders from 11 African nations attend the opening of the Gadhafi National Mosque.

Here are the highlights:

Lionel Messi will be out for six weeks after tearing a muscle in his left leg.
He was injured during Barcelona's 1-0 Champions League victory over Celtic.
Messi will miss both legs of Barcelona's Champions League quarterfinal encounter.
Thierry Henry may replace Messi in the starting lineup, with Deco and Dos Santos as options.

Here are the highlights:

Remains of adult and fetus found in shallow grave in backyard of suspect Cesar Armando Laurean.
Laurean arrested for first-degree murder in death of Marine Lance Cpl. Maria Lauterbach.
Body was charred, fetus in victim's abdomen, with burned hand and fingers.
DNA testing and dental records to confirm identity of remains.

Here are the highlights:

U.S. Embassy in Belgrade evacuated due to attack by protesters.
Riot police stand guard outside damaged embassy with blackened walls and broken windows.
Undersecretary of State R. Nicholas Burns criticizes Serbian government for inadequate security.
Protesters attacked Western embassies, shops, and a McDonald's restaurant in Belgrade.

China's giant pandas believed safe after earthquake, but concerns over food supply and infrastructure damage.
Captive pandas in two major reserves reported alive, but habitat damage raises concerns.
Giant pandas' primary food source, bamboo, may be affected by infrastructure damage.
Scientists hopeful that Chinese researchers will adapt to the situation and find alternative food sources.

Here are the highlights:

Sen. Hillary Clinton wins Texas and Ohio primaries, crucial for keeping White House hopes alive.
Clinton leads in Ohio with 54% of the vote, Obama with 44%.
Texas results are closer, with Clinton at 51% and Obama at 48%.
Clinton's wins give her a boost, but Obama still leads in delegate count.

US border officers found a wire between fences that could have harmed or decapitated agents.
The wire was 4 feet high when pulled tight, neck level for an agent on an ATV.
It was discovered by authorities monitoring a surveillance camera on the US-Mexican border.
No arrests were made, and the wire was removed without incident.

Here are the highlights:

Sen. Barack Obama wins South Carolina Democratic primary with 55% of the vote.
Obama defeats Sen. Hillary Clinton 55% to 27%, with John Edwards at 18%.
Obama's victory is seen as crucial for his campaign, ahead of Super Tuesday.
Obama's message of change resonates with South Carolina voters, particularly African Americans.

Here are the highlights:

Jamiel Shaw, 17, was shot and killed by gang members while walking home from school.
His father heard the shots and rushed to find his son's lifeless body.
Police arrested Pedro Espinoza, 19, and charged him with murder, potentially facing the death penalty.
Shaw's death is one of several gang-related killings in Los Angeles in recent weeks.

Here are the highlights:

Lewis Hamilton signs 5-year contract with McLaren worth $140m, making him one of the most marketable sport stars.
He's expected to earn over $1 billion if he maintains buzz created by his first season in Formula One.
Experts say Hamilton's marketability stems from his youth, articulacy, and charisma.
He's considered the most marketable driver in the short term, with potential to earn more than Michael Schumacher.

Here are the highlights:

China's giant pandas are believed to be safe after the earthquake, but concerns remain about their food supply.
Infrastructure damage may harm the pandas' bamboo supply, their primary source of food.
Staff and animals at two major panda reserves are confirmed safe, but access to resources is uncertain.
Scientists are hopeful that Chinese researchers will adapt to the situation and find alternative food sources.

Here are the highlights:

Red Cross President Mark W. Everson resigns due to personal relationship with subordinate employee.
Everson leaves post immediately, citing "personal and family reasons" and regret.
Red Cross Board of Governors asked for and received his resignation due to poor judgment.
Mary S. Elcano, general counsel, appointed as interim president and CEO.

Here are the highlights:

Canada's House of Commons voted to extend military mission in Afghanistan until 2011.
Troops will stay if NATO sends reinforcements to Kandahar province.
Canada wants at least 1,000 additional troops to join the mission.
80 Canadian soldiers and a diplomat have been killed in the conflict.

Police dogs in Duesseldorf, Germany wear protective shoes to shield their paws from broken glass.
The shoes were purchased for 60 euros, also worn by dogs in Alaska.
Dogs need a month of training to get used to wearing the protective shoes.
Broken glass is a problem for the police force's 20 German Shepherds and Belgian Shepherds.

Here are the highlights:

Barcelona president Joan Laporta says the club is ready for Ronaldinho to leave.
Ronaldinho struggled with injuries and poor form last season.
AC Milan showed interest in signing him, but a transfer fee was not agreed.
Barcelona will replace coach Frank Rijkaard with former player Josep Guardiola.

Here are the highlights:

Eight US troops killed in two bombings in Iraq, including five in Baghdad and three in Diyala province.
A suicide bomber killed a sheik and his 5-year-old niece in Diyala province.
US military reports 10 US troops killed in Iraq this month, 3,983 total since the war began.
Female suicide bombers increasingly used in Iraq, including a recent attack at a Baghdad pet market.

Here are the highlights:

ICE Chief Julie Myers attended a Halloween party where an employee wore a prison costume with skin-darkening makeup.
Myers ordered the photos deleted, citing the need to treat prisoners with dignity and respect.
The photos were later released under the Freedom of Information Act, sparking outrage in Congress.
Myers was confirmed as ICE chief despite the controversy.

Here are the highlights:

A train derailment in Lafayette, Louisiana, caused a toxic chemical spill, forcing 3,000 people to evacuate.
Hydrochloric acid leaked from two train cars, creating a toxic cloud and prompting evacuations.
Residents were advised to close windows and doors and turn off air conditioning to avoid contamination.
Cleanup efforts are underway, with authorities working to contain the spill and allow residents to return home.

Here are the highlights:

Uno's Chicago Grill: Offers transfat-free menu, grilled entrees, and whole-grain pasta and rice options.
Souplantation & Sweet Tomatoes: Provides fresh produce, low-sodium options, and a salad bar with nonfat dressings.
Mimi's Cafe: Serves healthy options like half-pound cheeseburgers wrapped in lettuce and grilled chicken with fresh steamed veggies.
P.F. Chang's China Bistro: Offers wok-based cooking with low fat content, whole-grain brown rice, and all-natural chicken and fish.

Here are the highlights:

Muqtada al-Sadr accuses Iraqi and US forces of attacking Sadr City, hours after his aide's assassination.
Heavy fighting reported between US-backed Iraqi troops and al-Sadr's Mehdi Army militia in Sadr City.
US forces kill 10 attackers, including 4 with RPGs, in Sadr City and Najaf.
US military claims no US or Iraqi troops were seriously hurt in the clashes.

Here are the highlights:

The Taliban's military and technical capabilities have strengthened despite heavy combat losses, says a State Department report.
The group's information operations have become more aggressive and sophisticated, and it still receives support from al Qaeda.
Afghanistan has struggled to build a stable government, but has taken steps to address poverty and build relationships with neighboring Pakistan.
The US military is concerned about the situation, calling for more troops to hold southern Afghanistan and train local forces.

Here are the highlights:

Tony Fernandes built Air Asia from a bankrupt carrier to the region's biggest budget airline in just five years.
He left a comfortable job in the music industry to start a new business in the aviation industry.
Fernandes believes in empowering employees, saying "everyone's got ability, it's how you bring the best out of them."
He prioritizes focus and discipline, sticking to a plan and vision to achieve success.

Joran van der Sloot questioned by Aruban authorities in Netherlands about Natalee Holloway's disappearance.
He denied any role in her vanishing and claimed he was under the influence of marijuana.
Video footage shows van der Sloot saying he was with Holloway when she died, but he claims it was a lie.
Aruban prosecutor's office says evidence exists to reopen inquiry against van der Sloot.

Here are the highlights:

A US Marine pleaded guilty to abusive sexual contact with a child under 16 in Japan.
He was sentenced to four years of confinement and faced other dropped charges.
The case sparked outrage in Japan, with the Prime Minister calling it "unforgivable".
The Marine Corps condemned the act, stating it does not tolerate sexual assault.

Cristiano Ronaldo missed an early penalty for Manchester United in the Champions League semifinal.
Manchester United earned a 0-0 draw in the first leg at Barcelona's Nou Camp stadium.
United goalkeeper Edwin van der Sar made a string of saves to keep the score level.
Barcelona's Lionel Messi returned from illness but was unable to score.

Here are the highlights:

Nelly Avila Moreno, alias Karina, surrendered to Colombian authorities after 24 years with the FARC.
She said she and her companion decided to abandon the group due to pressure from Colombian soldiers.
Karina called on fellow rebels to follow her example and laid blame on the group's leaders for the killing of Ivan Rios.
Colombian army chief Gen. Mario Montoya hailed Karina's surrender as a "confounding strike" against the FARC.

Al Qaeda still operates in Pakistan's tribal region, despite $10.5 billion in US aid.
US lacks comprehensive plan to meet national security goals in the region.
96% of US aid reimbursed Pakistan for military operations in the region.
No plan integrates Defense, State, USAID, and intelligence community capabilities.

Here are the highlights:

Wii Fit makes working out fun by turning exercise into games.
It's easy to get started and track progress over time.
The balance board is sleek and compact, fitting in with any living room.
The program offers 48 activities, including yoga, aerobics, and balance games.

Here are the highlights:

At least 63 people killed and over 200 wounded in Jaipur bomb attacks on Tuesday.
Police impose curfew to prevent communal violence and hamper investigation.
Authorities suspect Harkat-ul-Jihad al-Islami (HuJi) of being behind the attacks.
Nine newly-purchased bicycles found at the scene, used to carry explosives.

Here are the highlights:

At least 60 people killed and 150 injured in series of explosions in Jaipur, India.
Explosions occurred near tourist spots, including Hanuman Temple and market area.
No immediate claim of responsibility, but Indian government labels it a terrorist attack.
Rajasthan and Delhi placed on high alert, with investigation ongoing.

South Korea's new president, Lee Myung-Bak, pledges to donate his salary to the underprivileged.
He made the promise during an unscheduled meeting with reporters on Sunday.
Lee has a vast personal fortune, but as mayor, he donated his salary to street cleaners' children.
He plans to keep only a retirement house in Seoul and give away his entire fortune.

Warren Buffett named world's richest person with $62 billion net worth.
Bill Gates drops to third place with $58 billion net worth.
Mexico's Carlos Slim Helu ranks second with $60 billion net worth.
Forbes lists over 1,000 billionaires worldwide with total net worth of $4.4 trillion.

Here are the highlights:

Rufus Terrill, a bar owner, patrols Atlanta streets with his "Bum-bot" robot, chasing off bums and drug dealers.
Armed with a water gun and infrared camera, the robot spotlights trespassers and chases them away.
The robot has become a welcome sight for nearby daycare center operator Lydia Meredith, who's tired of cleaning up after shady characters.
The robot's creator, Terrill, is a neighborhood vigilante who's determined to keep the area safe for local children.

Here are the highlights:

Polish immigrant Robert Dziekanski died after being shot with a stun gun by Canadian police at Vancouver International Airport.
Dziekanski, 40, was agitated and had never flown before, did not speak English.
Police used a Taser device after confronting him, with one officer pinning his neck and head to the ground.
The incident is being investigated by police and Canada's national police complaints commission.

Here are the highlights:

Eliot Spitzer, NY governor, linked to top-dollar prostitution ring, faces political future uncertainty.
Spitzer publicly apologized for undisclosed personal matter, did not resign or mention prostitution sting.
Many political professionals say he cannot survive the scandal, citing hypocrisy and potential criminal charges.
Spitzer's resignation is seen as likely, with Lt. Gov. David Paterson set to take over if he steps down.

Here are the highlights:

Gordon B. Hinckley, 97, died Sunday night, president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints since 1995.
He had been in failing health for some time and died with his family by his side.
Hinckley was the 15th president in the church's 177-year history and oversaw significant growth and temple-building.
He was known for his wit, wisdom, and leadership, and will be deeply missed.

Here are the highlights:

John McCain clinches Republican nomination with sweep of GOP contests in four states.
McCain now has 1,195 delegates, four more than needed to secure nomination.
He will face Democratic contenders Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama in the general election.
McCain's campaign now shifts focus to making a case to the American people.

Here are the highlights:

Josef Fritzl kept his daughter and three children imprisoned in an underground cellar for 24 years.
He admitted to raping his daughter and fathering her seven children, six of whom survived.
The cellar was hidden behind an electronic door and took eight doors to access, including a steel and concrete door.
Fritzl's daughter, Elisabeth, and her children were reunited with her mother and are receiving medical care.

A man in a Basra detention center confesses to killing 15 girls, including a 9-year-old, and raping one.
He says he was forced to kill the girl, Ahlam, a university student, with a machine gun.
Iraqi authorities show a list of 15 girls he admitted kidnapping, raping, and killing.
The suspect was arrested by Iraqi security forces after they retook Basra in April.

Here are the highlights:

Sen. Barack Obama raised over $40 million in March from over 442,000 donors.
More than 218,000 donors gave for the first time, the campaign said.
Obama's total surpasses the Democratic record of $215 million in 2004.
He is $25 million shy of President Bush's fundraising record of $259 million.

Here are the highlights:

John Duns Scotus, a 13th-century thinker, was not dumb, but his views were criticized by others.
Mickey Finn, a Chicago saloon owner, earned his name for drugging and robbing customers.
Reverend William Archibald Spooner's speech errors led to the term "spoonerism".
Charles Lynch, a patriot and judge, was known for his vigilante court and "lynch law".

Here are the highlights:

Sen. John Kerry endorses Sen. Barack Obama for Democratic presidential nomination.
Kerry says Obama can bring change to the country and shatter the mold.
The endorsement is seen as a blow to former Sen. John Edwards.
Kerry's endorsement could be a big boost to Obama's campaign.

Here are the highlights:

Rising food prices threaten to plunge over 100 million people into hunger, says UN World Food Program.
Biofuels may be contributing to the crisis, driving up prices and displacing food crops.
Experts warn of a "silent tsunami" of hunger, affecting vulnerable populations worldwide.
UN and world leaders gather to discuss solutions to address the global food crisis.

Gasoline prices set a record for the 16th consecutive day, averaging $3.62 per gallon.
Shell Oil Co. President John Hofmeister calls for increased US oil production to stabilize prices.
Hofmeister suggests producing 2-3 million more barrels per day to reduce dependence on foreign oil.
President Bush and presidential candidates weigh in on the issue, with some advocating for more drilling.

A tornado struck Atlanta's historic Cabbagetown district, causing destruction and flooding in the neighborhood.
Residents describe the storm's sudden arrival with no warning, leaving some homes intact and others severely damaged.
Bertha Wise's yellow and cobalt-blue house was hit, with a splintered tree blocking her side door and car.
Residents are left to survey the damage, with some reporting looting and others expressing gratitude for their safety.

Bryant Purvis, a member of the "Jena 6," arrested for misdemeanor assault in Texas high school fight.
Purvis allegedly choked and pushed a student who had not flattened his friend's car tires.
He was arrested, charged, and released on $1,000 bond.
Purvis is awaiting trial for a separate incident in Louisiana.

Nigerian rebels attack two oil pipelines, asking Jimmy Carter and George Clooney to mediate issues in the Niger Delta.
Rebels claim attack was in response to government's failure to address regional injustices.
Pipeline damage will temporarily cut oil shipments by 169,000 barrels a day.
Rebels seek equal distribution of oil wealth and an end to government's "insincere" policies.

Here are the highlights:

Sin Hwa Dee started as a cottage industry in Singapore in the 1970s producing soya and oyster sauces.
The company expanded to produce preserved fruits and vegetables for Lunar New Year dishes.
Sin Hwa Dee introduced its products to the foreign market in 1992 and launched premixes in 1994.
Today, the company produces over 20 tons of sauces per day for clients like Singapore Airlines and Ritz Carlton.

Here are the highlights:

Writers Guild of America members vote to end 100-day strike, returning to work.
New deal covers residuals for writing in digital age, including new media and Internet.
Agreement is for three years, with writers achieving two of three goals.
Writers can now return to work, with new episodes of scripted programs expected to resume soon.

Here are the highlights:

Pope Benedict XVI's US trip has an unofficial motto: "This is not a political event."
The "Catholic vote" matters in US elections, with 70 million Catholics representing a quarter of the population.
Pope's visit unlikely to offer a decisive boost to either party, but could be exploited by both sides.
Papal message may be interpreted differently by Republicans and Democrats, sparking a "war for the microphone".

Here are the highlights:

Canada's House of Commons voted to extend military mission in Afghanistan until 2011.
Troops will stay if NATO sends reinforcements to Kandahar province.
Canada's 2,500 troops in Afghanistan have made progress in providing aid and security.
80 Canadian soldiers and a diplomat have been killed in the mission so far.

Here are the highlights:

Texas has the highest rural speed limit, 80 mph, on over 500 miles of interstate.
Montana's rural speed limit is 75 mph, allowing for a 3-hour drive from Billings to Butte.
St. Thomas in the U.S. Virgin Islands has a 20 mph city speed limit and 30 mph rural limit.
Nationwide, speed limits vary from 60 mph in Hawaii to 75 mph in most Western states.

Here are the highlights:

Math teacher Mawise Gumba fled Zimbabwe, finding his qualifications useless as a refugee in South Africa.
He joined the estimated 4,000 Zimbabweans who head to South Africa every day, mostly illegally.
Gumba lost his job due to Zimbabwe's economic crisis and inflation of nearly 5,000%.
He now seeks shelter and work in Johannesburg, hoping to find a better life.

Here are the highlights:

Three US soldiers killed and 31 wounded in two rocket attacks in Baghdad.
Fighting between US troops and Mehdi Army militia leaves 20 dead and 52 wounded in Sadr City.
Iraqi PM Nuri al-Maliki demands Muqtada al-Sadr disband Mehdi Army and threatens to bar followers from politics.
US military death toll in Iraq war reaches 4,022, with 30,000 wounded in action.

Here are the highlights:

Barack Obama defends himself and wife against unpatriotic claims.
He cites not putting hand on heart during national anthem as common behavior.
Obama says he will respond to attacks with truth, emphasizing his love for the country.
He criticizes Republicans for their own lack of patriotism, citing war and policy issues.

Here are the highlights:

Six Italian men were shot dead in Duisburg, Germany, in an execution-style killing linked to a mafia feud.
The killings are believed to be linked to a feud between two mafia clans in Calabria, Italy.
The 'Ndrangheta organized crime group is based in Calabria and has ties to drug trafficking and other illegal activities.
The group earns an estimated $30 billion annually, mostly from illegal drugs and other illegal businesses.

Here are the highlights:

Sumner Elementary School, Topeka, Kansas: Historic site of 1954 Supreme Court case Brown v. Board of Education.
Boyd Theater, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania: 1928 Art Deco movie palace threatened by lack of funding and potential sale.
Charity Hospital and adjacent neighborhood, New Orleans, Louisiana: Historic hospital and homes face demolition for new hospital construction.
Hangar One, Moffett Field, California: 1932 dirigible hangar with carcinogenic PCBs leaks, faces environmental remediation and potential demolition.

Panama City Beach police seek Shawn Wuertly, 29, for attempted murder and sexual battery.
Wuertly allegedly raped an 18-year-old Alabama student and threw her off a sixth-floor balcony.
The student remains hospitalized with non-life-threatening injuries.
Wuertly has an outstanding arrest warrant in Indiana, which was not discovered during initial questioning.

Here are the highlights:

John McWethy, former ABC News chief national security correspondent, died in a Colorado skiing accident.
He was 61 and had recently moved to Boulder to enjoy the ski trails.
McWethy was a renowned reporter known for his objectivity and ability to stay calm under pressure.
He won numerous awards, including five national Emmys and an Alfred I. duPont-Columbia Award.

Here are the highlights:

Investors seek safe havens in tough economic times, turning to high-end musical instruments like Stradivarius violins.
Investment funds specialize in these instruments, allowing musicians to use them while investors reap profits.
Profits can appreciate by 3.5% per year, beating U.S. Treasury bonds since 1850.
Investors support musicians, enjoying financial gain and the thrill of hearing their instruments performed.

Mexico City introduces single-sex buses for women to reduce harassment and discomfort.
Four major lines now offer the service, with plans to expand to 15 more.
Passengers praise the service, citing increased comfort and safety.
Female drivers may replace male drivers to further reduce unwanted contact.

Milan held to a 1-1 draw by Fiorentina in Serie A match.
Kaka scores from penalty spot in 27th minute, Mutu equalizes with 56th-minute header.
Filippo Inzaghi misses open net in 71st minute, Fiorentina hits post late on.
Milan coach Carlo Ancelotti praises team's effort despite not getting maximum points.

Here are the highlights:

Samuel David Crowe's death sentence commuted to life in prison by Georgia Board of Pardons and Paroles.
Crowe was convicted of murdering a retail manager in 1988 and had been scheduled for execution.
He had been serving time in prison, where he helped other inmates with addiction issues.
Crowe was shocked and relieved by the news, but also somber about the harm he caused.

Here are the highlights:

A Boeing 777 landed short of the runway at London Heathrow, skidding on grass and ripping apart sections.
17 people suffered minor injuries, with several others still being assessed.
The plane's captain claimed there was no power when he needed it, and the aircraft's electronics failed.
The UK Air Accident Investigation Branch will lead the inquiry into the crash landing.

Here are the highlights:

Every day, five US soldiers try to kill themselves, a 5-fold increase since the Iraq war began.
2,100 soldiers attempted suicide in 2007, with the rate rising for five consecutive years.
Senators introduce legislation to improve military suicide-prevention programs and mental health treatment.
Soldiers report receiving only an 800 number for help, calling for real people and professionals.

Here are the highlights:

A German woman held hostage in Iraq since February has been freed.
Her son, Sinan, remains in captivity, with Germany working to secure his release.
Militants had demanded Germany withdraw its troops from Afghanistan to ensure their safety.
The woman was taken to Germany's embassy in Baghdad after being released.

Here are the highlights:

Judge orders prosecution of 100 former Chilean soldiers and secret police for human rights abuses.
Charges relate to disappearances and deaths of 119 people during Augusto Pinochet's dictatorship.
Former DINA director Manuel Contreras already sentenced to 250 years in prison for human rights violations.
Ex-soldiers to be taken to military compounds, while civilian suspects will be jailed in Santiago penal facilities.

Here are the highlights:

Sen. Barack Obama calls for "libertad" and freedom for Cubans, promising justice and fair elections.
He wants looser travel restrictions and larger money transfers to the island.
Obama criticizes Sen. John McCain's stance on Cuba, saying it's a "failed policy" and "lip service".
Younger Cuban-Americans are questioning their community's alliance with the GOP, seeking change.

Valentino Rossi takes pole position at his home race in Mugello with a lap of 1:48.130 seconds.
He secured his 50th pole position overall and 40th in MotoGP, ahead of Dani Pedrosa and Loris Capirossi.
Rossi's pole marks his first of the season and continues his winning streak.
