He is three points ahead of Pedrosa and Jorge Lorenzo going into Sunday's race.

Here are the highlights:

Sharon Stone apologizes for saying China's earthquake was "karma" for not being nice to the Dalai Lama.
She calls her comments "unintentional" and "a product of news sensationalism".
Stone's remarks drew fire from Chinese officials and citizens, leading to her removal from Chinese ads.
Stone says she's "deeply saddened" by the pain caused to earthquake victims.

Rafael Nadal beats Jarko Nieminen 6-1 6-3 6-1, advancing to French Open's last 16.
Nadal cruises past Nieminen in under two hours, extending his winning record to 24 matches.
Novak Djokovic easily defeats Wayne Odesnik 7-5 6-4 6-2 in another third-round match.
Nicolas Almagro edges Andy Murray 6-3 6-7 6-3 7-5, setting up a clash with Jeremy Chardy.

Seven England players, including John Terry and Wayne Rooney, excused from Trinidad and Tobago friendly due to Champions League final involvement.
Rio Ferdinand and Wayne Bridge are exceptions, joining 22-man squad for the friendly.
Only three goalkeepers, 10 defenders, seven midfielders, and four forwards make up the England squad.
Jermain Defoe is the only player from the Champions League final to be selected for the friendly.

Here are the highlights:

Roger Von Bergendorff, 57, indicted for possessing ricin, weapons, and anarchist manual in his hotel room.
Authorities found ricin, guns, and hazardous materials in his Nevada hotel room.
Bergendorff was hospitalized for two months with suspected ricin poisoning and discharged before arrest.
He faces up to 30 years in prison if convicted.

Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe warns against outside influences in upcoming election.
He likens US diplomat Jendayi Frazer to a "prostitute" and threatens to expel US Ambassador James McGee.
Mugabe criticizes US and Britain, saying Zimbabwe is African, not British or American.
He denies responsibility for election-related violence and intimidation.

Here are the highlights:

Inter Milan fires coach Roberto Mancini, citing his comments about not staying after season.
Mancini rescinds comments, saying he wants to stay and win Champions League.
Former Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is favorite to replace Mancini.
Mancini's contract ends in 2012, leaving him 24 million euros richer as compensation.

Here are the highlights:

Chelsea Clinton faces renewed media scrutiny as she campaigns for her mother, Hillary Clinton.
She accompanies her mother to the polls on Super Tuesday in Chappaqua, New York.
Chelsea Clinton has been off-limits to the media since she was a girl, but pressure grows to burst her protective bubble.
She will campaign in Hawaii, Sen. Barack Obama's home state, ahead of the state's caucuses.

Here are the highlights:

Police release ATM camera photos showing a second person of interest in the murder of UNC student body president Eve Carson.
The second person is a large, shadowy figure in the back seat of the SUV.
Police are enhancing the photo to learn more about the person.
The murder remains under investigation, with no arrests made so far.

Here are the highlights:

Sen. Hillary Clinton attacks Sen. Barack Obama, accusing him of caving to special interests.
Clinton claims Obama's nuclear bill was watered down, allowing the industry to influence its passage.
Obama's campaign responds, saying Clinton has taken more money from Washington lobbyists than any Republican.
Clinton must win in Texas and Ohio to stay in the race, according to some analysts.

Gerolsteiner drops sponsorship of German ProTour cycling team, citing change in marketing strategy.
Team has invested $12 million annually since 1998, with riders including Stefan Schumacher.
T-Mobile fires rider Lorenzo Bernucci after positive doping test for appetite suppressant sibutramine.
Bernucci claims he took medication without knowing it was added to the list of prohibited substances.

Here are the highlights:

US and Libya negotiate compensation for past acts of state-sponsored terrorism, including Lockerbie bombing.
Deal aims to resolve all outstanding claims in good faith and offer fair compensation to victims and families.
Agreement would cover 8 acts, including Pan Am 103 and 1986 Berlin disco bombing.
US and Libya aim to establish a fair compensation mechanism and normalize relations.

Here are the highlights:

Researchers capture aerial photos of uncontacted indigenous Brazilians in the Amazonian rainforest.
The tribe has had no contact with the outside world and lives in remote corners of the Amazon.
Over 100 uncontacted tribes remain worldwide, with half living in the Amazonian rainforest.
Illegal logging threatens their land and way of life, putting them in grave danger.

Here are the highlights:

Tropical Storm Arthur forms near Belize, the first named storm of the 2008 Atlantic season.
The storm is expected to move across the Yucatan and re-emerge in the Gulf of Mexico.
Tropical storm-force winds extend 260 miles from the center, with maximum sustained winds at 40 mph.
A tropical storm warning is issued for Belize and parts of Mexico, with heavy rain expected.

Imams in Iraq denounce US soldier's shooting of Quran, calling for severe punishment.
US military and President Bush apologize, but protests continue in Afghanistan and Iraq.
Iraqi Islamic Party demands "severest of punishments" for the American soldier.
US sergeant relieved of duty, officially reprimanded, and reassigned to the US.

Here are the highlights:

Many Americans criticize recent immigrants for not assimilating, forgetting their own ancestors' experiences.
Immigrants have been criticized throughout history for not adapting to American customs.
A new study finds that recent immigrants assimilate more rapidly than those of a century ago.
Assimilation happens, despite individual groups' varying levels of success.

Stuart MacGill announces retirement from international cricket after 10-year Test career.
He has taken 207 wickets at an average of 28.28 over 43 Test matches.
MacGill made his Test debut against South Africa 10 years ago.
He will retire after the ongoing second Test against West Indies.

Indonesian businessman Tung Desem Waringin dropped 100 million rupiah from an airplane to promote his new book.
Cash notes were scattered over a soccer field in Serang, with people rushing to grab the money.
Giddy schoolchildren jumped up and down, holding up notes they picked up.
The stunt was to promote Waringin's book "Marketing Revolution".

Here are the highlights:

A woman found her husband dead from an accidental overdose of drugs received from an online pharmacy.
The drugs were sent without a doctor's visit, and the husband had become addicted.
The DEA has seized over $39 million in cash and assets from online drug investigations.
A CNN investigation shows it's easy to purchase prescription drugs online without a legitimate prescription.

Sen. Obama says he'd send US forces into Pakistan to root out terrorists without approval.
Sen. Clinton criticizes Obama's stance, saying it could destabilize Pakistan's government.
Sen. Dodd warns that losing Pakistan's support could lead to an Islamic fundamentalist state.
Sen. Biden notes that Obama's policy is already US policy, citing four years of precedent.

Here are the highlights:

A soldier's father posts YouTube video showing poor conditions in Fort Bragg barracks.
Building has mold, rust, and sewage issues, with soldiers living in unsanitary conditions.
Army Vice Chief of Staff Gen. Dick Cody promises action to address the problems.
Fort Bragg officials acknowledge serious issues, citing outdated buildings and construction delays.

Here are the highlights:

EPA imposes new restrictions on rat poisons to reduce accidental exposure to children and wildlife.
Only farmers, livestock owners, and certified rodent control employees can buy rat poison in bulk.
New rules require rat poisons to be kept in bait stations above ground and in certified containers.
Loose bait and four hazardous pesticides will no longer be sold for personal use.

Suspected Islamic insurgents fired mortar rounds at Somalia's transitional president's plane, but no one was harmed.
The attack occurred as the plane was about to take off from Mogadishu's airport on Sunday.
Al-Shaabab, an Islamic militia, is trying to seize control of Somalia and has been linked to al Qaeda.
The president has survived two assassination attempts, including a car bombing in 2006.

Here are the highlights:

22 people killed in three states over the weekend, including an Oklahoma mother who died with her child.
Severe storms brought winds of up to 175mph, causing destruction in Oklahoma, Missouri, and Georgia.
Tornadoes touched down in Oklahoma, Missouri, and Arkansas, with 150 injured and unknown missing in Oklahoma.
President Bush pledged federal support, declaring a state of emergency in affected areas.

Here are the highlights:

Engine fell from wing during takeoff from Cape Town, South Africa, causing panic among passengers.
Pilot flew plane slowly to emergency landing, dumping fuel to reduce weight.
No one was injured, but passengers were left shaken by the incident.
Engine had undergone major overhaul in 2005 and had flown only 3,806 hours since then.

Here are the highlights:

The Tennessee Valley Authority's power grid is vulnerable to cyber attacks, according to a new report.
The agency has not implemented adequate security practices, leaving systems open to disruption.
A skilled hacker could cause a blackout by exploiting vulnerabilities in the system.
The GAO recommends 73 steps to correct the security issues.

Here are the highlights:

MREs provided nutritious and compact meals for troops, sparking memories good and bad.
Michael Reimers recalled eating C rations in the 1980s, making a birthday cake with hot chocolate mix and grape jelly.
Ronald Mervyn enjoyed MREs, liking chicken ala king, dehydrated potatoes, and chocolate chip cookies.
Steven Carrigan shared his experiences eating MREs in the field, often adding Tabasco sauce to spice them up.

Arsenal thrash Derby 6-2 with Emmanuel Adebayor scoring a hat-trick.
Robin van Persie and Nicklas Bendtner also score for the Gunners.
Derby's Jay McEveley and Robert Earnshaw score consolation goals.
Arsenal secure third place in the Premier League table.

Here are the highlights:

220 square miles of ice collapsed in Antarctica, with a 5,282 square mile shelf "hanging by a thread".
Scientists blame global warming for the collapse, which is expected to continue.
The Wilkins ice shelf, seven times the size of Manhattan, is at risk of breaking apart.
The collapse could have significant impacts on the surrounding ecosystem and global climate.

Here are the highlights:

A 55-year-old woman died after being hit by a 75-80 pound spotted eagle ray in the Florida Keys.
The ray leaped from the water, causing multiple skull fractures and direct brain injury.
The woman, Judy Kay Zagorski, was on a boat with family and friends when the accident occurred.
The incident is considered extremely rare, with experts saying rays rarely collide with objects.

Maria Sharapova crashes out of French Open with a 6-7 7-6 6-2 loss to Dinara Safina.
Safina saves match point to win and advances to the quarterfinals.
Sharapova leads 5-2 in the second set, but unravels to lose the final four games.
Safina's victory marks her second upset of Sharapova at the French Open.

Villagers in Gudda, India, have been transformed by solar power, bringing light to their homes and daily lives.
Solar panels on rooftops charge batteries, powering lamps and lights for the first time.
Residents, including children, can now study and play at night, changing their daily routine.
Villagers credit the Barefoot College, which trained them to install and maintain the solar systems.

Here are the highlights:

Tom Cruise discusses his beliefs in Scientology in a 2004 video.
He says it's a privilege to be a Scientologist and is dedicated to helping others.
Cruise emphasizes the religion's humanitarian work and its ability to improve conditions.
He finds peace in Scientology and believes it helps him see the world clearly.

Here are the highlights:

Sen. Barack Obama becomes first African-American to head a major party's presidential ticket.
He secures Democratic nomination, exceeding 2,118 delegate threshold.
Obama praises Sen. Hillary Clinton's campaign, congratulates her on her efforts.
He turns focus to general election, criticizes John McCain's presidential campaign.

A panel separated from a Boeing 757's wing during a US Airways flight from Orlando to Philadelphia.
The incident occurred over Maryland, and the aircraft landed safely in Philadelphia.
None of the 174 passengers or six crew members were injured in the incident.
The panel has not been located, but investigators are using a computer program to track its whereabouts.

Here are the highlights:

Joran van der Sloot says he didn't lose sleep over Natalee Holloway's death.
He told a friend he was with her on an Aruban beach when she died.
Friend's body was dumped in the ocean, van der Sloot said.
Aruban prosecutor reopens investigation after video evidence emerges.

Here are the highlights:

The US has restored Fulbright scholarships to seven Gaza-based students after rescinding them due to travel restrictions.
The decision was reversed after Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice expressed outrage over the initial decision.
The US is working with Israeli authorities to obtain exit permits for the students to study at American universities.
The students must be interviewed by Israeli authorities before receiving visas to the United States.

Here are the highlights:

16 Buddhist monks arrested in Tibet for alleged involvement in bombings.
Suspects claimed to have been influenced by foreign radio and separatist propaganda.
Dalai Lama denies advocating violence or independence for Tibet.
Violence in Tibet resulted in 18 deaths and widespread destruction.

Here are the highlights:

Workers using blowtorches accidentally started a fire at Universal Studios in Los Angeles on Sunday.
The fire destroyed several movie sets, including the King Kong exhibit, and damaged a video vault.
Two firefighters were injured by an exploding pressurized cylinder, and eight others were hurt battling the blaze.
The fire destroyed an area called New York street, including movie set-style buildings designed to look like the cityscape of New York City.

Here are the highlights:

A small, shiny cup passed down from John Webber's grandfather sold for $100,000 at auction.
The ancient Persian gold cup dates back to the 3rd or 4th century B.C.
The cup features the double-faced Roman god Janus, god of gates and doors.
Experts analyzed the cup's gold sample to determine its age, concluding it's Archaemenid gold.

Here are the highlights:

Hello Kitty, the moon-faced cat, is a global phenomenon with over 50,000 products.
She's responsible for over half of Sanrio's $1 billion annual turnover.
Sanrio's CEO Shintaro Tsuji attributes Hello Kitty's success to her role in social communication.
He emphasizes the importance of creating products that bring joy and thoughtfulness to others.

Here are the highlights:

U.S. President George Bush criticizes Zimbabwe's government for intimidation of opposition figures.
Leading opposition figure Artur Mutambara arrested for criticizing President Robert Mugabe.
Mutambara charged with contempt of court and publishing falsehoods for opinion piece.
Bush urges international organizations to monitor Zimbabwe's election and human rights.

Here are the highlights:

A massive blast targeting the Danish Embassy in Pakistan killed at least six people and wounded 18.
The blast left a four-foot deep crater in the road and damaged the embassy's front wall and gate.
Danish Foreign Minister Per Stig Moeller condemned the attack, calling it "terrible" and "completely unacceptable".
The explosion was the first deadly attack in Islamabad since a bomb hit an Italian restaurant in March.

Sen. Edward Kennedy's brain tumor removal surgery was successful, with no permanent damage expected.
The 76-year-old senator was awake during the 3.5-hour procedure at Duke University Medical Center.
He is expected to undergo radiation and chemotherapy at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston.
Kennedy expressed satisfaction, saying he "feels like a million bucks" after the surgery.

Here are the highlights:

Retired Adm. William Fallon resigned as Central Command leader, citing concerns over chain of command.
He denied being forced out over opposition to a possible war with Iran.
Fallon believes President Bush doesn't want a war with Iran, but wants dialogue and firm stance.
He supports retaining General Petraeus and continuing to work with Iraqis to bring stability and security.

Here are the highlights:

Sen. Hillary Clinton to suspend presidential campaign and support Sen. Obama and party unity.
Clinton will make announcement in Washington, D.C. and thank supporters.
Sen. Obama addresses AIPAC, praises Clinton, and says he's "very proud" to have competed against her.
Clinton lavishes praise on Obama, saying he ran an "extraordinary race".

Here are the highlights:

U.S. Navy ships leave Myanmar coast after junta refused to allow aid delivery for three weeks.
Ships will sail away on Thursday, leaving only heavy lift aircraft in Thailand.
Cyclone Nargis killed over 77,000 people and displaced 500,000 to 600,000 others.
U.S. and international aid efforts hampered by Myanmar's restrictive access to affected areas.

Hyundai Chairman Chung Mong-koo escapes prison sentence for embezzlement with suspended five-year term.
He was originally sentenced to three years in prison for embezzling $106 million.
Chung was accused of funneling company funds into a slush fund for personal gain.
He will instead serve community service and has already spent two months in jail.

Here are the highlights:

The remains of two US contractors kidnapped in Iraq have been found, FBI officials announced.
Four US soldiers died in a roadside bombing in Baghdad, bringing the American toll to 4,000 deaths.
President Bush vowed to ensure the sacrifice of US troops and civilians was not in vain.
At least 35 Iraqis died in violence, including suicide bombings and mortar fire, on Sunday.

Here are the highlights:

A small, shiny cup passed down from a junk dealer's grandson is an ancient Persian artifact.
The 5½-inch gold cup dates back to the third or fourth century B.C. and sold for $100,000.
The cup features the double-faced Roman god Janus and is adorned with braided hair and snake ornaments.
Experts analyzed the cup's gold sample, concluding it is consistent with Archaemenid gold and goldsmithing.

Here are the highlights:

Sara Jane Olson, former Symbionese Liberation Army member, rearrested after clerical error released her early.
She will serve full sentence at Central California Women's Facility in Chowchilla.
Error occurred due to miscalculation of her release date, officials said.
Investigation underway to determine how mistake happened.

Artist Robert West's grandfather was a Pullman Porter, inspiring his train paintings.
West's passion for trains began with childhood visits to his grandfather's work at the train station.
Trains symbolize hope, freedom, and power in African-American history, according to West.
West's paintings depict historical scenes and have won several national and regional awards.

President Bush says missile defense system in Eastern Europe poses no threat to Russia, aimed at anti-ballistic missiles.
Ukraine's President Viktor Yushchenko wants his country to start NATO membership process, citing sovereign right.
Bush denies easing off on membership plans for Ukraine and Georgia if Russia acquiesces on missile shield.
Russia and some European countries express concerns over the system's potential use for offensive purposes.

Spanish police arrest two Moroccan men suspected of having links to Islamic terrorism.
One suspect, Ali Aarass, linked to 2003 Casablanca bombings that killed 45 people.
Mohamed El Bay wanted for alleged involvement in terrorist network in Morocco.
Police seize documentation and weapons during searches of suspects' homes in Melilla.

Rev. Jeremiah Wright defends himself against attacks, saying the black church was targeted in 2008 presidential campaign.
He clarifies his remarks, saying he was quoting the ambassador from Iraq and following biblical principles.
Wright says his sermons were taken out of context and the black church is often "invisible to the dominant culture".
He emphasizes the importance of reconciliation, saying it means embracing individual histories and rejecting superiority and prejudice.

Human error caused Tuesday's massive power outage in Florida, says Florida Power and Light President Armando Olivera.
A field engineer disabled two levels of relay protection without authorization at a substation in west Miami.
The fault caused an outage affecting 26 transmission lines, 38 substations, and 3 million people.
The employee has been suspended with pay as the investigation continues.

Zimbabwe's capital Harare quiet as polls close in presidential election, with results expected Sunday.
Opposition party alleges widespread irregularities and plans to release own results.
Government denies allegations, claims elections will be "free and fair".
Voter turnout high, but irregularities reported, including dead voters on the rolls.

Here are the highlights:

Netherlands rejects asylum plea of gay Iranian teenager Mehdi Kazemi, 19, fearing persecution in Iran.
Britain's Home Office previously rejected his asylum request, citing lack of evidence of persecution.
Kazemi's last appeal was rejected by the Council of State, citing the Dublin Regulation.
He may be deported to Britain and then potentially to Iran, sparking outrage from gay rights activists.

Here are the highlights:

A 73-year-old man, Josef Fritzl, held his daughter captive for 24 years in a basement in Austria.
The dungeon, 50-60 meters square, has a sleeping quarters, kitchen, and bathroom, all very dark and damp.
The conditions were "dire" with little food and clothing, and the family had never seen the light of day.
Police found the family after Fritzl gave them the electronic combination to the basement.

Here are the highlights:

Samantha Schroeder's 19-year-old son, John, is deploying to Iraq as a Marine, citing duty to his country.
She worries about his safety, recalling his words: "I owe this to my country."
Angela Fritz, a military wife, describes the pain of having her husband away, hiding her true feelings.
Katherine Shigekane's husband has been deployed four times, affecting their family life, but they appreciate time together.

Here are the highlights:

Videos of London transit bombings shown in court, depicting chaos and horrified reactions.
Four bombs detonated on underground trains and a bus, killing 52 people and injuring 900.
Bombers' videos show them practicing moves in various locations before the attacks.
Security cameras captured images of the bombers at blast locations.

Tony Rezko convicted of money laundering, fraud, and bribery charges by federal jury.
Rezko's links to Barack Obama's campaign sparked controversy in the presidential election.
Obama accepted contributions from Rezko and bought land from him, calling it a mistake.
Obama donated $80,000 in linked campaign contributions to charity.

Here are the highlights:

Mychal Bell, a black teenager, was released from custody after a judge set his bail at $45,000.
Bell was the last of the "Jena 6" to be released, after an estimated 15,000 protested his case.
LaSalle Parish District Attorney Reed Walters will not appeal a higher court's decision moving Bell's case to juvenile court.
Bell's release comes after weeks of protests and controversy over racial disparities in the justice system.

Sudan's government mobilized to plan, commit, and cover up crimes in Darfur, says International Criminal Court prosecutor.
2.5 million people forced from their homes in Darfur, UN estimates.
ICC indicts two men for war crimes and crimes against humanity in Darfur.
Sudanese government has taken no steps to arrest the indicted men.

Here are the highlights:

High school valedictorian Arthur Mkoyan's plans to study medicine in California are being derailed.
Immigration officials plan to deport him and his family to Armenia in 10 days.
Mkoyan's family fled Armenia 16 years ago due to corruption and threats.
He has a 4.0 GPA, but his academic achievements haven't helped his deportation case.

Here are the highlights:

The Senate passed a $555 billion government spending bill with billions for Iraq war funding.
The bill also includes $30 billion for troops in Afghanistan and thousands of earmarks.
President Bush will sign the bill if the Iraq funding is included, White House officials say.
The bill now goes back to the House for approval in its revised form.

Jeannie Longo-Ciprelli, a French cyclist, was considered the greatest female cyclist of her generation.
She won four world championships and two Tours de France, but struggled at the Olympics.
Longo-Ciprelli finally won Olympic gold in Atlanta in 1996, after four previous disappointments.
She won bronze in the time trial at the 2000 Sydney Olympics at age 41.

Russian arms dealer Viktor Bout arrested in Thailand with associate Andrew Smulian.
Accused of conspiracy to provide surface-to-air missiles to Colombian rebels.
Operation involved law enforcement agencies from at least five countries.
Bout and Smulian face up to 15 years in prison if convicted.

Here are the highlights:

Colombian artist Doris Salcedo created a mysterious crack in the Tate Modern's Turbine Hall floor.
The 167-meter-long crack, titled "Shibboleth," represents the gap between white Europeans and the rest of humanity.
Salcedo refused to reveal how she created the crack, saying the meaning is more important than the making.
The installation will be removed next April by filling in the crack, leaving a scar as a memory of the work.

Here are the highlights:

Armenian President Robert Kocharian declares state of emergency after clashes between police and protesters.
Thousands of demonstrators camped in Freedom Square for 10 days claim presidential election was rigged.
Police use force to clear square, with reports of injuries and arrests.
State of emergency could last until March 20, but government hopes it will be lifted sooner.

France agrees to send troops to eastern Afghanistan to support NATO's mission.
Canada extends its commitment of 2,500 troops until 2011, pending NATO troop contributions.
NATO leaders discuss membership for Georgia and Ukraine, with a general consensus on "when" rather than "if".
Macedonia's bid for membership is stalled due to Greece's objections over the name issue.

Here are the highlights:

Iraqi imam Sheikh Jalal al-Din Ali al-Saghir urges abolition of militias and denounces corruption in Baghdad's Sadr City.
He blames followers of anti-American cleric Muqtada al-Sadr for corruption and violence.
Al-Saghir praises Iraqi security forces' efforts in Basra and calls for disarmament of all armed groups.
He urges politicians to respect the rule of law and ensure fair provincial elections.

Heath Ledger, 28, died from accidental overdose of six medications in a New York apartment.
Autopsy report lists oxycodone, hydrocodone, diazepam, temazepam, alprazolam, and doxylamine as cause of death.
Federal drug investigators take over inquiry into Ledger's death to determine if drugs were prescribed legally.
Two doctors, one in California and one in Texas, are being investigated.

Here are the highlights:

Twenty-four people, including 8 children, injured in Harlem apartment building explosion.
Four children, including an infant, have burn injuries, with one in critical condition.
Firefighters responded to the scene, with one injured and in stable condition.
Cause of the explosion appears to be a gas leak, investigation ongoing.

ZipRealty is a full-service real estate brokerage firm using technology and agents for home buying and selling.
Its website provides comprehensive home listings data and market information.
Proprietary system reduces costs, passing savings to consumers.
Operates in 34 areas across 19 states and DC with over 2,000 agents.

Here are the highlights:

US health officials find contaminant in Baxter Healthcare's blood-thinner drug heparin linked to 12 deaths.
Contaminant, not heparin, found in some active pharmaceutical ingredients, reacts like heparin in tests.
Cause of contamination unclear, but not linked to Baxter's US or Chinese plants.
FDA to release guidelines for screening contaminant, similar to pet food recall issue in China.

Here are the highlights:

Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton met privately at Sen. Dianne Feinstein's home.
The meeting was positive and lasted about an hour, with no details disclosed.
Obama campaign director Robert Gibbs said they discussed party unity and November's election.
Clinton plans to endorse Obama and suspend her campaign within days.

Here are the highlights:

Annmarie Ausnes, 55, needed a kidney transplant due to polycystic kidney disease.
Sandra Andersen, a Starbucks barista, donated a kidney to Ausnes.
Andersen didn't know Ausnes' name, but felt compelled to test as a match.
The transplant was successful, and Ausnes is recovering well.

Here are the highlights:

English football fans face spiraling costs and visa woes for Moscow's Champions League final.
Up to 50,000 fans expected to travel, defying expensive flights and accommodation shortages.
Russian Embassy criticizes UK's visa requirements, but may lift some restrictions for ticket holders.
Fans warned of high costs, visa complications, and potential trouble in Moscow.

Here are the highlights:

A Vermont woman can visit her 6-year-old daughter in Virginia despite the state not recognizing same-sex unions.
The Virginia Supreme Court ruled that Vermont's civil union jurisdiction prevails in custody disputes.
The case is the first conflict between two state courts over same-sex unions.
Jenkins can visit her daughter, Isabella, in Virginia after a Vermont court granted visitation rights.

Air Force Chief of Staff Gen. Michael Moseley and Secretary Michael Wynne resign over nuclear weapons handling incidents.
B-52 bomber flew across US with nuclear weapons on board, crew unaware.

Here are the highlights:

Steve Irwin, the "Crocodile Hunter," died a year ago after a stingray barb to the chest.

A woman was forced to remove her nipple rings with pliers at a Texas airport.

Indonesia grounds Adam Air flights due to failure to meet quality standards.

Arthur C. Clarke, author of "2001: A Space Odyssey," dies at 90.

Tariq Aziz's trial for 1992 executions delayed due to co-defendant's illness.

Eos Airlines, an all-business-class carrier, declares bankruptcy and ceases operations due to financial issues.

Here are the highlights:

Josef Fritzl kept his daughter imprisoned for 24 years in an underground cellar with three of their children.

Fritzl's daughter, Elisabeth, was repeatedly raped and fathered seven children, six of whom survived.
The family was reunited, and the children are adjusting to sunlight and a daily routine.

An Indian woman accused of witchcraft was tied to a tree and beaten by a mob.

Croatia won 1-0 against Austria in their opening Group B match in Vienna.

Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff bypasses environmental laws to build 360 miles of border fence.

Viktor Bout charged with conspiring to sell weapons to Colombian rebel group FARC to kill Americans.

NBA planning to create up to five European franchises to compete for the NBA Championship.

• DEFCONOMY FIVE: Housing market collapse, massive foreclosures, and bank write-downs; odds of happening: extremely likely.
• DEFCONOMY ONE: Full economic meltdown, complete failure of financial system; odds of happening: not likely.

The family is slowly adapting to modern life, with therapy helping them cope with their complex relationships.

Here are the highlights:

An unexploded German flying bomb from WWII was found on a construction site in London's Canary Wharf.
Bomb disposal experts were called to make the V1 missile safe.
The area was cordoned off, with roads closed and the building site evacuated.
Thousands of V1s were fired at London during the war, with the docks a prime target.

Here are the highlights:

Zimbabwe's President Robert Mugabe warns war veterans will take up arms to prevent opposition takeover.
Mugabe claims opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai would turn country back to white control.
Tsvangirai arrested twice, campaign buses impounded, as Mugabe's party tightens grip.
Mugabe accuses MDC of being a party for whites, funded by the British.

Iowa Army National Guard's 1st Battalion, 133rd Infantry returns home from 17-month deployment in Iraq.
Over 600 soldiers march onto the field at Riverfront Stadium in Waterloo, Iowa.
Two soldiers were killed in action by roadside bombs during their deployment.
Family members and soldiers reunite in emotional ceremony.

Graeme Le Saux played over 400 matches, winning a Premier League title and 36 international caps.
He faced homophobic abuse due to false rumors about his sexuality, causing isolation and damage to his career.
Robbie Fowler's public humiliation in 1993 was a turning point, highlighting the seriousness of the issue.
Le Saux calls for the sport to be more inclusive and representative, with an end to prejudice and homophobia.

Nepal's new government converts deposed king's palace into a museum.
National flag unfurls at the palace, symbolizing the end of monarchy.
Ex-King Gyanendra leaves palace, will live as a civilian in a summer palace.
Nepal declares itself a republic after 239 years of royal rule.

Suspected arms dealer Monzer al Kassar extradited from Spain to US to face weapons conspiracy charges.
Kassar accused of selling weapons to Colombian guerrillas, including surface-to-air missile systems and machine guns.
He was arrested in Madrid in an undercover operation and had been wanted for decades.
Kassar faces life in prison if convicted.

Cindy McCain has a master's degree in special education and owns part of her father's business.
She's a tall, striking blonde with blue eyes, prioritizing charity work and international involvement.
Michelle Obama was raised in a working-class family, educated at Princeton and Harvard Law School.
She has a blunt style, wry sense of humor, and will make history as the first African-American first lady.

Queen Elizabeth celebrates her 82nd birthday with a parade and military ceremony, "Trooping the Color", in London.
The ceremony is open to the public and features a fly-past by the Royal Air Force.
The queen inspects the troops, who march past her in a carriage ride back to the palace.
The ceremony dates back to a tradition where colors were carried down the ranks for soldiers to recognize.

Floodwaters inundated Iowa City and the University of Iowa arts campus, forcing evacuations and closing classes.
The Iowa River crested at 31.5 feet, with water expected to remain at that level until Monday.
The university's fine arts building and art museum were severely damaged, with some art saved by being shipped out of state.
At least 500 to 600 homes were ordered to evacuate, with many more affected by voluntary orders.

Here are the highlights:

Mexican troops arrive in Juarez to quell drug-related violence that's killed 200 people since January.
Two rival drug cartels clashed in the city, targeting police and government officials.
The majority of the 2,000 troops will be based in the city to restore order.
No uninvolved civilians have been injured in the violence.

FEMA gave away $85 million in hurricane relief supplies, blaming Louisiana officials for turning down stockpiles.
FEMA director defends decision, saying states requested items like refrigerators, stoves, and diapers.
Louisiana officials say they were unaware of the available supplies and still need them.
FEMA's chief spokesman initially declined an on-camera interview, calling the story "not news".

Here are the highlights:

Medical examinations of 11 former detainees reveal clear physical and psychological evidence of torture and abuse.
Torture methods included beatings, electric shock, sleep deprivation, sexual humiliation, and sodomy.
Detainees were never charged with crimes and were released without explanation.
Report calls for a formal apology, investigation, and accountability for those involved in torture.

Here are the highlights:

A truce between Israel and Hamas will take effect Thursday and last six months.
Hamas officials announced the agreement, while Israeli officials stopped short of confirming.
Israel will reopen some border crossing terminals and Egypt has been mediating the talks.
The truce is meant to bring calm and allow for the release of Cpl. Gilad Shalit.

Here are the highlights:

Sen. Barack Obama proposes spending $60 billion on infrastructure and $150 billion on alternative energy.
He plans to pay for it by ending the Iraq war, reducing waste, and taxing polluters.
Obama rejects protectionist trade policies, saying they won't help America compete globally.
He promises a competitiveness agenda built on education, energy, innovation, and infrastructure.

Here are the highlights:

Lubos Michel will referee the Champions League final between Manchester United and Chelsea in Moscow.
Michel has refereed major tournaments, including Euro 2004 and the 2006 World Cup.
Manchester police have traveled to Moscow to help prevent fan violence and advise local authorities.
The British embassy in Moscow will stay open extra hours to support English fans.

Kimi Raikkonen lambasts Lewis Hamilton for pit-lane accident at Canadian Grand Prix.
Hamilton's McLaren rammed into Raikkonen's Ferrari at a red light, ending both drivers' races.
Raikkonen says Hamilton's mistake ruined his chance of winning, not angry but unhappy.
Hamilton apologizes, citing a bad pit stop and seeing the red light too late.

Here are the highlights:

British Foreign Office warns nationals of increased threat of terrorist attacks in the United Arab Emirates.
Travelers and expatriates urged to be vigilant, especially in public places.
Terrorists may target residential compounds, military, oil, transport, and aviation interests.
Over 1 million British visitors traveled to the UAE in 2006, with 100,000 nationals living there.

Al Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden to address the West in a new message, according to a banner ad.
The message is titled "The reasons of the struggle in the 60th anniversary of the Israeli Occupation".
It is unclear whether the message will be audio or video and when it will be posted.
Bin Laden's last message criticized Iraq and European countries for siding with the US.

Residents of Gladstone, Illinois, work with National Guard to create a makeshift levee against rising floodwaters.
Rising waters breached a 300-foot area of a levee near Gulf Port, Illinois, before 5 a.m.
Illinois Gov. Rod Blagojevich called up 1,100 National Guard members to assist in sandbagging efforts.
Floodwaters have submerged homes and created rivers where crop fields once stood in Gladstone.

Here are the highlights:

World-renowned security expert Gavin de Becker says "the gift of fear" is a warning sign that can prevent most crimes before they happen.
Kelly ignored her intuition when a man offered to help her with her groceries, and a rapist entered her home.
Nicole's intuition warned her of something odd in her apartment, but she ignored it until she caught an intruder on camera.
Gavin says listening to intuition can stop what's almost fate, and ignoring it can lead to dangerous consequences.

Here are the highlights:

• Woman discovers hospital kept her stillborn son's body in a jar for four years.
• She was told he was cremated, but only recently learned the truth.
• Mother is taking legal action against the hospital for medical negligence.
• She is organizing a naming ceremony and funeral for her stillborn son.

Here are the highlights:

Andre Berto won the vacant WBC welterweight title by halting Miguel Rodriguez in the seventh round.
Dane Mikkel Kessler knocked out Dimitri Sartison in the 12th round to become WBA supermiddle champion.
Amir Khan defended his Commonwealth lightweight title with a fifth-round stoppage of Michael Gomez.
Khan was floored in the second round but recovered to win with a powerful body shot.

Michelle Obama refining her message for the fall campaign, focusing on personal stories and family.
She will emphasize her humble upbringing on Chicago's South Side and her family's values.
Critics have labeled her as too angry, negative, and sarcastic, but she's trying to connect with voters on a personal level.
She will appear on "The View" and grace the cover of Us Weekly, showcasing her more personal side.

Brazilian coach Zico leaves Fenerbahce after failing to agree on new contract terms.
He guided the team to a league and Super Cup double in 2007.
Zico sought a new annual salary of $4.9 million, up from $2.9 million.
Luis Aragones, current Spain coach, is reportedly lined up as a replacement.

Gunman opens fire at Westroads Mall in Omaha, Nebraska, killing 8 people.
Witnesses call 911, describing rapid bursts of gunfire and chaos.
Police respond to the scene, finding the shooter dead with an AK-47 rifle.
Two employees remain hospitalized, one with critical injuries.

Jane McGrath, wife of Glenn McGrath, dies at 42 after long battle with cancer.
Australian cricketers will wear pink ribbons and pink bat grips to honor her.
The McGraths founded the McGrath Foundation to raise money for breast cancer research.
Jane was praised for her courage and legacy in the fight against breast cancer.

Here are the highlights:

An Alabama man, Gabe Watson, charged in wife's death on honeymoon scuba diving trip in Australia.
Australian coroner rules there's enough evidence to put Watson on trial for Tina Watson's 2003 drowning.
Coroner cites inconsistencies in Watson's statements and a possible motive for insurance money.
Watson's wife was a novice diver, while he was an experienced diver on their honeymoon trip.

Here are the highlights:

Nepalese authorities detain at least 650 Tibetan exiles protesting against China's policies in Nepal.
Police arrest and charge three Tibetan community leaders with organizing the protest.
Protesters were dragged to police stations across Kathmandu, with 900 detained in total.
Authorities charge the leaders for damaging diplomatic relations between Nepal and China.

Here are the highlights:

Betty Johnson Neumar, 76, charged with hiring hitman to kill her husband Harold Gentry in 1986.
She is also suspected of poisoning her previous husbands, including John Neumar Sr.
Her son wonders if she poisoned his father, who died from intestinal problems.
Authorities investigating deaths of her five husbands, including three uncharged cases.

Here are the highlights:

The Supreme Court ruled that child rapists cannot be given the death penalty.
The 5-4 decision stems from a Louisiana case involving Patrick Kennedy.
The ruling falls in line with other decisions on the death penalty, Justice Kennedy said.
The court deemed the death penalty for child rape would create a "perverse incentive" for rapists.

Female suicide bombers are increasingly deadly in Iraq, with 20 attacks so far in 2008.
The US Army has created "Daughters of Iraq" to train women to detect female bombers.
The program provides income to Iraqi women with few job opportunities and promotes social change.
Women will work at checkpoints, searching other females, a task forbidden to men under Iraqi cultural norms.

Here are the highlights:

Investigators focus on farms in Mexico and Florida to find source of salmonella outbreak linked to raw tomatoes.
Over 500 people in 32 states and DC have contracted the same strain of Salmonella Saintpaul since April.
Farms in Mexico and Florida will be inspected, as well as pathways from those farms, to determine contamination source.
At least 53 people have been hospitalized, with no deaths officially attributed to the outbreak.

Congress overrides President Bush's veto of $300 billion farm bill for second time.
Senate votes 80-14, House votes 317-109 to override veto.
Bill provides $300 billion in spending, including $40 billion in farm subsidies and $20 billion in nutrition programs.
President Bush objects to bill's subsidies for the wealthy and budget gimmicks.

Here are the highlights:

Luke Russert discussed youth voting on CNN's "Larry King Live" after his father's death.
He was raised in a household where politics was always discussed at the dinner table.
Luke first voted in 2004 and felt it was a significant milestone.
He may pursue a career in journalism and political commentary.

Here are the highlights:

NASA's Mars Phoenix Lander successfully touched down near Mars' north pole on Sunday.
The landing site shows a pattern of brown polygons as far as the camera can see.
The Phoenix mission will analyze soils and permafrost for signs of past or present life.
The lander is equipped with a robotic arm to scoop up ice and dirt for analysis.

Pregnant soldier Spc. Megan Lynn Touma, 23, found dead in Fayetteville, North Carolina, motel room.
Body sent to Medical Examiner's office to determine cause of death.
Touma was 7 months pregnant and had served in Germany and New York before Fort Bragg.
Second pregnant service member to die in North Carolina in recent months.

Hamas defeated Fatah in Gaza, ending violence and imposing law and order.
Gaza is safer, but people are struggling with food, gas, and patience.
Israel has tightened its siege, restricting supplies and exports, affecting 70-80% of the population.
Life in Gaza has become a daily struggle to secure basic commodities.

Zimbabwe's opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai pulls out of runoff election, citing sham vote.
Torture victims back Tsvangirai's decision, citing brutal attacks by Mugabe's supporters.
At least 70 people killed in attacks since election, with many more injured.
Mugabe's government claims vote is "free and fair", despite international observer disputes.

Here are the highlights:

Four opposition activists and a mayor's wife killed in Zimbabwe ahead of presidential runoff.
US Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice accuses Mugabe of sponsoring violence and intimidation.
Opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai's secretary-general charged with treason and faces death penalty.
Zimbabwe's opposition party blames Mugabe's supporters for the killings and intimidation.

Here are the highlights:

Sen. Barack Obama won North Carolina, while Sen. Hillary Clinton won Indiana in the Democratic presidential primary.
Obama took 91% of the black vote in North Carolina and 36% of the white vote.
Clinton won 59% of the white vote in Indiana and 68% of the rural vote.
The race will likely continue to the next round of primaries, with 796 superdelegates to be decided.

Here are the highlights:

North Korea declares its nuclear program, shutting down Yongbyon reactor and removing fuel rods.
US lifts some sanctions, removes North Korea from terrorism sponsors list.
Deal lacks details on number of weapons, uranium enrichment, and nuclear secrets shared with Syria.
Verification process to be implemented, but Pyongyang's cooperation uncertain.

Here are the highlights:

The last of six Texas A&M University mariners missing in the Gulf of Mexico was found dead.
Five crewmates were rescued earlier, telling the Coast Guard they were forced off their sailboat after it capsized.
The sailboat, named Cynthia Woods, was heading to Veracruz, Mexico, for the annual Veracruz Regatta race.
The survivors were lifted to safety by a Coast Guard helicopter and taken to a medical center for treatment.

Here are the highlights:

Hillary Clinton returns to the Senate after a two-week vacation, ready to focus on her duties.
She plans to campaign for Democratic Senate candidates and work on key issues like healthcare and the economy.
Clinton says she's not thinking about a potential vice presidential role and is focused on the Senate.
She's set to meet with Barack Obama and key donors in Washington and Unity, New Hampshire.

Prince William helps US Coast Guard bust drug-smuggling boat carrying $80 million worth of cocaine.
The 50-foot speedboat was spotted by a Royal Navy helicopter in the Atlantic Ocean.
45 bales of cocaine weighing nearly a ton were found on board, with a minimum street value of $80 million.
The bust was made without violence, and the five men on the boat were detained.

Here are the highlights:

Senate Republicans blocked a Democratic proposal to tax oil companies' windfall profits due to rising energy prices.
The measure required 60 votes, but fell short with a 51-43 vote.
Six Republicans broke ranks to support the bill, while two Democrats voted against it.
The proposal aimed to place a 25% tax on oil companies and permit lawsuits against OPEC.

Five Europeans rescued after diving trip gone wrong in Indonesia's Komodo National Park.
Group of four divers spent two nights on deserted island, fighting off a Komodo dragon.
Rescuers found them Saturday morning, dehydrated but in good condition.
They were taken to hospital for examination after being rescued.

Here are the highlights:

The Bush administration has launched a covert operation in Iran to spy on nuclear facilities and undermine the government.
The operation involves US commandos and Iranian dissidents, with a budget of up to $400 million.
The goal is to prevent Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons before the Bush administration leaves office.
The operation has resulted in increased violence and chaos inside Iran, including attacks by Kurdish separatists.

President Bush signs $162 billion bill to fund wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.
Bill provides funding without restrictions, as requested by the White House.
New GI Bill expands education benefits for veterans who have served since 9/11.
Bill also includes disaster relief and unemployment benefits for affected Americans.

Here are the highlights:

Sen. Barack Obama defended his patriotism, saying his "deep and abiding love for this country" drives his presidential bid.
He vowed not to question others' patriotism, urging unity in the face of challenges.
Obama defined patriotism as a willingness to sacrifice, citing John McCain's service.
He condemned questioning of McCain's military record, calling it a "distraction" from key issues.

Bangladesh police detain over 18,000 people in 11 days, citing improved security ahead of December elections.
Human rights groups call the arrests politically motivated, targeting opposition party members.
Police deny political motivation, saying the crackdown aims to rid the country of criminals.
Arrests include hundreds of party members, journalists, and over 150 top politicians.

Here are the highlights:

About 220 Zimbabweans sought refuge at the US Embassy in Harare due to election-related violence.
Some refugees had bandaged wounds and were waiting outside the embassy for assistance.
MDC supporters claimed militia members supporting President Mugabe's party destroyed their homes or hunted them.
Violence has continued after the runoff, with reports of abductions and intimidation.

Here are the highlights:

Nicholas Troy Sheley, 28, suspected of bludgeoning 8 people to death, appears in court.
Charged with first-degree murder in one slaying, with additional charges pending.
Sheley, a methamphetamine addict, gave up without a fight when confronted by police.
He is being held on $1 million bail in an Illinois jail.

Here are the highlights:

eBay ordered to pay $63 million in damages to LVMH for selling fake luxury goods.
LVMH claimed eBay was negligent in preventing the sale of counterfeit products.
eBay plans to appeal the ruling, calling it an attempt to protect uncompetitive practices.
The court also barred eBay from advertising certain LVMH perfume and cosmetic brands.

Tens of thousands protest in Seoul against government's decision to import US beef deemed unsafe.
Protesters say the beef may contain mad cow disease, which can be transmitted to humans.
The government had previously banned US beef imports after a mad cow disease outbreak in 2003.
Protesters demand the government reconsider its decision and prioritize public health.

Here are the highlights:

Will Smith led a crowd of 46,664 in singing "Happy Birthday" to Nelson Mandela.
Mandela thanked the crowd, saying "Your voices carried across the water to inspire us in our prison cells."
Proceeds from the concert will go to the 46664 Campaign, which raises awareness about AIDS and promotes HIV-prevention.
The concert featured performances by Queen, Amy Winehouse, and over a dozen African artists.

Here are the highlights:

A mining company has found what may be the largest gold deposit ever in the British Isles.
The deposit is estimated to contain over 1 million ounces of gold, worth up to $300 million.
The find is located in Northern Ireland, near the village of Clontibret.
The company plans to conduct more drilling and feasibility studies before moving ahead.

Iraq's Sunni Arab party demands "severest of punishments" for US soldier who desecrated the Quran.
US soldier used Quran for target practice at Baghdad shooting range, causing outrage in Iraq.
US commander apologizes, reassigns soldier, but Iraqi Islamic Party wants more severe punishment.
Tribal leaders and residents protest, calling for punishment and withdrawal of US forces.

Here are the highlights:

President Cristina Fernandez defends grain export tax increase, calls on farmers to respect the law.
Fernandez urges Argentines to support her policies in a rally on Wednesday.
She offers to debate the tax increase in Congress, but her party controls both houses.
Farmers protest, saying higher taxes make it difficult to make a living.

Here are the highlights:

Three Americans rescued after five years in captivity in Colombian jungle appear in good health.
They were captured in 2003 when their plane crashed in a remote region of Colombia.
The men, Keith Stansell, Marc Gonsalves, and Thomas Howes, are US government contractors.
They will begin reuniting with their families, who are eager to see them after long ordeal.

Here are the highlights:

Ohio distributor recalls 6 million Chinese-made tire valve stems due to potential safety risk.
8,600 of the valves are defective, with the rubber part prone to cracking.
Underinflated tires can burst, leading to crashes, if not addressed.
Defect caused by improper mixing of rubber compound at manufacturer's facility.

Simon Mann, a British mercenary, sentenced to 34 years in prison for plotting a coup in Equatorial Guinea.
He confessed to trying to overthrow President Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo, but denied being the plot's leader.
Mann testified that Lebanese businessman Eli Calil was the mastermind behind the plot.
He claimed several governments, including Spain and the US, supported the coup.

Here are the highlights:

Eve Carson, 22, was shot multiple times, including in her head, according to her autopsy report.
She was abducted and shot by two men, Demario James Atwater and Lawrence Alvin Lovette.
Carson's autopsy report lists six gunshot wounds, with two possibly from the same bullet.
The suspects have been charged with first-degree murder and sexual assault.

Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim emerges from hiding with evidence of fabricated sodomy charges against him.
He rejects the charges and claims new evidence of government officials' involvement.
Anwar says he has proof of threats on his life, leading him to hide at the Turkish embassy.
He vows to challenge the attacks on every ground, including the new sodomy charges.

Here are the highlights:

The FDA orders "black box" label warnings for certain antibiotics due to tendon rupture and tendonitis risks.
Cipro, Levaquin, Avelox, Noroxin, and Floxin are among the affected drugs.
The FDA requires label warnings and medication guides for fluoroquinolone drugs.
Patients should stop taking antibiotics at first sign of tendon pain and contact their doctor.

Here are the highlights:

Sen. Hillary Clinton and Sen. Barack Obama share a kiss on the tarmac before a rally in New Hampshire.
They sit side-by-side on a plane to Manchester, chatting amiably about the plane and politics.
The pair holds hands and waves to the crowd at a rally in Unity, New Hampshire.
Hillary and Bill Clinton donate to Obama's campaign, a sign of their unity.

Here are the highlights:

17 babies in a Texas hospital received overdoses of blood thinner heparin, one died.
Corrective action was taken after the discovery of the overdoses.
Heparin is used to clean IVs and prevent blood clots, but was given in a more concentrated form.
Twelve babies remain stable, three have been discharged, and one is critical.

Here are the highlights:

Gina Gershon demands a retraction from Vanity Fair over alleged Clinton visit claims.
Actress calls article "irresponsible journalism" and "a lie" in a statement.
Vanity Fair denies suggesting any improper relationship between Clinton and Gershon.
Clinton calls Vanity Fair article a "hatchet job" and its author "sleazy" and "dishonest".

Thousands flee Paradise, California, as wildfires charge into the area, with 14,000 already evacuated.
More than half of the town's 26,000 residents have been told to leave their homes.
The fire has already torched 40 homes, with thousands more threatened.
Wind gusts of over 40 mph push the fire close to residential communities.

Nepal's lawmakers to vote Saturday to pick country's first president since becoming a republic.
No one party won a majority in April elections, unclear who will become president.
President's role is largely ceremonial, but will swear in new prime minister.
Three main parties negotiating over whom to name president, no consensus yet.

Argentine farmers plan next move after President Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner announces public works program funding.
Export tax on soybeans, wheat, corn, and sunflower seeds has sparked three-month standoff with farmers.
President Kirchner rejects demands to repeal tax, calling it "extortion".
Farmers suspend roadblocks, but some rural areas still block roads.

An Illinois man, Edward F. Bachner, charged with illegal possession of tetrodotoxin, a potentially deadly neurotoxin.
Bachner accepted a small amount of tetrodotoxin from an undercover federal official at his home.
Tetrodotoxin can cause paralysis and death in large doses, often linked to puffer fish consumption.
Bachner faces up to 10 years in prison if convicted.

Susan Atkins, a former Manson family member, is seeking compassionate release due to terminal illness.
California's director of adult prisons recommends against her release, citing advisory role.
Atkins was convicted of murdering actress Sharon Tate and four others in 1969.
The Board of Parole Hearings will consider her request during its July 15 meeting.

Hurricane Bertha forms in Atlantic Ocean, first hurricane of 2008 season.
Bertha strengthens into Category 3 hurricane with 120 mph winds.
Hurricane expected to weaken by Wednesday, turn northwest in 24-48 hours.
No landfall expected in US, Bermuda may be affected this weekend.

Here are the highlights:

Anonymous developers plan to sell software to unlock iPhone for use on non-AT&T networks worldwide.
The software allows iPhone to work on other carriers without disassembling the device.
Unlocking the iPhone takes about two minutes and requires no technical expertise.
The developers plan to sell the software once their online payment and customer service systems are ready.

Here are the highlights:

Susan Atkins, a former Charles Manson follower, denied compassionate release from prison due to terminal illness.
Atkins, 60, has brain cancer and has had a leg amputated, her attorney said.
She requested release in June, citing less than six months to live.
California Board of Parole Hearings denied the request.

Here are the highlights:

Hillary Clinton denies suggesting Obama's assassination, says her words were taken out of context.
Obama campaign accused of inflaming the situation and taking her words out of context.
Clinton acknowledges dwindling chances of winning nomination, says she'll stay in the race.
She vows to campaign for Obama if he wins nomination and unify the Democratic Party.

North Korea destroys nuclear reactor's cooling tower, a significant step towards dismantling its nuclear program.
Leader Kim Jong Il may be willing to drop nuclear weapons for better relations with the US.
Experts say North Korea's economic struggles and desire for foreign investment may be driving its cooperation.
North Korea's declaration of its nuclear program and reactor disablement could lead to economic and energy assistance.

Zimbabwe introduces $100 billion banknotes to ease cash shortages and high inflation.
New notes are equal to one US dollar, but can't buy a loaf of bread.
Economist says cash shortages will persist unless inflation is addressed through increased production.
Zimbabwe's official inflation rate is 2.2 million percent.

Misha Di Bono drives a rolling billboard for Jobing.com, earning $500/month and free gas.
Jobing.com's 60% of employees drive wrapped cars, with a waiting list for the program.
Yahoo offers commuting benefits like free movie tickets and massages for carpoolers and bike commuters.
Companies are trying to ease the pain at the pump with programs like reduced workweeks and carpools.

Radovan Karadzic, former Bosnian Serb leader, arrested after decade-long hunt.
US diplomat calls arrest "historic day" and "equivalent of catching Europe's Osama bin Laden".
Karadzic is accused of leading worst acts of brutality in Europe since World War II.
Arrest brings Serbia closer to joining the EU, says EU foreign affairs chief.

Here are the highlights:

Michael Essien agrees to a five-year contract with Chelsea, tying him to the club until 2013.
The Ghanaian midfielder has made 143 appearances and scored 14 goals for the team.
New Chelsea coach Luiz Felipe Scolari praised Essien, calling him one of the best midfield players in the world.
Essien is pleased to extend his career with Chelsea, feeling positive about the season ahead.

Marius Kloppers born in South Africa on August 26, 1962.
He earned degrees from University of Pretoria and Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Kloppers joined Billiton Group in 1993 and played key role in merger with BHP.
He has been CEO of BHP Billiton since October 2007.

Here are the highlights:

Barack Obama emphasized challenges women in his family overcame at a fundraiser with Hillary Clinton.
He recounted his mother's struggles as a single mom and his grandmother's glass ceiling experience.
Obama urged equal pay for women, paid leave, and sick leave to support working mothers.
He unveiled a plan to increase women's economic security with tax credits and minimum wage increase.

Here are the highlights:

Sen. Barack Obama meets with Iraqi Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki to discuss troop withdrawals.
Obama proposes withdrawing US combat troops from Iraq within 16 months.
Iraqi government wants a "general time horizon" for troop withdrawals, not a specific date.
Obama and al-Maliki agree on a "vision" for a US troop withdrawal.

Nepal lawmakers to vote for first president since becoming a republic.
No party won a majority, making the outcome unclear.
President's role is largely ceremonial, but will swear in new PM.
Three main parties negotiate over who will hold the position.

Here are the highlights:

President Bush defends attending Beijing Olympics opening ceremony, citing not boycotting as an affront to Chinese people.
He will raise concerns on religious freedom and human rights with Chinese President Hu Jintao.
Bush assures Japan's Prime Minister Fukuda that US will not abandon efforts to resolve North Korea's abduction issue.
Bush to focus on free trade and open markets at G-8 summit, downplaying economic solutions.

Here are the highlights:

Old cars can have hidden problems, even with a visual inspection or test drive.
A vehicle history report can reveal a car's past, including accidents and damage.
Look for records of multiple garages, which may indicate neglect or abuse.
Check the report's description to ensure it matches the car you're buying.

Here are the highlights:

President George W. Bush called Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh to push nuclear partnership deal.
Deal would provide India with US nuclear fuel and technology for civilian power plants.
India would not transfer fuel and equipment to weapons program and allow inspections.
US-Indian cooperation in energy and satellite technology would also expand under the plan.

Twenty-nine people were hanged in Iran for various crimes, including murder, drug dealing, and public nuisance.
Convicts were tried by the highest judicial authorities and found guilty of their charges.
The hangings were carried out as a warning to those who contemplate committing similar crimes.
Iran executed 317 people last year, second only to China's 470.

Here are the highlights:

The US government fined Genwal Resources $1.85 million for coal mine safety violations.
Insufficient pillar support and mining activity caused the August 2007 mine collapse in Utah.
Six miners were killed and three rescuers died in subsequent collapses.
The mine's owner, Genwal Resources, had denied using retreat mining at the time of the disaster.

Two Roma girls, aged 12 and 13, drowned at a beach in southern Italy.
Their bodies were laid out on the sand, with sunbathers nearby, seemingly indifferent.
The incident sparked outrage and condemnation from the Archbishop of Naples and civil liberties groups.
The event occurred amid heightened tensions between Italian authorities and the Roma minority.

Here are the highlights:

Congress overrides President Bush's veto to halt Medicare payment cuts to doctors.
The bill stops a 10.6% cut in Medicare payments to doctors, effective July 1.
The money will be taken from the Medicare Advantage program, supported by the Bush administration.
The bill was passed with a strong majority in both the House and Senate.

Iran to execute 30 people convicted of drug and criminal charges on Sunday.
Verdicts are final, and sentences will be carried out as planned.
Convicted crimes include murder, drug dealing, armed robbery, and smuggling arms.
Iran executed 317 people last year, second only to China.

Senate votes to move forward on bill to crack down on oil speculation.
Democrats blame speculation for rising oil prices, Republicans want to offer amendments.
Bill aims to limit speculation, increase transparency in oil markets and punish manipulators.
Final vote expected before August recess, with no guarantee of passage.

Here are the highlights:

Kerstin Fritzl, 19, has woken from a coma after being held captive in a cellar for decades.
She is the daughter of Josef Fritzl, who confessed to raping her and fathering seven children.
Kerstin's mother, Elisabeth, was held captive for 24 years and had seven children with her father.
Doctors are now investigating the case to shed light on what occurred during her captivity.

Iraqi officials to meet IOC on Monday to lift ban on Olympic participation.
Iraq's sports minister is optimistic about reaching an agreement to participate in the games.
Iraq is considering legal action against the IOC if the ban is not lifted.
Iraqi athletes may still compete in track and field if the original committee is reinstated.

Two teenage girls from Britain were arrested in Ghana for trying to smuggle 13 lbs of cocaine back to the UK.
They were sentenced to nine months in jail, but served over six months in custody.
Ghanaian authorities later changed their minds, and the girls served the full sentence.
The girls were "pawns in a larger operation" and the men behind the plot remain at large.

Cambodia sends letter to UN Security Council to address standoff with Thailand over ancient border temple.
Cambodia and Thailand agree to meet to defuse tensions, despite each side amassing troops.
Preah Vihear temple, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, sits on Cambodian soil but has Thai entrance.
Tensions escalated after Cambodia listed the temple as a World Heritage Site, sparking Thai opposition.

Here are the highlights:

• "The Dark Knight" opened to huge crowds and rave reviews, with Heath Ledger's Joker getting much of the praise.
• iReporter Chelsea Itson said the movie left her feeling "jittery" and she couldn't sleep afterward.
• Many fans, including Christina Perez, wore Joker makeup as a tribute to Heath Ledger, who died before the film's release.
• Fans praised Ledger's dark and disturbing portrayal of the Joker, saying it was one of the best villain portrayals of all time.

Here are the highlights:

A blue-ribbon panel recommends a new law requiring presidential consultation with Congress before going to war.
The current War Powers Resolution is "ineffective" and should be repealed and replaced.
The new law would require presidential consultation with key Congressional leaders before sending troops into combat.
Congress would have 30 days to declare war or vote on a resolution of approval.

Dubai forgives Iraq's nearly $7 billion debt, UAE President Sheikh Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan announces.
UAE promises to appoint an ambassador to Iraq and help rebuild holy shrines.
Iraqi Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki meets with UAE President, discussing debt relief and reconstruction.
UAE Cabinet nominates Abdullah Ibrahim al-Shehhi as ambassador to Iraq, with plans to reopen embassy by year-end.

Here are the highlights:

Shada, an Iraqi woman, carries her husband Murtada around the house after a bombing blew off his legs.
Murtada, a 29-year-old taxi driver, was once proud but now relies on his wife for daily care.
Shada's daily burden is immense, leaving her unable to work or leave the house.
She cares for her husband and 3-year-old son, struggling to make ends meet.

Indian and Pakistani military officials met to discuss a border clash in Kashmir, the first since 2003.
Indian army says Pakistani troops crossed the Line of Control, sparking a firefight.
Pakistan denies its troops crossed the border, claims Indian soldiers initiated the fight.
Four Pakistani soldiers reportedly killed, but Pakistan denies any casualties.

Here are the highlights:

"Mad Men" and "Damages" lead Emmy nominations with 16 and 12 nods respectively.
HBO's "The Wire" again snubbed despite critical acclaim and fan devotion.
"Curb Your Enthusiasm" and "Entourage" among comedy series nominees.
"John Adams" leads all nominees with 23 nominations, followed by "Recount" with 11.

A Virginia judge approved an $11 million settlement for the families of 24 victims of the 2007 Virginia Tech shootings.
The settlement also compensates 18 people injured in the attack.
Families of the remaining eight deceased victims will have their claims resolved at a later date.
The settlement includes provisions for family meetings with the governor and Virginia Tech officials.

Here are the highlights:

A female soldier, 2nd Lt. Holley Wimunc, is missing after an arson fire at her apartment near Fort Bragg.
A neighbor reported seeing a man running from the area and smelling smoke on Wednesday night.
Wimunc's husband, John, is a Marine stationed at Camp Lejeune and has a history of domestic violence.
The FBI is investigating the disappearance as a missing person case.

Here are the highlights:

US Army's official history shows mistakes made in early months of Iraq war, including underestimating chaos and troop needs.
Military leaders' decisions, such as transferring control to a new headquarters, were criticized as "a recipe for disaster".
Insurgency took root as US troops struggled to secure the country, with some calling it a "window of opportunity lost".
US commanders and historians agree that wrong assumptions led to the wrong plan, resulting in a prolonged and costly conflict.

Here are the highlights:

House inspector-general to investigate allegations of sexual misconduct among congressional pages.
Two pages dismissed for allegedly having oral sex in public areas of their dormitory.
Rep. Ginny Brown-Waite resigns from House Page Board, citing lax oversight.
No members of Congress involved in the current controversy, officials say.

Starbucks closing over two-thirds of its 84 stores in Australia, leaving 23 cafes open.
Closures to take place by the weekend, affecting Brisbane, Melbourne, and Sydney.
Company also closing 600 stores in the US, announced earlier this month.
Starbucks has over 8,000 company-operated stores and 6,800 licensed cafes globally.

Here are the highlights:

North Carolina man Edgar Patino charged with murdering pregnant Fort Bragg soldier Megan Touma.
Patino is the father of Touma's unborn child and was arrested at his home.
Police found evidence linking him to anonymous letters sent to derail the investigation.
Patino faces first-degree murder charges with a maximum penalty of death or life in prison.

Canada sends warship to Somalia to protect UN aid ships from pirate attacks.
HMCS Ville de Quebec will escort food aid ships to designated ports.
The ship is armed with torpedoes, surface-to-air missiles, and other weapons.
Canada's mission will last a few weeks before other governments take over.

Here are the highlights:

Seventeenth person dies from injuries in Texas bus crash, 33-39 others injured.
Bus driver lost control on US 75, crashed into guardrail and rolled into a gully.
Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration says bus was operating illegally.
Driver's medical certificate had expired, bus had no seat belts.

Here are the highlights:

Connie Nielsen became an actress to be an outsider, allowing her to say what others dare not.
She refuses fame and money, focusing on good work and artistic growth.
Nielsen has appeared in films like "Gladiator", "One Hour Photo", and "The Hunted".
She chooses roles that challenge her, tackling complex subjects like war and social issues.

Radovan Karadzic, former Bosnian Serb leader, arrested after 10 years as a fugitive.
Charged with genocide, complicity in genocide, and other war crimes in Bosnia's 1992-1995 conflict.
Karadzic's troops massacred hundreds of thousands of Muslims and Croats during "ethnic cleansing" campaign.
He was born in 1945 and studied psychiatry and medicine before becoming a politician.

Here are the highlights:

125,000 Western lowland gorillas found in Congo swamp, double previous estimated population.
Researchers trekked through mud for three days to reach the remote area.
Gorillas are listed as critically endangered due to hunting and diseases like Ebola.
Discovery indicates gorilla population remains stable in some areas, but threats persist.

Here are the highlights:

A passenger train crashed into a collapsed overpass in the Czech Republic, killing at least 6 people.
The EuroCity train was traveling from Krakow to Prague, carrying Iron Maiden concert-goers.
The train derailed when a bridge under construction fell down as it approached.
At least 41 others were injured in the accident.

Here are the highlights:

Gas prices soar to record highs, with California and Alaska having the highest prices.
Missouri has the lowest gas prices, with a gallon of regular gas at $3.862.
California's high prices are due to a "boutique blend" of fuel required to meet environmental standards.
Independent gas station owners struggle to stay afloat due to high prices and reduced profits.

Sen. John McCain urges international peacekeeping mission to Georgia and review of Russia's WTO membership.
McCain's campaign attacks Obama's foreign policy credentials, citing lack of experience with Georgia.
Obama calls for cease-fire and direct diplomacy with Russia, urging Georgia to show restraint.
McCain says crisis in Georgia should not be used for partisan gain, but his campaign continues to criticize Obama's response.

Here are the highlights:

Three aid workers shot in Somalia, two fatally, including head of UN Development Program.
One aid worker, Mohamed Mohamud Qeyre, was shot outside his office in Mogadishu.
Another aid worker, Ali Baashi, was also targeted and killed in a separate incident.
Aid operations in Somalia to be suspended due to the attacks.

Here are the highlights:

A Spanair jet crashed on takeoff at Madrid's Barajas Airport, killing 153 people.
The plane was carrying 172 people, with 19 survivors, including two infants.
The cause of the crash is unknown, but one engine caught fire.
The airport was closed but reopened after two hours, allowing limited flights.

Here are the highlights:

A Greyhound Canada bus passenger stabbed and decapitated a sleeping man on board.
Witnesses described the attack as sudden and brutal, with a bloodcurdling scream.
Passengers quickly exited the bus and used tools to keep the suspect contained until police arrived.
The suspect was seized with the help of negotiators, and no one else was injured.

Here are the highlights:

A magnitude-5.4 earthquake struck the Los Angeles metropolitan area, causing no serious damage or injuries.
The quake's epicenter was 2 miles southwest of Chino Hills and 5 miles southeast of Diamond Bar.
The temblor was a warning to southern Californians, with a 5% chance of being a precursor to a larger earthquake.
Seismologists say the "Big One" remains a possibility, with a 99% chance of a magnitude 6.7 or larger quake within 30 years.

Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf resigns after nine years in power.
US and Britain praise Musharraf's contribution to the war on terror.
Musharraf's resignation is seen as a step towards democracy in Pakistan.
US officials kept out of the struggle between Musharraf and the parliament.

Here are the highlights:

Two men who claimed to have found Bigfoot's carcass admit it was a hoax, a joke that got out of hand.
They used an Internet-purchased Sasquatch costume, possum roadkill, and slaughterhouse leftovers.
Former police officer Matt Whitton was fired for his role in the hoax.
The two men hired an attorney, saying they face threats of civil and criminal prosecution.

Here are the highlights:

A slim majority of Americans think churches should stay out of politics, a new survey suggests.
Fifty-two percent of respondents say churches should stay quiet, while 46 percent say they should express views.
The shift is most pronounced among Republicans, with 11-point increase in those saying churches should not endorse candidates.
The survey also found growing discomfort with politicians discussing their religious beliefs.

Swedish wrestler Ara Abrahamian stripped of bronze medal for discarding it during presentation ceremony.
Abrahamian disqualified from tournament, citing "blatant errors in judging" and feeling he deserved gold.
He violated Olympic charter rules on demonstrations and respect for athletes.
Abrahamian never apologized or expressed regret for his actions.

Here are the highlights:

Tropical Storm Fay made landfall in southwestern Florida at Cape Romano, just south of Marco Island.
Maximum sustained winds were near 60 mph, with higher gusts, and tropical storm force winds extended 125 miles.
Fay is expected to continue moving north-northeasterly, passing near Orlando and entering the Atlantic on Wednesday.
Rainfall amounts up to 10 inches are expected across southern and east-central Florida.

Former Olympic champion Angel Matos faces life ban for kicking referee in the face during taekwondo bronze medal match.
